text:
ííííThe Poems of Goethe

ííííTranslated in the original metresby Edgar Alfred Bowring

ííííTHE TRANSLATOR'S ORIGINAL DEDICATION.

ííííTO THE COUNTESS GRANVILLE.

ííííMY DEAR LADY GRANVILLE,--

ííííTHE reluctance which must naturally be felt by any one inventuring to give to the world a book such as the present, wherethe beauties of the great original must inevitably be diminished,if not destroyed, in the process of passing through thetranslator's hands, cannot but be felt in all its force when thattranslator has not penetrated beyond the outer courts of thepoetic fane, and can have no hope of advancing further, or ofreaching its sanctuary. But it is to me a subject of peculiarsatisfaction that your kind permission to have your nameinscribed upon this page serves to attain a twofold end--onedirect and personal, and relating to the present day; the otherreflected and historical, and belonging to times long gone by. Ofthe first little need now be said, for the privilege is whollymine, in making this dedication: as to the second, one word ofexplanation will suffice for those who have made the greatestpoet of Germany, almost of the world, their study, and to whomthe story of his life is not unknown. All who have followed thecareer of GOETHE are familiar with the name and character ofDALBERG, and also with the deep and lasting friendship thatexisted between them, from which SCHILLER too was not absent;recalling to the mind the days of old, when a Virgil and a Horaceand a Maecenas sat side by side.

ííííRemembering, then, the connection that, in a former century,was formed and riveted between your illustrious ancestor and himwhom it is the object of these pages to represent, I deem it ahappy augury that the link then established finds itself notwholly severed even now (although its strength may beimmeasurably weakened in the comparison), inasmuch as this pagebrings them once more in contact, the one in the person of hisown descendant, the other in that of the translator of his Poems.

ííííBelieve me, with great truth,Very faithfully yours,EDGAR A. BOWRING.London, April, 1853.

ííííORIGINAL PREFACE.

ííííI feel no small reluctance in venturing to give to the public awork of the character of that indicated by the title-page to thepresent volume; for, difficult as it must always be to rendersatisfactorily into one's own tongue the writings of the bards ofother lands, the responsibility assumed by the translator isimmeasurably increased when he attempts to transfer the thoughtsof those great men, who have lived for all the world and for allages, from the language in which they were originally clothed, toone to which they may as yet have been strangers. Preeminentlyis this the case with Goethe, the most masterly of all the masterminds of modern times, whose name is already inscribed on thetablets of immortality, and whose fame already extends over theearth, although as yet only in its infancy. Scarcely have twodecades passed away since he ceased to dwell among men, yet henow stands before us, not as a mere individual, like those whomthe world is wont to call great, but as a type, as an emblem--therecognised emblem and representative of the human mind in itspresent stage of culture and advancement.

ííííAmong the infinitely varied effusions of Goethe's pen, perhapsthere are none which are of as general interest as his Poems,which breathe the very spirit of Nature, and embody the realmusic of the feelings. In Germany, they are universally known,and are considered as the most delightful of his works. Yet inthis country, this kindred country, sprung from the same stem,and so strongly resembling her sister in so many points, they arenearly unknown. Almost the only poetical work of the greatestPoet that the world has seen for ages, that is really andgenerally read in England, is Faust, the translations of whichare almost endless; while no single person has as yet appeared toattempt to give, in an English dress, in any collective orsystematic manner, those smaller productions of the genius ofGoethe which it is the object of the present volume to lay beforethe reader, whose indulgence is requested for its manyimperfections. In addition to the beauty of the language in whichthe Poet has given utterance to his thoughts, there is a depth ofmeaning in those thoughts which is not easily discoverable atfirst sight, and the translator incurs great risk of overlookingit, and of giving a prosaic effect to that which in the originalcontains the very essence of poetry. It is probably thisdifficulty that has deterred others from undertaking the task Ihave set myself, and in which I do not pretend to do more thanattempt to give an idea of the minstrelsy of one so unrivalled,by as truthful an interpretation of it as lies in my power.

ííííThe principles which have guided me on the present occasion arethe same as those followed in the translation of Schiller'scomplete Poems that was published by me in 1851, namely, asliteral a rendering of the original as is consistent with goodEnglish, and also a very strict adherence to the metre of theoriginal. Although translators usually allow themselves greatlicense in both these points, it appears to me that by so doingthey of necessity destroy the very soul of the work they professto translate. In fact, it is not a translation, but a paraphrasethat they give. It may perhaps be thought that the presenttranslations go almost to the other extreme, and that a renderingof metre, line for line, and word for word, makes it impossibleto preserve the poetry of the original both in substance and insound. But experience has convinced me that it is not so, andthat great fidelity is even the most essential element ofsuccess, whether in translating poetry or prose. It was thereforevery satisfactory to me to find that the principle laid down byme to myself in translating Schiller met with the very general,if not universal, approval of the reader. At the same time, Ihave endeavoured to profit in the case of this, the younger bornof the two attempts made by me to transplant the muse of Germanyto the shores of Britain, by the criticisms, whether friendly orhostile, that have been evoked or provoked by the appearance ofits elder brother.

ííííAs already mentioned, the latter contained the whole of thePoems of Schiller. It is impossible, in anything like the samecompass, to give all the writings of Goethe comprised under thegeneral title of Gedichte, or poems. They contain between 30,000and 40,000 verses, exclusive of his plays. and similar works.Very many of these would be absolutely without interest to theEnglish reader,--such as those having only a local application,those addressed to individuals, and so on. Others again, fromtheir extreme length, could only be published in separatevolumes. But the impossibility of giving all need form noobstacle to giving as much as possible; and it so happens thatthe real interest of Goethe's Poems centres in those classes ofthem which are not too diffuse to run any risk when translated ofoffending the reader by their too great number. Those by far themore generally admired are the Songs and Ballads, which are about150 in number, and the whole of which are contained in thisvolume (with the exception of one or two of the former, whichhave been, on consideration, left out by me owing to theirtrifling and uninteresting nature). The same may be said of theOdes, Sonnets, Miscellaneous Poems, &c.

ííííIn addition to those portions of Goethe's poetical works whichare given in this complete form, specimens of the different otherclasses of them, such as the Epigrams, Elegies, &c., are added,as well as a collection of the various Songs found in his Plays,making a total number of about 400 Poems, embraced in the presentvolume.

ííííA sketch of the life of Goethe is prefixed, in order that thereader may have before him both the Poet himself and the Poet'soffspring, and that he may see that the two are but one--thatGoethe lives in his works, that his works lived in him.

ííííThe dates of the different Poems are appended throughout, thatof the first publication being given, when that of thecomposition is unknown. The order of arrangement adopted is thatof the authorized German editions. As Goethe would never arrangethem himself in the chronological order of their composition, ithas become impossible to do so, now that he is dead. The planadopted in the present volume would therefore seem to be thebest, as it facilitates reference to the original. Thecircumstances attending or giving rise to the production of anyof the Poems will be found specified in those cases in which theyhave been ascertained by me.

ííííHaving said thus much by way of explanation, I now leave thebook to speak for itself, and to testify to its own character.Whether viewed with a charitable eye by the kindly reader, whowill make due allowance for the difficulties attending itsexecution, or received by the critic, who will judge of it onlyby its own merits, with the unfriendly welcome which it veryprobably deserves, I trust that I shall at least be pardoned formaking an attempt, a failure in which does not necessarily implydisgrace, and which, by leading the way, may perhaps become themeans of inducing some abler and more worthy (but not moreearnest) labourer to enter upon the same field, the riches ofwhich will remain unaltered and undiminished in value, evenalthough they may be for the moment tarnished by the hands of theless skilful workman who first endeavours to transplant them to aforeign soil.

ííííPREFACE TO THE SECOND EDITION.

ííííI have taken advantage of the publication of a Second Editionof my translation of the Poems of Goethe (originally published in1853), to add to the Collection a version of the much admiredclassical Poem of Hermann and Dorothea, which was previouslyomitted by me in consequence of its length. Its universalpopularity, however, and the fact that it exhibits theversatility of Goethe's talents to a greater extent than,perhaps, any other of his poetical works, seem to call for itsadmission into the present volume.

ííííOn the other hand I have not thought it necessary to includethe sketch of Goethe's Life that accompanied the First Edition.At the time of its publication, comparatively little was known inthis country of the incidents of his career, and my sketch wasavowedly written as a temporary stop-gap, as it were, pending theproduction of some work really deserving the tittle of a life ofGoethe. Not to mention other contributions to the literature ofthe subject, Mr. Lewis's important volumes give the Englishreader all the information he is likely to require respectingGoethe's career, and my short memoir appeared to be no longerrequired.

ííííI need scarcely add that I have availed myself of thisopportunity to make whatever improvements have suggestedthemselves to me in my original version of these Poems.

ííííE. A. B.London, 1874.

ííííEpilogue to Schiller's Song of the Bell

ííííL'ENVOI

ííííTHE POEMS OF GOETHE.

ííííDEDICATION.

ííííThe morn arrived; his footstep quickly scared

ííííThe gentle sleep that round my senses clung,And I, awak'ning, from my cottage fared,

ííííAnd up the mountain side with light heart sprung;At every step I felt my gaze ensnared

ííííBy new-born flow'rs that full of dew-drops hung;The youthful day awoke with ecstacy,And all things quicken'd were, to quicken me.

ííííAnd as I mounted, from the valley rose

ííííA streaky mist, that upward slowly spread,Then bent, as though my form it would enclose,

ííííThen, as on pinions, soar'd above my head:My gaze could now on no fair view repose,

ííííin mournful veil conceal'd, the world seem'd dead;The clouds soon closed around me, as a tomb,And I was left alone in twilight gloom.

ííííAt once the sun his lustre seem'd to pour,

ííííAnd through the mist was seen a radiant light;Here sank it gently to the ground once more,

ííííThere parted it, and climb'd o'er wood and height.How did I yearn to greet him as of yore,

ííííAfter the darkness waxing doubly bright!The airy conflict ofttimes was renew'd,Then blinded by a dazzling glow I stood.

ííííEre long an inward impulse prompted me

ííííA hasty glance with boldness round to throw;At first mine eyes had scarcely strength to see,

ííííFor all around appear'd to burn and glow.Then saw I, on the clouds borne gracefully,

ííííA godlike woman hov'ring to and fro.In life I ne'er had seen a form so fair--She gazed at me, and still she hover'd there.

íííí"Dost thou not know me?" were the words she said

ííííIn tones where love and faith were sweetly bound;"Knowest thou not Her who oftentimes hath shed

ííííThe purest balsam in each earthly wound?Thou knows't me well; thy panting heart I led

ííííTo join me in a bond with rapture crown'd.Did I not see thee, when a stripling, yearningTo welcome me with tears, heartfelt and burning?"

íííí"Yes!" I exclaim'd, whilst, overcome with joy,

ííííI sank to earth; "I long have worshipp'd thee;Thou gav'st me rest, when passions rack'd the boy,

ííííPervading ev'ry limb unceasingly;Thy heav'nly pinions thou didst then employ

ííííThe scorching sunbeams to ward off from me.From thee alone Earth's fairest gifts I gain'd,Through thee alone, true bliss can be obtain'd.

íííí"Thy name I know not; yet I hear thee nam'd

ííííBy many a one who boasts thee as his own;Each eye believes that tow'rd thy form 'tis aim'd,

ííííYet to most eyes thy rays are anguish-sown.Ah! whilst I err'd, full many a friend I claim'd,

ííííNow that I know thee, I am left alone;With but myself can I my rapture share,I needs must veil and hide thy radiance fair.

ííííShe smiled, and answering said: "Thou see'st how wise,

ííííHow prudent 'twas but little to unveil!Scarce from the clumsiest cheat are clear'd thine eyes,

ííííScarce hast thou strength thy childish bars to scale,When thou dost rank thee 'mongst the deities,

ííííAnd so man's duties to perform would'st fail!How dost thou differ from all other men?Live with the world in peace, and know thee then!"

íííí"Oh, pardon me," I cried, "I meant it well:

ííííNot vainly did'st thou bless mine eyes with light;For in my blood glad aspirations swell,

ííííThe value of thy gifts I know aright!Those treasures in my breast for others dwell,

ííííThe buried pound no more I'll hide from sight.Why did I seek the road so anxiously,If hidden from my brethren 'twere to be?"

ííííAnd as I answer'd, tow'rd me turn'd her face,

ííííWith kindly sympathy, that god-like one;Within her eye full plainly could I trace

ííííWhat I had fail'd in, and what rightly done.She smiled, and cured me with that smile's sweet grace,

ííííTo new-born joys my spirit soar'd anon;With inward confidence I now could dareTo draw yet closer, and observe her there.

ííííThrough the light cloud she then stretch'd forth her hand,

ííííAs if to bid the streaky vapour fly:At once it seemed to yield to her command,

ííííContracted, and no mist then met mine eye.My glance once more survey'd the smiling land,

ííííUnclouded and serene appear'd the sky.Nought but a veil of purest white she held,And round her in a thousand folds it swell'd.

íííí"I know thee, and I know thy wav'ring will.

ííííI know the good that lives and glows in thee!"--Thus spake she, and methinks I hear her still--

íííí"The prize long destined, now receive from me;That blest one will be safe from ev'ry ill,

ííííWho takes this gift with soul of purity,--"The veil of Minstrelsy from Truth's own hand,Of sunlight and of morn's sweet fragrance plann'd.

íííí"And when thou and thy friends at fierce noon-day

ííííAre parched with heat, straight cast it in the air!Then Zephyr's cooling breath will round you play,

ííííDistilling balm and flowers' sweet incense there;The tones of earthly woe will die away,

ííííThe grave become a bed of clouds so fair,To sing to rest life's billows will be seen,The day be lovely, and the night serene."--

ííííCome, then, my friends! and whensoe'er ye find

ííííUpon your way increase life's heavy load;If by fresh-waken'd blessings flowers are twin'd

ííííAround your path, and golden fruits bestow'd,We'll seek the coming day with joyous mind!

ííííThus blest, we'll live, thus wander on our roadAnd when our grandsons sorrow o'er our tomb,Our love, to glad their bosoms, still shall bloom.

ííííSONGS.-----Late resounds the early strain;Weal and woe in song remain.-----SOUND, SWEET SONG.

ííííSOUND, sweet song, from some far land,Sighing softly close at hand,

ííííNow of joy, and now of woe!

ííííStars are wont to glimmer so.

ííííSooner thus will good unfold;Children young and children oldGladly hear thy numbers flow.

In other cases, the date given isthat of the actual composition. All the poems are arranged in theorder of the recognised German editions.-----TO THE KIND READER.

ííííNo one talks more than a Poet;Fain he'd have the people know it.

ííííPraise or blame he ever loves;None in prose confess an error,Yet we do so, void of terror,

ííííIn the Muses' silent groves.

ííííWhat I err'd in, what corrected,What I suffer'd, what effected,

ííííTo this wreath as flow'rs belong;For the aged, and the youthful,And the vicious, and the truthful,

ííííAll are fair when viewed in song.

íííí1800.*-----THE NEW AMADIS.

ííííIN my boyhood's days so drear

ííííI was kept confined;There I sat for many a year,

ííííAll alone I pined,As within the womb.

ííííYet thou drov'st away my gloom,

ííííGolden phantasy!I became a hero true,

ííííLike the Prince Pipi,And the world roam'd through,

ííííMany a crystal palace built,

ííííCrush'd them with like art,And the Dragon's life-blood spilt

ííííWith my glitt'ring dart.Yes! I was a man!

ííííNext I formed the knightly plan

ííííPrincess Fish to free;She was much too complaisant,

ííííKindly welcomed me,--And I was gallant.

ííííHeav'nly bread her kisses proved,

ííííGlowing as the wine;Almost unto death I loved.

ííííSun-s appeared to shineIn her dazzling charms.

ííííWho hath torn her from mine arms?

ííííCould no magic bandMake her in her flight delay?

ííííSay, where now her land?Where, alas, the way?

íííí1775.*-----WHEN THE FOX DIES, HIS SKIN COUNTS.*

íííí(* The name of a game, known in English as "Jack's alight.")

ííííWE young people in the shade

ííííSat one sultry day;Cupid came, and "Dies the Fox"

ííííWith us sought to play.

ííííEach one of my friends then sat

ííííBy his mistress dear;Cupid, blowing out the torch,

ííííSaid: "The taper's here!"

ííííThen we quickly sent around

ííííThe expiring brand;Each one put it hastily

ííííln his neighbour's hand.

ííííDorilis then gave it me,

ííííWith a scoffing jest;Sudden into flame it broke,

ííííBy my fingers press'd.

ííííAnd it singed my eyes and face,

ííííSet my breast on fire;Then above my head the blaze

ííííMounted ever higher.

ííííVain I sought to put it out;

ííííEver burned the flame;Stead of dying, soon the Fox

ííííLivelier still became.

íííí1770.-----THE HEATHROSE.

ííííONCE a boy a Rosebud spied,

ííííHeathrose fair and tender,All array'd in youthful pride,--Quickly to the spot he hied,

ííííRavished by her splendour.Rosebud, rosebud, rosebud red,

ííííHeathrose fair and tender!

ííííSaid the boy, "I'll now pick thee,

ííííHeathrose fair and tender!"Said the rosebud, "I'll prick thee,So that thou'lt remember me,

ííííNe'er will I surrender!"Rosebud, rosebud, rosebud red,

ííííHeathrose fair and tender!

ííííNow the cruel boy must pick

ííííHeathrose fair and tender;Rosebud did her best to prick,--Vain 'twas 'gainst her fate to kick--

ííííShe must needs surrender.Rosebud, rosebud, rosebud red,

ííííHeathrose fair and tender!

íííí1779.*-----BLINDMAN'S BUFF.

ííííOH, my Theresa dear!Thine eyes, I greatly fear,

ííííCan through the bandage see!Although thine eyes are bound,By thee I'm quickly found,

ííííAnd wherefore shouldst thou catch but me?

ííííEre long thou held'st me fast,With arms around me cast,

ííííUpon thy breast I fell;Scarce was thy bandage gone,When all my joy was flown,

ííííThou coldly didst the blind repel.

ííííHe groped on ev'ry side,His limbs he sorely tried,

ííííWhile scoffs arose all round;If thou no love wilt give,In sadness I shall live,

ííííAs if mine eyes remain'd still bound.

íííí1770.-----CHRISTEL.

ííííMy senses ofttimes are oppress'd,

ííííOft stagnant is my blood;But when by Christel's sight I'm blest,

ííííI feel my strength renew'd.I see her here, I see her there,

ííííAnd really cannot tellThe manner how, the when, the where,

ííííThe why I love her well.

ííííIf with the merest glance I view

ííííHer black and roguish eyes,And gaze on her black eyebrows too,

ííííMy spirit upward flies.Has any one a mouth so sweet,

ííííSuch love-round cheeks as she?Ah, when the eye her beauties meet,

ííííIt ne'er content can be.

ííííAnd when in airy German dance

ííííI clasp her form divine,So quick we whirl, so quick advance,

ííííWhat rapture then like mine!And when she's giddy, and feels warm,

ííííI cradle her, poor thing,Upon my breast, and in mine arm,--

ííííI'm then a very king!

ííííAnd when she looks with love on me,

ííííForgetting all but this,When press'd against my bosom, she

ííííExchanges kiss for kiss,All through my marrow runs a thrill,

ííííRuns e'en my foot along!I feel so well, I feel so ill,

ííííI feel so weak, so strong!

ííííWould that such moments ne'er would end!

ííííThe day ne'er long I find;Could I the night too with her spend,

ííííE'en that I should not mind.If she were in mine arms but held,

ííííTo quench love's thirst I'd try;And could my torments not be quell'd,

ííííUpon her breast would die.

íííí1776.*------THE COY ONE.

ííííONE Spring-morning bright and fair,

ííííRoam'd a shepherdess and sang;Young and beauteous, free from care,

ííííThrough the fields her clear notes rang:So, Ia, Ia! le ralla, &c.

ííííOf his lambs some two or three

ííííThyrsis offer'd for a kiss;First she eyed him roguishly,

ííííThen for answer sang but this:So, Ia, Ia! le ralla, &c.

ííííRibbons did the next one offer,

ííííAnd the third, his heart so trueBut, as with the lambs, the scoffer

ííííLaugh'd at heart and ribbons too,--Still 'twas Ia! le ralla, &c.

íííí1791.-----THE CONVERT.

ííííAs at sunset I was straying

ííííSilently the wood along,Damon on his flute was playing,

ííííAnd the rocks gave back the song,So la, Ia! &c.

ííííSoftly tow'rds him then he drew me;

ííííSweet each kiss he gave me then!And I said, "Play once more to me!"

ííííAnd he kindly play'd again,So la, la! &c.

ííííAll my peace for aye has fleeted,

ííííAll my happiness has flown;Yet my ears are ever greeted

ííííWith that olden, blissful tone,So la, la! &c.

íííí1791.-----PRESERVATION.

ííííMy maiden she proved false to me;

ííííTo hate all joys I soon began,

ííííThen to a flowing stream I ran,--The stream ran past me hastily.

ííííThere stood I fix'd, in mute despair;

ííííMy head swam round as in a dream;

ííííI well-nigh fell into the stream,And earth seem'd with me whirling there.

ííííSudden I heard a voice that cried--

ííííI had just turn'd my face from thence--

ííííIt was a voice to charm each sense:"Beware, for deep is yonder tide!"

ííííA thrill my blood pervaded now,

ííííI look'd and saw a beauteous maid

ííííI asked her name--twas Kate, she said--"Oh lovely Kate! how kind art thou!

íííí"From death I have been sav'd by thee,

íííí'Tis through thee only that I live;

ííííLittle 'twere life alone to give,My joy in life then deign to be!"

ííííAnd then I told my sorrows o'er,

ííííHer eyes to earth she sweetly threw;

ííííI kiss'd her, and she kiss'd me too,And--then I talked of death no more.

íííí1775.*-----THE MUSES' SON.

íííí[Goethe quotes the beginning of this song in his Autobiography,as expressing the manner in which his poetical effusions used topour out from him.]

ííííTHROUGH field and wood to stray,And pipe my tuneful lay,--

íííí'Tis thus my days are pass'd;And all keep tune with me,And move in harmony,

ííííAnd so on, to the last.

ííííTo wait I scarce have powerThe garden's earliest flower,

ííííThe tree's first bloom in Spring;They hail my joyous strain,--When Winter comes again,

ííííOf that sweet dream I sing.

ííííMy song sounds far and near,O'er ice it echoes clear,

ííííThen Winter blossoms bright;And when his blossoms fly,Fresh raptures meet mine eye,

ííííUpon the well-till'd height.

ííííWhen 'neath the linden tree,Young folks I chance to see,

ííííI set them moving soon;His nose the dull lad curls,The formal maiden whirls,

ííííObedient to my tune.

ííííWings to the feet ye lend,O'er hill and vale ye send

ííííThe lover far from home;When shall I, on your breast,.

ííííYe kindly muses, rest,And cease at length to roam?

íííí1800.*------FOUND.

ííííONCE through the forest

ííííAlone I went;To seek for nothing

ííííMy thoughts were bent.

ííííI saw i' the shadow

ííííA flower stand thereAs stars it glisten'd,

ííííAs eyes 'twas fair.

ííííI sought to pluck it,--

ííííIt gently said:"Shall I be gather'd

ííííOnly to fade?"

ííííWith all its roots

ííííI dug it with care,And took it home

ííííTo my garden fair.

ííííIn silent corner

ííííSoon it was set;There grows it ever,

ííííThere blooms it yet.

íííí1815.*-----LIKE AND LIKE.

ííííA FAIR bell-flower

ííííSprang tip from the ground;And early its fragrance

ííííIt shed all around;A bee came thither

ííííAnd sipp'd from its bell;That they for each other

ííííWere made, we see well.

íííí1814.-----RECIPROCAL INVITATION TO THE DANCE.

ííííTHE INDIFFERENT.

ííííCOME to the dance with me, come with me, fair one!

ííííDances a feast-day like this may well crown.If thou my sweetheart art not, thou canst be so,

ííííBut if thou wilt not, we still will dance on.Come to the dance with me, come with me, fair one!

ííííDances a feast-day like this may well crown.

ííííTHE TENDER.

ííííLoved one, without thee, what then would all feast be?

ííííSweet one, without thee, what then were the dance?If thou my sweetheart wert not, I would dance not.

ííííIf thou art still so, all life is one feast.Loved one, without thee, what then would all feasts be?

ííííSweet one, without thee, what then were the dance?

ííííTHE INDIFFERENT.

ííííLet them but love, then, and leave us the dancing!

ííííLanguishing love cannot bear the glad dance.Let us whirl round in the waltz's gay measure,

ííííAnd let them steal to the dim-lighted wood.Let them but love, then, and leave us the dancing!

ííííLanguishing love cannot bear the glad dance.

ííííTHE TENDER.

ííííLet them whirl round, then, and leave us to wander!

ííííWand'ring to love is a heavenly dance.Cupid, the near one, o'erhears their deriding,

ííííVengeance takes suddenly, vengeance takes soon.Let them whirl round, then, and leave us to wander!

ííííWand'ring to love is a heavenly dance.

íííí1789.*-----SELF-DECEIT.

ííííMy neighbour's curtain, well I see,

ííííIs moving to and fin.No doubt she's list'ning eagerly,

ííííIf I'm at home or no.

ííííAnd if the jealous grudge I bore

ííííAnd openly confess'd,Is nourish'd by me as before,

ííííWithin my inmost breast.

ííííAlas! no fancies such as these

ííííE'er cross'd the dear child's thoughts.I see 'tis but the ev'ning breeze

ííííThat with the curtain sports.

íííí1803.-----DECLARATION OF WAR.

ííííOH, would I resembled

ííííThe country girls fair,Who rosy-red ribbons

ííííAnd yellow hats wear!

ííííTo believe I was pretty

ííííI thought was allow'd;In the town I believed it

ííííWhen by the youth vow'd.

ííííNow that Spring hath return'd,

ííííAll my joys disappear;The girls of the country

ííííHave lured him from here.

ííííTo change dress and figure,

ííííWas needful I found,My bodice is longer,

ííííMy petticoat round.

ííííMy hat now is yellow.

ííííMy bodice like snow;The clover to sickle

ííííWith others I go.

ííííSomething pretty, e'er long

ííííMidst the troop he explores;The eager boy signs me

ííííTo go within doors.

ííííI bashfully go,--

ííííWho I am, he can't trace;He pinches my cheeks,

ííííAnd he looks in my face.

ííííThe town girl now threatens

ííííYou maidens with war;Her twofold charms pledges .

ííííOf victory are.

íííí1803.-----LOVER IN ALL SHAPES.

ííííTo be like a fish,Brisk and quick, is my wish;If thou cam'st with thy line.Thou wouldst soon make me thine.To be like a fish,Brisk and quick, is my wish.

ííííOh, were I a steed!Thou wouldst love me indeed.Oh, were I a carFit to bear thee afar!Oh, were I a steed!Thou wouldst love me indeed.

ííííI would I were goldThat thy fingers might hold!If thou boughtest aught then,I'd return soon again.I would I were goldThat thy fingers might hold!

ííííI would I were true,And my sweetheart still new!To be faithful I'd swear,And would go away ne'er.I would I were true,And my sweetheart still new!

ííííI would I were old,And wrinkled and cold,So that if thou said'st No,I could stand such a blow!I would I were old,And wrinkled and cold.

ííííAn ape I would be,Full of mischievous glee;If aught came to vex thee,I'd plague and perplex thee.An ape I would be,Full of mischievous glee

ííííAs a lamb I'd behave,As a lion be brave,As a lynx clearly see,As a fox cunning be.As a lamb I'd behave,As a lion be brave.

ííííWhatever I were,All on thee I'd confer;With the gifts of a princeMy affection evince.Whatever I were,All on thee I'd confer.

ííííAs nought diff'rent can make me,As I am thou must take me!If I'm not good enough,Thou must cut thine own stuff.As nought diff'rent can make me,As I am thou must take me!

íííí1815.*-----THE GOLDSMITH'S APPRENTICE.

ííííMy neighbour, none can e'er deny,

ííííIs a most beauteous maid;Her shop is ever in mine eye,

ííííWhen working at my trade.

ííííTo ring and chain I hammer then

ííííThe wire of gold assay'd,And think the while: "For Kate, oh when

ííííWill such a ring be made?"

ííííAnd when she takes her shutters down,

ííííHer shop at once invade,To buy and haggle, all the town,

ííííFor all that's there displayd.

ííííI file, and maybe overfile

ííííThe wire of gold assay'd;My master grumbles all the while,--

ííííHer shop the mischief made.

ííííTo ply her wheel she straight begins,

ííííWhen not engaged in trade;I know full well for what she spins,--

íííí'Tis hope guides that dear maid.

ííííHer leg, while her small foot treads on,

ííííIs in my mind portray'd;Her garter I recall anon,--

ííííI gave it that dear maid.

ííííThen to her lips the finest thread

ííííIs by her hand convey'd.Were I there only in its stead,

ííííHow I would kiss the maid!

íííí1808.-----ANSWERS IN A GAME OF QUESTIONS.

ííííTHE LADY.

ííííIN the small and great world too,

ííííWhat most charms a woman's heart?It is doubtless what is new,

ííííFor its blossoms joy impart;Nobler far is what is true,

ííííFor fresh blossoms it can shoot

ííííEven in the time of fruit.

ííííTHE YOUNG GENTLEMAN.

ííííWith the Nymphs in wood and cave

ííííParis was acquainted well,Till Zeus sent, to make him rave,

ííííThree of those in Heav'n who dwell;And the choice more trouble gave

ííííThan e'er fell to mortal lot,

ííííWhether in old times or not.

ííííTHE EXPERIENCED.

ííííTenderly a woman view,

ííííAnd thoult win her, take my word;He who's quick and saucy too,

ííííWill of all men be preferr'd;Who ne'er seems as if he knew

ííííIf he pleases, if he charms,--

ííííHe 'tis injures, he 'tis harms.

ííííTHE CONTENTED.

ííííManifold is human strife,

ííííHuman passion, human pain;Many a blessing yet is rife,

ííííMany pleasures still remain.Yet the greatest bliss in life,

ííííAnd the richest prize we find,

ííííIs a good, contented mind.

ííííTHE MERRY COUNSEL.

ííííHe by whom man's foolish will

ííííIs each day review'd and blamed,Who, when others fools are still,

ííííIs himself a fool proclaim'd,--Ne'er at mill was beast's back press'd

ííííWith a heavier load than he.What I feel within my breast

ííííThat in truth's the thing for me!

íííí1789.-----DIFFERENT EMOTIONS ON THE SAME SPOT.

ííííTHE MAIDEN.

ííííI'VE seen him before me!What rapture steals o'er me!

ííííOh heavenly sight!He's coming to meet me;Perplex'd, I retreat me,

ííííWith shame take to flight.My mind seems to wander!Ye rocks and trees yonder,

ííííConceal ye my rapture.

ííííConceal my delight!

ííííTHE YOUTH.

íííí'Tis here I must find her,'Twas here she enshrined her,

ííííHere vanish'd from sight.She came, as to meet me,Then fearing to greet me,

ííííWith shame took to flight.Is't hope? Do I wander?Ye rocks and trees yonder,

ííííDisclose ye the loved one,

ííííDisclose my delight!

ííííTHE LANGUISHING.

ííííO'er my sad, fate I sorrow,To each dewy morrow,

ííííVeil'd here from man's sightBy the many mistaken,Unknown and forsaken,

ííííHere I wing my flight!Compassionate spirit!Let none ever hear it,--

ííííConceal my affliction,

ííííConceal thy delight!

ííííTHE HUNTER.

ííííTo-day I'm rewarded;Rich booty's afforded

ííííBy Fortune so bright.My servant the pheasants,And hares fit for presents

ííííTakes homeward at night;Here see I enrapturedIn nets the birds captured!--

ííííLong life to the hunter!

ííííLong live his delight!

íííí1789.-----WHO'LL BUY GODS OF LOVE?

ííííOF all the beauteous waresExposed for sale at fairs,None will give more delightThan those that to your sightFrom distant lands we bring.Oh, hark to what we sing!These beauteous birds behold,They're brought here to be sold.

ííííAnd first the big one see,So full of roguish glee!With light and merry boundHe leaps upon the ground;Then springs up on the bougd,We will not praise him now.The merry bird behold,--He's brought here to be sold.

ííííAnd now the small one see!A modest look has he,And yet he's such apotherAs his big roguish brother.'Tis chiefly when all's stillHe loves to show his will.The bird so small and bold,--He's brought here to be sold.

ííííObserve this little love,This darling turtle dove!All maidens are so neat,So civil, so discreetLet them their charms set loose,And turn your love to use;The gentle bird behold,--She's brought here to be sold.

ííííTheir praises we won't tell;They'll stand inspection well.They're fond of what is new,--And yet, to show they're true,Nor seal nor letter's wanted;To all have wings been granted.The pretty birds behold,--Such beauties ne'er were sold!

íííí1795.-----THE MISANTHROPE.

ííííAT first awhile sits he,

ííííWith calm, unruffled brow;His features then I see,Distorted hideously,--

ííííAn owl's they might be now.

ííííWhat is it, askest thou?Is't love, or is't ennui?

íííí'Tis both at once, I vow.

íííí1767-9.-----DIFFERENT THREATS.

ííííI ONCE into a forest far

ííííMy maiden went to seek,And fell upon her neck, when: "Ah!"

ííííShe threaten'd, "I will shriek!"

ííííThen cried I haughtily: "I'll crush

ííííThe man that dares come near thee!""Hush!" whisper'd she: "My loved one, hush!

ííííOr else they'll overhear thee!"

íííí1767-9.-----MAIDEN WISHES.

ííííWHAT pleasure to meA bridegroom would be!When married we are,They call us mamma.No need then to sew,To school we ne'er go;Command uncontroll'd,Have maids, whom to scold;Choose clothes at our ease,Of what tradesmen we please;Walk freely about,And go to each rout,And unrestrained areBy papa or mamma.

íííí1767-9.-----MOTIVES.

ííííIF to a girl who loves us trulyHer mother gives instruction dulyIn virtue, duty, and what not,--And if she hearkens ne'er a jot,But with fresh-strengthen'd longing flies

ííííTo meet our kiss that seems to burn,--

ííííCaprice has just as much concernedAs love in her bold enterprise.

ííííBut if her mother can succeedIn gaining for her maxims heed,And softening the girl's heart too,So that she coyly shuns our view,--The heart of youth she knows but ill;

ííííFor when a maiden is thus stern,

ííííVirtue in truth has less concernIn this, than an inconstant will.

íííí1767-9.-----TRUE ENJOYMENT.

ííííVAINLY wouldst thou, to gain a heart,

ííííHeap up a maiden's lap with gold;The joys of love thou must impart,

ííííWouldst thou e'er see those joys unfold.The voices of the throng gold buys,

ííííNo single heart 'twill win for thee;Wouldst thou a maiden make thy prize,

ííííThyself alone the bribe must be.

ííííIf by no sacred tie thou'rt bound,

ííííOh youth, thou must thyself restrain!Well may true liberty be found,

ííííTho' man may seem to wear a chain.Let one alone inflame thee e'er,

ííííAnd if her heart with love o'erflows,Let tenderness unite you there,

ííííIf duty's self no fetter knows.

ííííFirst feel, oh youth! A girl then find

ííííWorthy thy choice,--let her choose thee,In body fair, and fair in mind,

ííííAnd then thou wilt be blessed, like me.I who have made this art mine own,

ííííA girl have chosen such as thisThe blessing of the priest alone

ííííIs wanting to complete our bliss.

ííííNought but my rapture is her guide,

ííííOnly for me she cares to please,--Ne'er wanton save when by my side,

ííííAnd modest when the world she sees;That time our glow may never chill,

ííííShe yields no right through frailty;Her favour is a favour still,

ííííAnd I must ever grateful be.

ííííYet I'm content, and full of joy,

ííííIf she'll but grant her smile so sweet,Or if at table she'll employ,

ííííTo pillow hers, her lover's feet,Give me the apple that she bit,

ííííThe glass from which she drank, bestow,And when my kiss so orders it,

ííííHer bosom, veil'd till then, will show.

ííííAnd when she wills of love to speak,

ííííIn fond and silent hours of bliss,Words from her mouth are all I seek,

ííííNought else I crave,--not e'en a kiss.With what a soul her mind is fraught,

ííííWreath'd round with charms unceasingly!She's perfect,--and she fails in nought

ííííSave in her deigning to love me.

ííííMy rev'rence throws me at her feet,

ííííMy longing throws me on her breast;This, youth, is rapture true and sweet,

ííííBe wise, thus seeking to be blest.When death shall take thee from her side,

ííííTo join the angelic choir above,In heaven's bright mansions to abide,--No diff'rence at the change thoult prove.

íííí1767-8.-----THE FAREWELL.

íííí[Probably addressed to his mistress Frederica.]

ííííLET mine eye the farewell say,

ííííThat my lips can utter ne'er;Fain I'd be a man to-day,

ííííYet 'tis hard, oh, hard to bear!

ííííMournful in an hour like this

ííííIs love's sweetest pledge, I ween;Cold upon thy mouth the kiss,

ííííFaint thy fingers' pressure e'en.

ííííOh what rapture to my heart

ííííUsed each stolen kiss to bring!As the violets joy impart,

ííííGather'd in the early spring.

ííííNow no garlands I entwine,

ííííNow no roses pluck. for thee,Though 'tis springtime, Fanny mine,

ííííDreary autumn 'tis to me!

íííí1771.-----THE BEAUTIFUL NIGHT.

ííííNow I leave this cottage lowly,

ííííWhere my love hath made her home,And with silent footstep slowly

ííííThrough the darksome forest roam,Luna breaks through oaks and bushes,

ííííZephyr hastes her steps to meet,And the waving birch-tree blushes,

ííííScattering round her incense sweet.

ííííGrateful are the cooling breezes

ííííOf this beauteous summer night,Here is felt the charm that pleases,

ííííAnd that gives the soul delight.Boundless is my joy; yet, Heaven,

ííííWillingly I'd leave to theeThousand such nights, were one given

ííííBy my maiden loved to me!

íííí1767-8.-----HAPPINESS AND VISION.

ííííTOGETHER at the altar weIn vision oft were seen by thee,

ííííThyself as bride, as bridegroom I.Oft from thy mouth full many a kissIn an unguarded hour of bliss

ííííI then would steal, while none were by.

ííííThe purest rapture we then knew,The joy those happy hours gave too,

ííííWhen tasted, fled, as time fleets on.What now avails my joy to me?Like dreams the warmest kisses flee,

ííííLike kisses, soon all joys are gone.

íííí1767-8.-----LIVING REMEMBRANCE.

ííííHALF vex'd, half pleased, thy love will feel,Shouldst thou her knot or ribbon steal;To thee they're much--I won't conceal;

ííííSuch self-deceit may pardon'd be;A veil, a kerchief, garter, rings,In truth are no mean trifling things,

ííííBut still they're not enough for me.

ííííShe who is dearest to my heart,Gave me, with well dissembled smart,Of her own life, a living part,

ííííNo charm in aught beside I trace;How do I scorn thy paltry ware!A lock she gave me of the hair

ííííThat wantons o'er her beauteous face.

ííííIf, loved one, we must sever'd be,Wouldst thou not wholly fly from me,I still possess this legacy,

ííííTo look at, and to kiss in play.--My fate is to the hair's allied,We used to woo her with like pride,

ííííAnd now we both are far away.

ííííHer charms with equal joy we press'd,Her swelling cheeks anon caress'd,Lured onward by a yearning blest,

ííííUpon her heaving bosom fell.Oh rival, free from envy's sway,Thou precious gift, thou beauteous prey.

ííííRemain my joy and bliss to tell!

íííí1767-9.-----THE BLISS OF ABSENCE.

ííííDRINK, oh youth, joy's purest rayFrom thy loved one's eyes all day,

ííííAnd her image paint at night!Better rule no lover knows,Yet true rapture greater grows,

ííííWhen far sever'd from her sight.

ííííPowers eternal, distance, time,Like the might of stars sublime,

ííííGently rock the blood to rest,O'er my senses softness steals,Yet my bosom lighter feels,

ííííAnd I daily am more blest.

ííííThough I can forget her ne'er,Yet my mind is free from care,

ííííI can calmly live and move;Unperceived infatuationLonging turns to adoration,

ííííTurns to reverence my love.

ííííNe'er can cloud, however light,Float in ether's regions bright,

ííííWhen drawn upwards by the sun,As my heart in rapturous calm.Free from envy and alarm,

ííííEver love I her alone!

íííí1767-9.-----TO LUNA.

ííííSISTER of the first-born light,

ííííType of sorrowing gentleness!

ííííQuivering mists in silv'ry dressFloat around thy features bright;When thy gentle foot is heard,

ííííFrom the day-closed caverns then

ííííWake the mournful ghosts of men,I, too, wake, and each night-bird.

ííííO'er a field of boundless span

ííííLooks thy gaze both far and wide.

ííííRaise me upwards to thy side!Grant this to a raving man!And to heights of rapture raised,

ííííLet the knight so crafty peep

ííííAt his maiden while asleep,Through her lattice-window glazed.

ííííSoon the bliss of this sweet view,

ííííPangs by distance caused allays;

ííííAnd I gather all thy rays,And my look I sharpen too.Round her unveil'd limbs I see

ííííBrighter still become the glow,

ííííAnd she draws me down below,As Endymion once drew thee.

íííí1767-9.-----THE WEDDING NIGHT.

ííííWITHIN the chamber, far away

ííííFrom the glad feast, sits Love in dreadLest guests disturb, in wanton play,

ííííThe silence of the bridal bed.His torch's pale flame serves to gild

ííííThe scene with mystic sacred glow;The room with incense-clouds is fil'd,

ííííThat ye may perfect rapture know.

ííííHow beats thy heart, when thou dost hear

ííííThe chime that warns thy guests to fly!How glow'st thou for those lips so dear,

ííííThat soon are mute, and nought deny!With her into the holy place

ííííThou hast'nest then, to perfect all;The fire the warder's hands embrace,

ííííGrows, like a night-light, dim and small.

ííííHow heaves her bosom, and how burns

ííííHer face at every fervent kiss!Her coldness now to trembling turns,

ííííThy daring now a duty is.Love helps thee to undress her fast,

ííííBut thou art twice as fast as he;And then he shuts both eye at last,

ííííWith sly and roguish modesty.

íííí1767.-----MISCHIEVOUS JOY.

ííííAS a butterfly renew'd,

ííííWhen in life I breath'd my last,

ííííTo the spots my flight I wing,

ííííScenes of heav'nly rapture past,

ííííOver meadows, to the spring,Round the hill, and through the wood.

ííííSoon a tender pair I spy,

ííííAnd I look down from my seat

ííííOn the beauteous maiden's head--

ííííWhen embodied there I meet

ííííAll I lost as soon as dead,Happy as before am I.

ííííHim she clasps with silent smile,

ííííAnd his mouth the hour improves,

ííííSent by kindly Deities;

ííííFirst from breast to mouth it roves,

ííííThen from mouth to hands it flies,And I round him sport the while.

ííííAnd she sees me hov'ring near;

ííííTrembling at her lovers rapture,

ííííUp she springs--I fly away,

íííí"Dearest! let's the insect capture

ííííCome! I long to make my preyYonder pretty little dear!"

íííí1767-9.-----APPARENT DEATH.

ííííWEEP, maiden, weep here o'er the tomb of Love;

ííííHe died of nothing--by mere chance was slain.But is he really dead?--oh, that I cannot prove:

ííííA nothing, a mere chance, oft gives him life again.

íííí1767-9.-----NOVEMBER SONG.

ííííTo the great archer--not to him

ííííTo meet whom flies the sun,And who is wont his features dim

ííííWith clouds to overrun--

ííííBut to the boy be vow'd these rhymes,

ííííWho 'mongst the roses plays,Who hear us, and at proper times

ííííTo pierce fair hearts essays.

ííííThrough him the gloomy winter night,

ííííOf yore so cold and drear,Brings many a loved friend to our sight,

ííííAnd many a woman dear.

ííííHenceforward shall his image fair

ííííStand in yon starry skies,And, ever mild and gracious there,

ííííAlternate set and rise.

íííí1815.*-----TO THE CHOSEN ONE.[This sweet song is doubtless one of those addressed toFrederica.]

ííííHAND in hand! and lip to lip!

ííííOh, be faithful, maiden dear!Fare thee well! thy lover's ship

ííííPast full many a rock must steersBut should he the haven see,

ííííWhen the storm has ceased to break,And be happy, reft of thee,--

ííííMay the Gods fierce vengeance take!

ííííBoldly dared is well nigh won!

ííííHalf my task is solved aright;Ev'ry star's to me a sun,

ííííOnly cowards deem it night.Stood I idly by thy side,

ííííSorrow still would sadden me;But when seas our paths divide,

ííííGladly toil I,--toil for thee!

ííííNow the valley I perceive,

ííííWhere together we will go,And the streamlet watch each eve,

ííííGliding peacefully belowOh, the poplars on yon spot!

ííííOh, the beech trees in yon grove!And behind we'll build a cot,

ííííWhere to taste the joys of love!

íííí1771.-----FIRST LOSS.

ííííAH! who'll e'er those days restore,

ííííThose bright days of early loveWho'll one hour again concede,

ííííOf that time so fondly cherish'd!Silently my wounds I feed,And with wailing evermore

ííííSorrow o'er each joy now perish'd.Ah! who'll e'er the days restore

ííííOf that time so fondly cherish'd.

íííí1789.*-----AFTER-SENSATIONS.

ííííWHEN the vine again is blowing,

ííííThen the wine moves in the cask;When the rose again is glowing,

ííííWherefore should I feel oppress'd?

ííííDown my cheeks run tears all-burning,

ííííIf I do, or leave my task;I but feel a speechless yearning,

ííííThat pervades my inmost breast.

ííííBut at length I see the reason,

ííííWhen the question I would ask:'Twas in such a beauteous season,

ííííDoris glowed to make me blest!

íííí1797.-----PROXIMITY OF THE BELOVED ONE.

ííííI THINK of thee, whene'er the sun his beams

ííííO'er ocean flings;I think  of thee, whene'er the moonlight gleams

ííííIn silv'ry springs.

ííííI see thee, when upon the distant ridge

ííííThe dust awakes;At midnight's hour, when on the fragile bridge

ííííThe wanderer quakes.

ííííI hear thee, when yon billows rise on high,

ííííWith murmur deep.To tread the silent grove oft wander I,

ííííWhen all's asleep.

ííííI'm near thee, though thou far away mayst be--

ííííThou, too, art near!The sun then sets, the stars soon lighten me.

ííííWould thou wert here!

íííí1795.-----PRESENCE.

ííííALL things give token of thee!As soon as the bright sun is shining,Thou too wilt follow, I trust.

ííííWhen in the garden thou walk'st,Thou then art the rose of all roses,Lily of lilies as well.

ííííWhen thou dost move in the dance,Then each constellation moves also;With thee and round thee they move.

ííííNight! oh, what bliss were the night!For then thou o'ershadow'st the lustre,Dazzling and fair, of the moon.

ííííDazzling and beauteous art thou,And flowers, and moon, and the planetsHomage pay, Sun, but to thee.

ííííSun! to me also be thouCreator of days bright and glorious;Life and Eternity this!

íííí1813.-----TO THE DISTANT ONE.

ííííAND have I lost thee evermore?

ííííHast thou, oh fair one, from me flown?Still in mine ear sounds, as of yore,

ííííThine ev'ry word, thine ev'ry tone.

ííííAs when at morn the wand'rer's eye

ííííAttempts to pierce the air in vain,When, hidden in the azure sky,

ííííThe lark high o'er him chaunts his strain:

ííííSo do I cast my troubled gaze

ííííThrough bush, through forest, o'er the lea;Thou art invoked by all my lays;

ííííOh, come then, loved one, back to me!

íííí1789.*-----BY THE RIVER.

ííííFLOW on, ye lays so loved, so fair,

ííííOn to Oblivion's ocean flow!May no rapt boy recall you e'er,

ííííNo maiden in her beauty's glow!

ííííMy love alone was then your theme,

ííííBut now she scorns my passion true.Ye were but written in the stream;

ííííAs it flows on, then, flow ye too!

íííí1798.*-----FAREWELL.

ííííTo break one's word is pleasure-fraught,

ííííTo do one's duty gives a smart;While man, alas! will promise nought,

ííííThat is repugnant to his heart.

ííííUsing some magic strains of yore,

ííííThou lurest him, when scarcely calm,On to sweet folly's fragile bark once more,

ííííRenewing, doubling chance of harm.

ííííWhy seek to hide thyself from me?

ííííFly not my sight--be open then!Known late or early it must be,

ííííAnd here thou hast thy word again.

ííííMy duty is fulfill'd to-day,

ííííNo longer will I guard thee from surprise;But, oh, forgive the friend who from thee turns away,

ííííAnd to himself for refuge flies!

íííí1797.-----THE EXCHANGE.

ííííTHE stones in the streamlet I make my bright pillow,And open my arms to the swift-rolling billow,

ííííThat lovingly hastens to fall on my breast.Then fickleness soon bids it onwards be flowing;A second draws nigh, its caresses bestowing,--

ííííAnd so by a twofold enjoyment I'm blest.

ííííAnd yet thou art trailing in sorrow and sadnessThe moments that life, as it flies, gave for gladness,

ííííBecause by thy love thou'rt remember'd no more!Oh, call back to mind former days and their blisses!The lips of the second will give as sweet kisses

ííííAs any the lips of the first gave before!

íííí1767-9.-----WELCOME AND FAREWELL.

íííí[Another of the love-songs addressed to Frederica.]

ííííQUICK throbb'd my heart: to norse! haste, haste,

ííííAnd lo! 'twas done with speed of light;The evening soon the world embraced,

ííííAnd o'er the mountains hung the night.Soon stood, in robe of mist, the oak,

ííííA tow'ring giant in his size,Where darkness through the thicket broke,

ííííAnd glared with hundred gloomy eyes.

ííííFrom out a hill of clouds the moon

ííííWith mournful gaze began to peer:The winds their soft wings flutter'd soon,

ííííAnd murmur'd in mine awe-struck ear;The night a thousand monsters made,

ííííYet fresh and joyous was my mind;What fire within my veins then play'd!

ííííWhat glow was in my bosom shrin'd!

ííííI saw thee, and with tender pride

ííííFelt thy sweet gaze pour joy on me;While all my heart was at thy side.

ííííAnd every breath I breath'd for thee.The roseate hues that spring supplies

ííííWere playing round thy features fair,And love for me--ye Deities!

ííííI hoped it, I deserved it ne'er!

ííííBut, when the morning sun return'd,

ííííDeparture filled with grief my heart:Within thy kiss, what rapture burn'd!

ííííBut in thy look, what bitter smart!I went--thy gaze to earth first roved

ííííThou follow'dst me with tearful eye:And yet, what rapture to be loved!

ííííAnd, Gods, to love--what ecstasy!

íííí1771.-----NEW LOVE, NEW LIFE.

íííí[Written at the time of Goethe's connection with Lily.]

ííííHEART! my heart! what means this feeling?

ííííWhat oppresseth thee so sore?What strange life is o'er me stealing!

ííííI acknowledge thee no more.Fled is all that gave thee gladness,Fled the cause of all thy sadness,

ííííFled thy peace, thine industry--

ííííAh, why suffer it to be?

ííííSay, do beauty's graces youthful,

ííííDoes this form so fair and bright,Does this gaze, so kind, so truthful,

ííííChain thee with unceasing might?Would I tear me from her boldly,Courage take, and fly her coldly,

ííííBack to her. I'm forthwith led

ííííBy the path I seek to tread.

ííííBy a thread I ne'er can sever,

ííííFor 'tis 'twined with magic skill,Doth the cruel maid for ever

ííííHold me fast against my will.While those magic chains confine me,To her will I must resign me.

ííííAh, the change in truth is great!

ííííLove! kind love! release me straight!

íííí1775.-----TO BELINDA.

íííí[This song was also written for Lily. Goethe mentions, at the endof his Autobiography, that he overheard her singing it oneevening after he had taken his last farewell of her.]

ííííWHEREFORE drag me to yon glittering eddy,

ííííWith resistless might?Was I, then, not truly blest already

ííííIn the silent night?

ííííIn my secret chamber refuge taking,

íííí'Neath the moon's soft ray,And her awful light around me breaking,

ííííMusing there I lay.

ííííAnd I dream'd of hours with joy o'erflowing,

ííííGolden, truly blest,While thine image so beloved was glowing

ííííDeep within my breast.

ííííNow to the card-table hast thou bound me,

íííí'Midst the torches glare?Whilst unhappy faces are around me,

ííííDost thou hold me there?

ííííSpring-flow'rs are to me more rapture-giving,

ííííNow conceal'd from view;Where thou, angel, art, is Nature living,

ííííLove and kindness too.

íííí1775.-----MAY SONG.

ííííHow fair doth Nature

ííííAppear again!How bright the sunbeams!

ííííHow smiles the plain!

ííííThe flow'rs are bursting

ííííFrom ev'ry bough,And thousand voices

ííííEach bush yields now.

ííííAnd joy and gladness

ííííFill ev'ry breast!Oh earth!--oh sunlight!

ííííOh rapture blest!

ííííOh love! oh loved one!

ííííAs golden bright,As clouds of morning

ííííOn yonder height!

ííííThou blessest gladly

ííííThe smiling field,--The world in fragrant

ííííVapour conceal'd.

ííííOh maiden, maiden,

ííííHow love I thee!Thine eye, how gleams it!

ííííHow lov'st thou me!

ííííThe blithe lark loveth

ííííSweet song and air,The morning flow'ret

ííííHeav'n's incense fair,

ííííAs I now love thee

ííííWith fond desire,For thou dost give me

ííííYouth, joy, and fire,

ííííFor new-born dances

ííííAnd minstrelsy.Be ever happy,

ííííAs thou lov'st me!

íííí1775.*-----WITH A PAINTED RIBBON.

ííííLITTLE leaves and flow'rets too,

ííííScatter we with gentle hand,Kind young spring-gods to the view,

ííííSporting on an airy band.

ííííZephyr, bear it on the wing,

ííííTwine it round my loved one's dress;To her glass then let her spring,

ííííFull of eager joyousness.

ííííRoses round her let her see,

ííííShe herself a youthful rose.Grant, dear life, one look to me!

íííí'Twill repay me all my woes,

ííííWhat this bosom feels, feel thou.

ííííFreely offer me thy hand;Let the band that joins us now

ííííBe no fragile rosy band!

íííí1770.-----WITH A GOLDEN NECKLACE.

ííííTHIS page a chain to bring thee burns,

ííííThat, train'd to suppleness of old,On thy fair neck to nestle, yearns,

ííííIn many a hundred little fold.

ííííTo please the silly thing consent!

íííí'Tis harmless, and from boldness free;By day a trifling ornament,

ííííAt night 'tis cast aside by thee.

ííííBut if the chain they bring thee ever,

ííííHeavier, more fraught with weal or woe,I'd then, Lisette, reproach thee never

ííííIf thou shouldst greater scruples show.

íííí1775.*-----ON THE LAKE,

íííí[Written on the occasion of Goethe's starting with his friendPassavant on a Swiss Tour.]

ííííI DRINK fresh nourishment, new blood

ííííFrom out this world more free;The Nature is so kind and good

ííííThat to her breast clasps me!The billows toss our bark on high,

ííííAnd with our oars keep time,While cloudy mountains tow'rd the sky

ííííBefore our progress climb.

ííííSay, mine eye, why sink'st thou down?Golden visions, are ye flown?

ííííHence, thou dream, tho' golden-twin'd;

ííííHere, too, love and life I find.

ííííOver the waters are blinking

ííííMany a thousand fair star;Gentle mists are drinking

ííííRound the horizon afar.Round the shady creek lightly

ííííMorning zephyrs awake,And the ripen'd fruit brightly

ííííMirrors itself in the lake.

íííí1775.-----FROM THE MOUNTAIN.

íííí[Written just after the preceding one, on a mountain overlookingthe Lake of Zurich.]

ííííIF I, dearest Lily, did not love thee,

ííííHow this prospect would enchant my sight!And yet if I, Lily, did not love thee,

ííííCould I find, or here, or there, delight?

íííí1775.-----FLOWER-SALUTE.

ííííTHIS nosegay,--'twas I dress'd it,--

ííííGreets thee a thousand times!Oft stoop'd I, and caress'd it,

ííííAh! full a thousand times,And 'gainst my bosom press'd it

ííííA hundred thousand times!

íííí1815.*-----IN SUMMER.

ííííHow plain and heightWith dewdrops are bright!How pearls have crown'dThe plants all around!How sighs the breezeThro' thicket and trees!How loudly in the sun's clear raysThe sweet birds carol forth their lays!

ííííBut, ah! above,Where saw I my love,Within her room,Small, mantled in gloom,Enclosed around,Where sunlight was drown'd,How little there was earth to me,With all its beauteous majesty!

íííí1776.*-----MAY SONG.

ííííBETWEEN wheatfield and corn,Between hedgerow and thorn,Between pasture and tree,Where's my sweetheartTell it me!

ííííSweetheart caught I

ííííNot at home;She's then, thought I.

ííííGone to roam.Fair and loving

ííííBlooms sweet May;Sweetheart's roving,

ííííFree and gay.

ííííBy the rock near the wave,Where her first kiss she gave,On the greensward, to me,--Something I see!Is it she?

íííí1812.-----PREMATURE SPRING.

ííííDAYS full of rapture,

ííííAre ye renew'd ?--Smile in the sunlight

ííííMountain and wood?

ííííStreams richer laden

ííííFlow through the dale,Are these the meadows?

ííííIs this the vale?

ííííCoolness cerulean!

ííííHeaven and height!Fish crowd the ocean,

ííííGolden and bright.

ííííBirds of gay plumage

ííííSport in the grove,Heavenly numbers

ííííSinging above.

ííííUnder the verdure's

ííííVigorous bloom,Bees, softly bumming,

ííííJuices consume.

ííííGentle disturbance

ííííQuivers in air,Sleep-causing fragrance,

ííííMotion so fair.

ííííSoon with more power

ííííRises the breeze,Then in a moment

ííííDies in the trees.

ííííBut to the bosom

ííííComes it again.Aid me, ye Muses,

ííííBliss to sustain!

ííííSay what has happen'd

ííííSince yester e'en?Oh, ye fair sisters,

ííííHer I have seen!

íííí1802.-----AUTUMN FEELINGS.

ííííFLOURISH greener, as ye clamber,Oh ye leaves, to seek my chamber,

ííííUp the trellis'd vine on high!May ye swell, twin-berries tender,Juicier far,--and with more splendour

ííííRipen, and more speedily!O'er ye broods the sun at evenAs he sinks to rest, and heaven

ííííSoftly breathes into your earAll its fertilising fullness,While the moon's refreshing coolness,

ííííMagic-laden, hovers near;And, alas! ye're watered ever

ííííBy a stream of tears that rillFrom mine eyes--tears ceasing never,

ííííTears of love that nought can still!

íííí1775.*-----RESTLESS LOVE.

ííííTHROUGH rain, through snow,Through tempest go!'Mongst streaming caves,O'er misty waves,On, on! still on!Peace, rest have flown!

ííííSooner through sadness

ííííI'd wish to be slain,Than all the gladness

ííííOf life to sustainAll the fond yearning

ííííThat heart feels for heart,Only seems burning

ííííTo make them both smart.

ííííHow shall I fly?Forestwards hie?Vain were all strife!Bright crown of life.Turbulent bliss,--Love, thou art this!

íííí1789.-----THE SHEPHERD'S LAMENT.

ííííON yonder lofty mountain

ííííA thousand times I stand,And on my staff reclining,

ííííLook down on the smiling land.

ííííMy grazing flocks then I follow,

ííííMy dog protecting them well;I find myself in the valley,

ííííBut how, I scarcely can tell.

ííííThe whole of the meadow is cover'd

ííííWith flowers of beauty rare;I pluck them, but pluck them unknowing

ííííTo whom the offering to bear.

ííííIn rain and storm and tempest,

ííííI tarry beneath the tree,But closed remaineth yon portal;

íííí'Tis all but a vision to me.

ííííHigh over yonder dwelling,

ííííThere rises a rainbow gay;But she from home hath departed

ííííAnd wander'd far, far away.

ííííYes, far away bath she wander'd,

ííííPerchance e'en over the sea;Move onward, ye sheep, then, move onward!

ííííFull sad the shepherd must be.

íííí1803.*-----COMFORT IN TEARS.

ííííHow happens it that thou art sad,

ííííWhile happy all appear?Thine eye proclaims too well that thou

ííííHast wept full many a tear.

íííí"If I have wept in solitude,

ííííNone other shares my grief,And tears to me sweet balsam are,

ííííAnd give my heart relief."

ííííThy happy friends invite thee now,--

ííííOh come, then, to our breast!And let the loss thou hast sustain'd

ííííBe there to us confess'd!

íííí"Ye shout, torment me, knowing not

ííííWhat 'tis afflicteth me;Ah no! I have sustained no loss,

ííííWhate'er may wanting be."

ííííIf so it is, arise in haste!

ííííThou'rt young and full of life.At years like thine, man's blest with strength.

ííííAnd courage for the strife.

íííí"Ah no! in vain 'twould be to strive,

ííííThe thing I seek is far;It dwells as high, it gleams as fair

ííííAs yonder glitt'ring star."

ííííThe stars we never long to clasp,

ííííWe revel in their light,And with enchantment upward gaze,

ííííEach clear and radiant night.

íííí"And I with rapture upward gaze,

ííííOn many a blissful day;Then let me pass the night in tears,

ííííTill tears are wip'd away!

íííí1803.*-----NIGHT SONG,

ííííWHEN on thy pillow lying,

ííííHalf listen, I implore,And at my lute's soft sighing,

ííííSleep on! what wouldst thou more?

ííííFor at my lute's soft sighing

ííííThe stars their blessings pourOn feelings never-dying;

ííííSleep on! what wouldst thou more?

ííííThose feelings never-dying

ííííMy spirit aid to soarFrom earthly conflicts trying;

ííííSleep on! what wouldst thou more?

ííííFrom earthly conflicts trying

ííííThou driv'st me to this shore;Through thee I'm thither flying,--

ííííSleep on! what wouldst thou more?

ííííThrough thee I'm hither flying,

ííííThou wilt not list beforeIn slumbers thou art lying:

ííííSleep on! what wouldst thou more?

íííí1803.*-----LONGING.

ííííWHAT pulls at my heart so?

ííííWhat tells me to roam?What drags me and lures me

ííííFrom chamber and home?How round the cliffs gather

ííííThe clouds high in air!I fain would go thither,

ííííI fain would be there!

ííííThe sociable flight

ííííOf the ravens comes back;I mingle amongst them,

ííííAnd follow their track.Round wall and round mountain

ííííTogether we fly;She tarries below there,

ííííI after her spy.

ííííThen onward she wanders,

ííííMy flight I wing soonTo the wood fill'd with bushes,

ííííA bird of sweet tune.She tarries and hearkens,

ííííAnd smiling, thinks she:"How sweetly he's singing!

ííííHe's singing to me!"

ííííThe heights are illum'd

ííííBy the fast setting sun;The pensive fair maiden

ííííLooks thoughtfully on;She roams by the streamlet,

ííííO'er meadows she goes,And darker and darker

ííííThe pathway fast grows.

ííííI rise on a sudden,

ííííA glimmering star;"What glitters above me,

ííííSo near and so far?"

ííííAnd when thou with wonder

ííííHast gazed on the light,I fall down before thee,

ííííEntranced by thy sight!

íííí1803.-----TO MIGNON.

ííííOVER vale and torrent farRolls along the sun's bright car.Ah! he wakens in his course

ííííMine, as thy deep-seated smart

ííííIn the heart.Ev'ry morning with new force.

ííííScarce avails night aught to me;E'en the visions that I seeCome but in a mournful guise;

ííííAnd I feel this silent smart

ííííIn my heartWith creative pow'r arise.

ííííDuring many a beauteous yearI have seen ships 'neath me steer,As they seek the shelt'ring bay;

ííííBut, alas, each lasting smart

ííííIn my heartFloats not with the stream away.

ííííI must wear a gala dress,Long stored up within my press,For to-day to feasts is given;

ííííNone know with what bitter smart

ííííIs my heartFearfully and madly riven.

ííííSecretly I weep each tear,Yet can cheerful e'en appear,With a face of healthy red;

ííííFor if deadly were this silent smart

ííííIn my heart,Ah, I then had long been dead!-----THE MOUNTAIN CASTLE.

ííííTHERE stands on yonder high mountain

ííííA castle built of yore,Where once lurked horse and horseman

ííííIn rear of gate and of door.

ííííNow door and gate are in ashes,

ííííAnd all around is so still;And over the fallen ruins

ííííI clamber just as I will.

ííííBelow once lay a cellar,

ííííWith costly wines well stor'd;No more the glad maid with her pitcher

ííííDescends there to draw from the hoard.

ííííNo longer the goblet she places

ííííBefore the guests at the feast;The flask at the meal so hallow'd

ííííNo longer she fills for the priest.

ííííNo more for the eager squire

ííííThe draught in the passage is pour'd;No more for the flying present

ííííReceives she the flying reward.

ííííFor all the roof and the rafters,

ííííThey all long since have been burn'd,And stairs and passage and chapel

ííííTo rubbish and ruins are turn'd.

ííííYet when with lute and with flagon,

ííííWhen day was smiling and bright,I've watch'd my mistress climbing

ííííTo gain this perilous height,

ííííThen rapture joyous and radiant

ííííThe silence so desolate brake,And all, as in days long vanish'd,

ííííOnce more to enjoyment awoke;

ííííAs if for guests of high station

ííííThe largest rooms were prepared;As if from those times so precious

ííííA couple thither had fared;

ííííAs if there stood in his chapel

ííííThe priest in his sacred dress,And ask'd: "Would ye twain be united?"

ííííAnd we, with a smile, answer'd, "Yes!"

ííííAnd songs that breath'd a deep feeling,

ííííThat touched the heart's innermost chord,The music-fraught mouth of sweet echo,

ííííInstead of the many, outpour'd.

ííííAnd when at eve all was hidden

ííííIn silence unbroken and deep,The glowing sun then look'd upwards,

ííííAnd gazed on the summit so steep.

ííííAnd squire and maiden then glitter'd

ííííAs bright and gay as a lord,She seized the time for her present,

ííííAnd he to give her reward.

íííí1803.*-----THE SPIRIT'S SALUTE.

ííííTHE hero's noble shade stands high

ííííOn yonder turret grey;And as the ship is sailing by,

ííííHe speeds it on his way.

íííí"See with what strength these sinews thrill'd!

ííííThis heart, how firm and wild!These bones, what knightly marrow fill'd!

ííííThis cup, how bright it smil'd!

íííí"Half of my life I strove and fought,

ííííAnd half I calmly pass'd;And thou, oh ship with beings fraught,

ííííSail safely to the last!"

íííí1774.-----TO A GOLDEN HEART THAT HE WORE ROUND HIS NECK.

íííí[Addressed, during the Swiss tour already mentioned, to a presentLily had given him, during the time of their happy connection,which was then about to be terminated for ever.]

ííííOH thou token loved of joys now perish'd

ííííThat I still wear from my neck suspended,Art thou stronger than our spirit-bond so cherish'd?

ííííOr canst thou prolong love's days untimely ended?

ííííLily, I fly from thee! I still am doom'd to rangeThro' countries strange,

ííííThro' distant vales and woods, link'd on to thee!Ah, Lily's heart could surely never fall

ííííSo soon away from me!

ííííAs when a bird bath broken from his thrall,

ííííAnd seeks the forest green,Proof of imprisonment he bears behind him,A morsel of the thread once used to bind him;

ííííThe free-born bird of old no more is seen,

ííííFor he another's prey bath been.

íííí1775.-----THE BLISS OF SORROW.

ííííNEVER dry, never dry,

ííííTears that eternal love sheddeth!How dreary, how dead doth the world still appear,When only half-dried on the eye is the tear!

ííííNever dry, never dry,

ííííTears that unhappy love sheddeth!

íííí1789.*-----THE WANDERER'S NIGHT-SONG.

ííííTHOU who comest from on high,

ííííWho all woes and sorrows stillest,Who, for twofold misery,

ííííHearts with twofold balsam fillest,Would this constant strife would cease!

ííííWhat are pain and rapture now?Blissful Peace,

ííííTo my bosom hasten thou!

íííí1789.*-----THE SAME.

íííí[Written at night on the Kickelhahn, a hill in the forest ofIlmenau, on the walls of a little hermitage where Goethe composedthe last act of his Iphigenia.]

ííííHUSH'D on the hill

ííííIs the breeze;

ííííScarce by the zephyr

ííííThe trees

ííííSoftly are press'd;The woodbird's asleep on the bough.Wait, then, and thou

ííííSoon wilt find rest.

íííí1783.-----THE HUNTER'S EVEN-SONG.

ííííTHE plain with still and wand'ring feet,

ííííAnd gun full-charged, I tread,And hov'ring see thine image sweet,

ííííThine image dear, o'er head.

ííííIn gentle silence thou dost fare

ííííThrough field and valley dear;But doth my fleeting image ne'er

ííííTo thy mind's eye appear?

ííííHis image, who, by grief oppress'd,

ííííRoams through the world forlorn,And wanders on from east to west,

ííííBecause from thee he's torn?

ííííWhen I would think of none but thee,

ííííMine eyes the moon survey;A calm repose then steals o'er me,

ííííBut how, 'twere hard to say.

íííí1776,*-----TO THE MOON.

ííííBUSH and vale thou fill'st again

ííííWith thy misty ray,And my spirit's heavy chain

ííííCastest far away.

ííííThou dost o'er my fields extend

ííííThy sweet soothing eye,Watching like a gentle friend,

ííííO'er my destiny.

ííííVanish'd days of bliss and woe

ííííHaunt me with their tone,Joy and grief in turns I know,

ííííAs I stray alone.

ííííStream beloved, flow on! flow on!

ííííNe'er can I be gay!Thus have sport and kisses gone,

ííííTruth thus pass'd away.

ííííOnce I seem'd the lord to be

ííííOf that prize so fair!Now, to our deep sorrow, we

ííííCan forget it ne'er.

ííííMurmur, stream, the vale along,

ííííNever cease thy sighs;Murmur, whisper to my song

ííííAnswering melodies!

ííííWhen thou in the winter's night

ííííOverflow'st in wrath,Or in spring-time sparklest bright,

ííííAs the buds shoot forth.

ííííHe who from the world retires,

ííííVoid of hate, is blest;Who a friend's true love inspires,

ííííLeaning on his breast!

ííííThat which heedless man ne'er knew,

ííííOr ne'er thought aright,Roams the bosom's labyrinth through,

ííííBoldly into night.

íííí1789.*-----TO LINA.

ííííSHOULD these songs, love, as they fleet,

ííííChance again to reach thy hand,At the piano take thy seat,

ííííWhere thy friend was wont to stand!

ííííSweep with finger bold the string,

ííííThen the book one moment see:But read not! do nought but sing!

ííííAnd each page thine own will be!

ííííAh, what grief the song imparts

ííííWith its letters, black on white,That, when breath'd by thee, our hearts

ííííNow can break and now delight!

íííí1800.*-----EVER AND EVERYWHERE.

ííííFAR explore the mountain hollow,High in air the clouds then follow!

ííííTo each brook and vale the Muse

ííííThousand times her call renews.

ííííSoon as a flow'ret blooms in spring,It wakens many a strain;

ííííAnd when Time spreads his fleeting wing,

ííííThe seasons come again.

íííí1820.*-----PETITION.

ííííOH thou sweet maiden fair,Thou with the raven hair,

ííííWhy to the window go?

ííííWhile gazing down below,Art standing vainly there?

ííííOh, if thou stood'st for me,And lett'st the latch but fly,

ííííHow happy should I be!How soon would I leap high!

íííí1789.*-----TO HIS COY ONE.

ííííSEEST thou yon smiling Orange?Upon the tree still hangs it;Already March bath vanish'd,And new-born flow'rs are shooting.I draw nigh to the tree then,And there I say: Oh Orange,Thou ripe and juicy Orange,Thou sweet and luscious Orange,I shake the tree, I shake it,Oh fall into my lap!

íííí1789.*-----NIGHT THOUGHTS.

ííííOH, unhappy stars! your fate I mourn,

ííííYe by whom the sea-toss'd sailor's lighted,Who with radiant beams the heav'ns adorn,

ííííBut by gods and men are unrequited:For ye love not,--ne'er have learnt to love!Ceaselessly in endless dance ye move,In the spacious sky your charms displaying,

ííííWhat far travels ye have hasten'd through,Since, within my loved one's arms delaying,

ííííI've forgotten you and midnight too!

íííí1789.*-----TO LIDA.

ííííTHE only one whom, Lida, thou canst love,

ííííThou claim'st, and rightly claim'st, for only thee;He too is wholly thine; since doomed to rove

ííííFar from thee, in life's turmoils nought I seeSave a thin veil, through which thy form I view,As though in clouds; with kindly smile and true,

ííííIt cheers me, like the stars eterne that gleamAcross the northern-lights' far-flick'ring beam.

íííí1789.*-----PROXIMITY.

ííííI KNOW not, wherefore, dearest love,

ííííThou often art so strange and coyWhen 'mongst man's busy haunts we move,

ííííThy coldness puts to flight my joy.But soon as night and silence round us reign,I know thee by thy kisses sweet again!

íííí1789.*-----RECIPROCAL.

ííííMY mistress, where sits she?

ííííWhat is it that charms?The absent she's rocking,

ííííHeld fast in her arms.

ííííIn pretty cage prison'd

ííííShe holds a bird still;Yet lets him fly from her,

ííííWhenever he will.

ííííHe pecks at her finger,

ííííAnd pecks at her lips,And hovers and flutters,

ííííAnd round her he skips.

ííííThen hasten thou homeward,

ííííIn fashion to be;If thou hast the maiden,

ííííShe also hath thee.

íííí1816.-----ROLLICKING HANS.

ííííHALLO there! A glass!

ííííHa! the draught's truly sweet!If for drink go my shoes,

ííííI shall still have my feet.

ííííA maiden and wine,

ííííWith sweet music and song,--I would they were mine,

ííííAll life's journey along!

ííííIf I depart from this sad sphere,And leave a will behind me here,A suit at law will be preferr'd,But as for thanks,--the deuce a word!So ere I die, I squander all,And that a proper will I call.

ííííHIS COMRADE.

ííííHallo there! A glass!

ííííHa! the draught's truly sweetIf thou keepest thy shoes,

ííííThou wilt then spare thy feet.

ííííA maiden and wine,

ííííWith sweet music and song,On pavement, are thine,

ííííAll life's journey along!-----THE FREEBOOTER,

ííííNo door has my house,

ííííNo house has my door;And in and out ever

ííííI carry my store.

ííííNo grate has my kitchen,

ííííNo kitchen my grate;Yet roasts it and boils it

ííííBoth early and late.

ííííMy bed has no trestles,

ííííMy trestles no bed;Yet merrier moments

ííííNo mortal e'er led.

ííííMy cellar is lofty,

ííííMy barn is full deep,From top to the bottom,--

ííííThere lie I and sleep.

ííííAnd soon as I waken,

ííííAll moves on its race;My place has no fixture,

ííííMy fixture no place.

íííí1827.*-----JOY AND SORROW.

ííííAs a fisher-boy I fared

ííííTo the black rock in the sea,And, while false gifts I prepared.

ííííListen'd and sang merrily,Down descended the decoy,

ííííSoon a fish attack'd the bait;One exultant shout of joy,--

ííííAnd the fish was captured straight.

ííííAh! on shore, and to the wood

ííííPast the cliffs, o'er stock and stone,One foot's traces I pursued,

ííííAnd the maiden was alone.Lips were silent, eyes downcast

ííííAs a clasp-knife snaps the bait,With her snare she seized me fast,

ííííAnd the boy was captured straight.

ííííHeav'n knows who's the happy swain

ííííThat she rambles with anew!I must dare the sea again,

ííííSpite of wind and weather too.When the great and little fish

ííííWail and flounder in my net,Straight returns my eager wish

ííííIn her arms to revel yet!

íííí1815.-----MARCH.

ííííTHE snow-flakes fall in showers,

ííííThe time is absent still,When all Spring's beauteous flowers,When all Spring's beauteous flowers

ííííOur hearts with joy shall fill.

ííííWith lustre false and fleeting

ííííThe sun's bright rays are thrown;The swallow's self is cheating:The swallow's self is cheating,

ííííAnd why? He comes alone!

ííííCan I e'er feel delighted

ííííAlone, though Spring is near?Yet when we are united,Yet when we are united,

ííííThe Summer will be here.

íííí1817.-----APRIL.

ííííTELL me, eyes, what 'tis ye're seeking;

ííííFor ye're saying something sweet,

ííííFit the ravish'd ear to greet,Eloquently, softly speaking.

ííííYet I see now why ye're roving;

ííííFor behind those eyes so bright,

ííííTo itself abandon'd quite,Lies a bosom, truthful, loving,--

ííííOne that it must fill with pleasure

íííí'Mongst so many, dull and blind,

ííííOne true look at length to find,That its worth can rightly treasure.

ííííWhilst I'm lost in studying ever

ííííTo explain these cyphers duly,--

ííííTo unravel my looks trulyIn return be your endeavour!

íííí1820.-----MAY.

ííííLIGHT and silv'ry cloudlets hover

ííííIn the air, as yet scarce warm;Mild, with glimmer soft tinged over,

ííííPeeps the sun through fragrant balm.Gently rolls and heaves the ocean

ííííAs its waves the bank o'erflow.And with ever restless motion

ííííMoves the verdure to and fro,

ííííMirror'd brightly far below.

ííííWhat is now the foliage moving?

ííííAir is still, and hush'd the breeze,Sultriness, this fullness loving,

ííííThrough the thicket, from the trees.Now the eye at once gleams brightly,

ííííSee! the infant band with mirthMoves and dances nimbly, lightly,

ííííAs the morning gave it birth,

ííííFlutt'ring two and two o'er earth.

íííí*      *      *      *

íííí1816.-----JUNE.

ííííSHE behind yon mountain lives,Who my love's sweet guerdon gives.Tell me, mount, how this can be!Very glass thou seem'st to me,And I seem to be close by,For I see her drawing nigh;Now, because I'm absent, sad,Now, because she sees me, glad!

ííííSoon between us rise to sightValleys cool, with bushes light,Streams and meadows; next appear

ííííMills and wheels, the surest tokenThat a level spot is near,

ííííPlains far-stretching and unbroken.And so onwards, onwards roam,To my garden and my home!

ííííBut how comes it then to pass?All this gives no joy, alas!--I was ravish'd by her sight,By her eyes so fair and bright,By her footstep soft and light.How her peerless charms I praised,When from head to foot I gazed!I am here, she's far away,--I am gone, with her to stay.

ííííIf on rugged hills she wander,

ííííIf she haste the vale along,Pinions seem to flutter yonder,

ííííAnd the air is fill'd with song;With the glow of youth still playing,

ííííJoyous vigour in each limb,One in silence is delaying,

ííííShe alone 'tis blesses him.

ííííLove, thou art too fair, I ween!Fairer I have never seen!From the heart full easilyBlooming flowers are cull'd by thee.If I think: "Oh, were it so,"Bone and marrow seen to glow!If rewarded by her love,Can I greater rapture prove?

ííííAnd still fairer is the bride,When in me she will confide,When she speaks and lets me knowAll her tale of joy and woe.All her lifetime's historyNow is fully known to me.Who in child or woman e'erSoul and body found so fair?

íííí1815.-----NEXT YEAR'S SPRING.

ííííTHE bed of flowers

ííííLoosens amain,The beauteous snowdrops

ííííDroop o'er the plain.The crocus opens

ííííIts glowing bud,Like emeralds others,

ííííOthers, like blood.With saucy gesture

ííííPrimroses flare,And roguish violets,

ííííHidden with care;And whatsoever

ííííThere stirs and strives,The Spring's contented,

ííííIf works and thrives.

íííí'Mongst all the blossoms

ííííThat fairest are,My sweetheart's sweetness

ííííIs sweetest far;Upon me ever

ííííHer glances light,My song they waken,

ííííMy words make bright,An ever open

ííííAnd blooming mind,In sport, unsullied,

ííííIn earnest, kind.Though roses and lilies

ííííBy Summer are brought,Against my sweetheart

ííííPrevails he nought.

íííí1816.-----AT MIDNIGHT HOUR.

íííí[Goethe relates that a remarkable situation he was in one brightmoonlight night led to the composition of this sweet song, whichwas "the dearer to him because he could not say whence it cameand whither it would."]

ííííAT midnight hour I went, not willingly,

ííííA little, little boy, yon churchyard past,To Father Vicar's house; the stars on high

ííííOn all around their beauteous radiance cast,

ííííAt midnight hour.

ííííAnd when, in journeying o'er the path of life,

ííííMy love I follow'd, as she onward moved,With stars and northern lights o'er head in strife,

ííííGoing and coming, perfect bliss I proved

ííííAt midnight hour.

ííííUntil at length the full moon, lustre-fraught,
