ííííBurst thro' the gloom wherein she was enshrined;And then the willing, active, rapid thought

ííííAround the past, as round the future twined,

ííííAt midnight hour.

íííí1818.-----TO THE RISING FULL MOON.

ííííDornburg, 25th August, 1828.

ííííWILT thou suddenly enshroud thee,

ííííWho this moment wert so nigh?Heavy rising masses cloud thee,

ííííThou art hidden from mine eye.

ííííYet my sadness thou well knowest,

ííííGleaming sweetly as a star!That I'm loved, 'tis thou that showest,

ííííThough my loved one may be far.

ííííUpward mount then! clearer, milder,

ííííRobed in splendour far more bright!Though my heart with grief throbs wilder,

ííííFraught with rapture is the night!

íííí1828.-----THE BRIDEGROOM.*

íííí(Not in the English sense of the word, but the German, where ithas the meaning of betrothed.)

ííííI SLEPT,--'twas midnight,--in my bosom woke,

ííííAs though 'twere day, my love-o'erflowing heart;To me it seemed like night, when day first broke;

ííííWhat is't to me, whate'er it may impart?

ííííShe was away; the world's unceasing strife

ííííFor her alone I suffer'd through the heatOf sultry day; oh, what refreshing life

ííííAt cooling eve!--my guerdon was complete.

ííííThe sun now set, and wand'ring hand in hand,

ííííHis last and blissful look we greeted then;While spake our eyes, as they each other scann'd:

íííí"From the far east, let's trust, he'll come again!"

ííííAt midnight!--the bright stars, in vision blest,

ííííGuide to the threshold where she slumbers calm:Oh be it mine, there too at length to rest,--

ííííYet howsoe'er this prove, life's full of charm!

íííí1828.-----SUCH, SUCH IS HE WHO PLEASETH ME.

ííííFLY, dearest, fly! He is not nigh!

ííííHe who found thee one fair morn in Spring

ííííIn the wood where thou thy flight didst wing.Fly, dearest, fly! He is not nigh!Never rests the foot of evil spy.

ííííHark! flutes' sweet strains and love's refrains

ííííReach the loved one, borne there by the wind,

ííííIn the soft heart open doors they find.Hark! flutes' sweet strains and love's refrains,Hark!--yet blissful love their echo pains.

ííííErect his head, and firm his tread,

ííííRaven hair around his smooth brow strays,

ííííOn his cheeks a Spring eternal plays.Erect his head, and firm his tread,And by grace his ev'ry step is led.

ííííHappy his breast, with pureness bless'd,

ííííAnd the dark eyes 'neath his eyebrows placed,

ííííWith full many a beauteous line are graced.Happy his breast, with pureness bless'd,Soon as seen, thy love must be confess'd.

ííííHis mouth is red--its power I dread,

ííííOn his lips morn's fragrant incense lies,

ííííRound his lips the cooling Zephyr sighs.His mouth is red--its power I dread,With one glance from him, all sorrow's fled.

ííííHis blood is true, his heart bold too,

ííííIn his soft arms, strength, protection, dwells

ííííAnd his face with noble pity swells.His blood is true, his heart bold too,Blest the one whom those dear arms may woo!

íííí1816..-----SICILIAN SONG.

ííííYE black and roguish eyes,

ííííIf ye command.Each house in ruins lies,

ííííNo town can stand.And shall my bosom's chain,--

ííííThis plaster wall,?To think one moment, deign,--

ííííShall ii not fall?

íííí1811.-----SWISS SONG,

ííííUp in th' mountainI was a-sitting,With the bird thereAs my guest,Blithely singing,Blithely springing,And buildingHis nest.

ííííIn the gardenI was a-standing,And the bee thereSaw as well,Buzzing, humming,Going, coming,And buildingHis cell.

ííííO'er the meadowI was a-going,And there saw theButterflies,Sipping, dancing,Flying, glancing,And charmingThe eyes.

ííííAnd then came myDear Hansel,And I show'd themWith glee,Sipping, quaffing,And he, laughing,Sweet kissesGave me.

íííí1811.-----FINNISH SONG.

ííííIF the loved one, the well-known one,Should return as he departed,On his lips would ring my kisses,Though the wolf's blood might have dyed them;And a hearty grasp I'd give him,Though his finger-ends were serpents.

ííííWind! Oh, if thou hadst but reason,Word for word in turns thou'dst carry,E'en though some perchance might perish'Tween two lovers so far distant.

ííííAll choice morsels I'd dispense with,Table-flesh of priests neglect too,Sooner than renounce my lover,Whom, in Summer having vanquish'd,I in Winter tamed still longer.

íííí1810.-----GIPSY SONG.

ííííIN the drizzling mist, with the snow high-pil'd,In the Winter night, in the forest wild,I heard the wolves with their ravenous howl,I heard the screaming note of the owl:

ííííWille wau wau wau!

ííííWille wo wo wo!

ííííWito hu!

ííííI shot, one day, a cat in a ditch--The dear black cat of Anna the witch;Upon me, at night, seven were-wolves came down,Seven women they were, from out of the town.

ííííWille wau wau wau!

ííííWille wo wo wo!

ííííWito hu!

ííííI knew them all; ay, I knew them straight;First, Anna, then Ursula, Eve, and Kate,And Barbara, Lizzy, and Bet as well;And forming a ring, they began to yell:

ííííWille wau wau wau!

ííííWille wo wo wo!

ííííWito hu!

ííííThen call'd I their names with angry threat:"What wouldst thou, Anna? What wouldst thou, Bet?"At hearing my voice, themselves they shook,And howling and yelling, to flight they took.

ííííWille wau wau wau!

ííííWille wo wo wo!

ííííWito hu!

íííí1772.-----THE DESTRUCTION OF MAGDEBURG.

íííí[For a fine account of the fearful sack of Magdeburg, by Tilly,in the year 1613, see SCHILLER's History of the Thirty Years'War.]

ííííOH, Magdeberg the town!Fair maids thy beauty crown,Thy charms fair maids and matrons crown;Oh, Magdeburg the town!

ííííWhere all so blooming stands,Advance fierce Tilly's bands;O'er gardens and o'er well--till'd landsAdvance fierce Tilly's bands.

ííííNow Tilly's at the gate.Our homes who'll liberate?Go, loved one, hasten to the gate,And dare the combat straight!

ííííThere is no need as yet,However fierce his threat;Thy rosy cheeks I'll kiss, sweet pet!There is no need as yet.

ííííMy longing makes me pale.Oh, what can wealth avail?E'en now thy father may be pale.Thou mak'st my courage fail.

ííííOh, mother, give me bread!Is then my father dead?Oh, mother, one small crust of bread!Oh, what misfortune dread!

ííííThy father, dead lies he,The trembling townsmen flee,Adown the street the blood runs free;Oh, whither shall we flee?

ííííThe churches ruined lie,The houses burn on high,The roofs they smoke, the flames out fly,Into the street then hie!

ííííNo safety there they meet!The soldiers fill the Street,With fire and sword the wreck complete:No safety there they meet!

ííííDown falls the houses' line,Where now is thine or mine?That bundle yonder is not thine,Thou flying maiden mine!

ííííThe women sorrow sore.The maidens far, far more.The living are no virgins more;Thus Tilly's troops make war!-----

ííííFAMILIAR SONGS.

íííí------What we sing in companySoon from heart to heart will fly.-----

ííííTHE Gesellige Lieder, which I have angicisled as above, asseveral of them cannot be called convivial songs, are separatedby Goethe from his other songs, and I have adhered to the samearrangement. The Ergo bibamus is a well-known drinking song inGermany, where it enjoys vast popularity.

ííííON THE NEW YEAR.

íííí[Composed for a merry party that used to meet, in 1802, atGoethe's house.]

ííííFATE now allows us,

íííí'Twixt the departing

ííííAnd the upstarting,Happy to be;And at the call of

ííííMemory cherish'd,

ííííFuture and perish'dMoments we see.

ííííSeasons of anguish,--

ííííAh, they must ever

ííííTruth from woe sever,Love and joy part;Days still more worthy

ííííSoon will unite us,

ííííFairer songs light us,Strength'ning the heart.

ííííWe, thus united,

ííííThink of, with gladness,

ííííRapture and sadness,Sorrow now flies.Oh, how mysterious

ííííFortune's direction!

ííííOld the connection,

ííííNew-born the prize!

ííííThank, for this, Fortune,

ííííWavering blindly!

ííííThank all that kindlyFate may bestow!Revel in change's

ííííImpulses clearer,

ííííLove far sincerer,More heartfelt glow!

ííííOver the old one,

ííííWrinkles collected,

ííííSad and dejected,Others may view;But, on us gently

ííííShineth a true one,

ííííAnd to the new oneWe, too, are new.

ííííAs a fond couple

íííí'Midst the dance veering,

ííííFirst disappearing,Then reappear,So let affection

ííííGuide thro' life's mazy

ííííPathways so hazyInto the year!

íííí1802.-----ANNIVERSARY SONG.

íííí[This little song describes the different members of the partyjust spoken of.]

ííííWHY pacest thou, my neighbour fair,

ííííThe garden all alone?If house and land thou seek'st to guard,

ííííI'd thee as mistress own.

ííííMy brother sought the cellar-maid,

ííííAnd suffered her no rest;She gave him a refreshing draught,

ííííA kiss, too, she impress'd.

ííííMy cousin is a prudent wight,

ííííThe cook's by him ador'd;He turns the spit round ceaselessly,

ííííTo gain love's sweet reward.

ííííWe six together then began

ííííA banquet to consume,When lo! a fourth pair singing came,

ííííAnd danced into the room.

ííííWelcome were they,--and welcome too

ííííWas a fifth jovial pair.Brimful of news, and stored with tales

ííííAnd jests both new and rare.

ííííFor riddles, spirit, raillery,

ííííAnd wit, a place remain'd;A sixth pair then our circle join'd,

ííííAnd so that prize was gain'd.

ííííAnd yet to make us truly blest,

ííííOne miss'd we, and full sore;A true and tender couple came,--

ííííWe needed them no more.

ííííThe social banquet now goes on,

ííííUnchequer'd by alloy;The sacred double-numbers then

ííííLet us at once enjoy!

íííí1802.-----THE SPRING ORACLE.

ííííOH prophetic bird so bright,Blossom-songster, cuckoo bight!In the fairest time of year,Dearest bird, oh! deign to hearWhat a youthful pair would pray,Do thou call, if hope they may:Thy cuck-oo, thy cuck-oo.Ever more cuck-oo, cuck-oo!

ííííHearest thou? A loving pairFain would to the altar fare;Yes! a pair in happy youth,Full of virtue, full of truth.Is the hour not fix'd by fate?Say, how long must they still wait?Hark! cuck-oo! hark! cuck-oo!Silent yet! for shame, cuck-oo!

íííí'Tis not our fault, certainly!Only two years patient be!But if we ourselves please here,Will pa-pa-papas appear?Know that thou'lt more kindness do us,More thou'lt prophesy unto us.One! cuck-oo! Two! cuck-oo!Ever, ever, cuck-oo, cuck-oo, coo!

ííííIf we've calculated clearly,We have half a dozen nearly.If good promises we'll give,Wilt thou say how long we'II live?Truly, we'll confess to thee,We'd prolong it willingly.Coo cuck-oo, coo cuck-oo,Coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo!

ííííLife is one continued feast--(If we keep no score, at least).If now we together dwell,Will true love remain as well?For if that should e'er decay,Happiness would pass away.Coo cuck-oo, coo cuck-oo,Coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo, coo!

íííí1803.*(Gracefully in infinitum.)-----THE HAPPY COUPLE.

ííííAFTER these vernal rains

ííííThat we so warmly sought,Dear wife, see how our plains

ííííWith blessings sweet are fraught!We cast our distant gaze

ííííFar in the misty blue;Here gentle love still strays,

ííííHere dwells still rapture true.

ííííThou seest whither go

ííííYon pair of pigeons white,Where swelling violets blow

ííííRound sunny foliage bright.'Twas there we gather'd first

ííííA nosegay as we roved;There into flame first burst

ííííThe passion that we proved.

ííííYet when, with plighted troth,

ííííThe priest beheld us fareHome from the altar both,

ííííWith many a youthful pair,--Then other moons had birth,

ííííAnd many a beauteous sun,Then we had gain'd the earth

ííííWhereon life's race to run.

ííííA hundred thousand fold

ííííThe mighty bond was seal'd;In woods, on mountains cold,

ííííIn bushes, in the field,Within the wall, in caves,

ííííAnd on the craggy height,And love, e'en o'er the waves,

ííííBore in his tube the light.

ííííContented we remain'd,

ííííWe deem'd ourselves a pair;'Twas otherwise ordain'd,

ííííFor, lo! a third was there;A fourth, fifth, sixth appear'd,

ííííAnd sat around our board;And now the plants we've rear'd

ííííHigh o'er our heads have soar'd!

ííííHow fair and pleasant looks,

ííííOn yonder beauteous spot,Embraced by poplar-brooks,

ííííThe newly-finish'd cot!Who is it there that sits

ííííIn that glad home above?Is't not our darling Fritz

ííííWith his own darling love?

ííííBeside yon precipice,

ííííWhence pent-up waters steal,And leaving the abyss,

ííííFall foaming through the wheel,Though people often tell

ííííOf millers' wives so fair,Yet none can e'er excel

ííííOur dearest daughter there!

ííííYet where the thick-set green

ííííStands round yon church and sad,Where the old fir-tree's seen

ííííAlone tow'rd heaven to nod,--'Tis there the ashes lie

ííííOf our untimely dead;From earth our gaze on high

ííííBy their blest memory's led.

ííííSee how yon hill is bright

ííííWith billowy-waving arms!The force returns, whose might

ííííHas vanquished war's alarms.Who proudly hastens here

ííííWith wreath-encircled brow?'Tis like our child so dear

ííííThus Charles comes homeward now.

ííííThat dearest honour'd guest

ííííIs welcom'd by the bride;She makes the true one blest,

ííííAt the glad festal tide.And ev'ry one makes haste

ííííTo join the dance with glee;While thou with wreaths hast graced

ííííThe youngest children three.

ííííTo sound of flute and horn

ííííThe time appears renew'd,When we, in love's young morn,

ííííIn the glad dance upstood;And perfect bliss I know

ííííEre the year's course is run,For to the font we go

ííííWith grandson and with son!

íííí1803.*-----SONG OF FELLOWSHIP.

íííí[Written and sung in honour of the birthday of the Pastor Ewaldat the time of Goethe's happy connection with Lily.]

ííííIN ev'ry hour of joy

ííííThat love and wine prolong,The moments we'll employ

ííííTo carol forth this song!We're gathered in His name,

ííííWhose power hath brought us here;He kindled first our flame,

ííííHe bids it burn more clear.

ííííThen gladly glow to-night,

ííííAnd let our hearts combine!Up! quaff with fresh delight

ííííThis glass of sparkling wine!Up! hail the joyous hour,

ííííAnd let your kiss be true;With each new bond of power

ííííThe old becomes the new!

ííííWho in our circle lives,

ííííAnd is not happy there?True liberty it gives,

ííííAnd brother's love so fair.Thus heart and heart through life

ííííWith mutual love are fill'd;And by no causeless strife

ííííOur union e'er is chill'd.

ííííOur hopes a God has crown'd

ííííWith life-discernment free,And all we view around,

ííííRenews our ecstasy.Ne'er by caprice oppress'd,

ííííOur bliss is ne'er destroy'd;More freely throbs our breast,

ííííBy fancies ne'er alloy'd.

ííííWhere'er our foot we set,

ííííThe more life's path extends,And brighter, brighter yet

ííííOur gaze on high ascends.We know no grief or pain,

ííííThough all things fall and rise;Long may we thus remain!

ííííEternal be our ties!

íííí1775.-----CONSTANCY IN CHANGE.

ííííCOULD this early bliss but rest

ííííConstant for one single hour!But e'en now the humid West

ííííScatters many a vernal shower.Should the verdure give me joy?

íííí'Tis to it I owe the shade;Soon will storms its bloom destroy,

ííííSoon will Autumn bid it fade.

ííííEagerly thy portion seize,

ííííIf thou wouldst possess the fruit!Fast begin to ripen these,

ííííAnd the rest already shoot.With each heavy storm of rain

ííííChange comes o'er thy valley fair;Once, alas! but not again

ííííCan the same stream hold thee e'er.

ííííAnd thyself, what erst at least

ííííFirm as rocks appear'd to rise,Walls and palaces thou seest

ííííBut with ever-changing eyes.Fled for ever now the lip

ííííThat with kisses used to glow,And the foot, that used to skip

ííííO'er the mountain, like the roe.

ííííAnd the hand, so true and warm,

ííííEver raised in charity,And the cunning-fashion'd form,--

ííííAll are now changed utterly.And what used to bear thy name,

ííííWhen upon yon spot it stood,Like a rolling billow came,

ííííHast'ning on to join the flood.

ííííBe then the beginning found

ííííWith the end in unison,Swifter than the forms around

ííííAre themselves now fleeting on!Thank the merit in thy breast,

ííííThank the mould within thy heart,That the Muses' favour blestNe'er will perish, ne'er depart.

íííí1803.*-----TABLE SONG.

íííí[Composed for the merry party already mentioned, on the occasionof the departure for France of the hereditary prince, who was oneof the number, and who is especially alluded to in the 3rdverse.]

ííííO'ER me--how I cannot say,--

ííííHeav'nly rapture's growing.Will it help to guide my way

ííííTo yon stars all-glowing?Yet that here I'd sooner be,

ííííTo assert I'm able,Where, with wine and harmony,

ííííI may thump the table.

ííííWonder not, my dearest friends,

ííííWhat 'tis gives me pleasure;For of all that earth e'er lends,

íííí'Tis the sweetest treasure.Therefore solemnly I swear,

ííííWith no reservation,That maliciously I'll ne'er

ííííLeave my present station.

ííííNow that here we're gather'd round,

ííííChasing cares and slumbers,Let, methought, the goblet sound

ííííTo the bard's glad numbers!Many a hundred mile away,

ííííGo those we love dearly;Therefore let us here to-day

ííííMake the glass ring clearly!

ííííHere's His health, through Whom we live!

ííííI that faith inherit.To our king the next toast give,

ííííHonour is his merit,'Gainst each in-- and outward foe

ííííHe's our rock and tower.Of his maintenance thinks he though,

ííííMore that grows his power.

ííííNext to her good health I drink,

ííííWho has stirr'd my passion;Of his mistress let each think,

ííííThink in knightly fashion.If the beauteous maid but see

ííííWhom 'tis I now call so,Let her smiling nod to me:

íííí"Here's my love's health also!"

ííííTo those friends,--the two or three,--

ííííBe our next toast given,In whose presence revel we,

ííííIn the silent even,--Who the gloomy mist so cold

ííííScatter gently, lightly;To those friends, then, new or old,

ííííLet the toast ring brightly.

ííííBroader now the stream rolls on,

ííííWith its waves more swelling,While in higher, nobler tone,

ííííComrades, we are dwelling,--We who with collected might,

ííííBravely cling together,Both in fortune's sunshine bright,

ííííAnd in stormy weather.

ííííJust as we are gather'd thus,

ííííOthers are collected;On them, therefore, as on us,

ííííBe Fate's smile directed!From the springhead to the sea,

ííííMany a mill's revolving,And the world's prosperity

ííííIs the task I'm solving.

íííí1802.-----WONT AND DONE.

ííííI HAVE loved; for the first time with passion I rave!I then was the servant, but now am the slave;

ííííI then was the servant of all:By this creature so charming I now am fast bound,To love and love's guerdon she turns all around,

ííííAnd her my sole mistress I call.

ííííl've had faith; for the first time my faith is now strong!And though matters go strangely, though matters go wrong,

ííííTo the ranks of the faithful I'm true:Though ofttimes 'twas dark and though ofttimes 'twas drear,In the pressure of need, and when danger was near,

ííííYet the dawning of light I now view.

ííííI have eaten; but ne'er have thus relish'd my food!For when glad are the senses, and joyous the blood,

ííííAt table all else is effacedAs for youth, it but swallows, then whistles an air;As for me, to a jovial resort I'd repair,

ííííWhere to eat, and enjoy what I taste.

ííííI have drunk; but have never thus relish'd the bowl!For wine makes us lords, and enlivens the soul,

ííííAnd loosens the trembling slave's tongue.Let's not seek to spare then the heart-stirring drink,For though in the barrel the old wine may sink,

ííííIn its place will fast mellow the young.

ííííI have danced, and to dancing am pledged by a vow!Though no caper or waltz may be raved about now,

ííííIn a dance that's becoming, whirl round.And he who a nosegay of flowers has dress'd,And cares not for one any more than the rest,

ííííWith a garland of mirth is aye crown'd.

ííííThen once more be merry, and banish all woes!For he who but gathers the blossoming rose.

ííííBy its thorns will be tickled alone.To-day still, as yesterday, glimmers the star;Take care from all heads that hang down to keep far,

ííííAnd make but the future thine own.

íííí1813.-----GENERAL CONFESSION.

ííííIn this noble ring to-day

ííííLet my warning shame ye!Listen to my solemn voice,--

ííííSeldom does it name ye.Many a thing have ye intended,

ííííMany a thing have badly ended,And now I must blame ye.

ííííAt some moment in our lives

ííííWe must all repent us!So confess, with pious trust,

ííííAll your sins momentous!Error's crooked pathways shunning.

ííííLet us, on the straight road running,Honestly content us!

ííííYes! we've oft, when waking, dream'd,

ííííLet's confess it rightly;Left undrain'd the brimming cup,

ííííWhen it sparkled brightly;Many a shepherd's-hour's soft blisses,

ííííMany a dear mouth's flying kissesWe've neglected lightly.

ííííMute and silent have we sat,

ííííWhilst the blockheads prated,And above e'en song divine

ííííHave their babblings rated;To account we've even call'd us

ííííFor the moments that enthrall'd us,With enjoyment freighted.

ííííIf thou'lt absolution grant

ííííTo thy true ones ever,We, to execute thy will,

ííííCeaseless will endeavour,From half-measures strive to wean us,

ííííWholly, fairly, well demean us,Resting, flagging never.

ííííAt all blockheads we'll at once

ííííLet our laugh ring clearly,And the pearly-foaming wine

ííííNever sip at merely.Ne'er with eye alone give kisses,

ííííBut with boldness suck in blissesFrom those lips loved dearly.

íííí1803.*-----COPTIC SONG.

ííííLEAVE we the pedants to quarrel and strive,

ííííRigid and cautious the teachers to be!All of the wisest men e'er seen alive

ííííSmile, nod, and join in the chorus with me:"Vain 'tis to wait till the dolt grows less silly!Play then the fool with the fool, willy-nilly,--

ííííChildren of wisdom,--remember the word!"

ííííMerlin the old, from his glittering grave,When I, a stripling, once spoke to him,--gave

ííííJust the same answer as that I've preferr'd;"Vain 'tis to wait till the dolt grows less silly!Play then the fool with the fool, willy-nilly,--

ííííChildren of wisdom,--remember the word!"

ííííAnd on the Indian breeze as it booms,And in the depths of Egyptian tombs,

ííííOnly the same holy saying I've heard:"Vain 'tis to wait till the dolt grows less silly!Play then the fool with the fool, willy-nilly,--

ííííChildren of wisdom,--remember the word!"

íííí1789.*-----ANOTHER.

ííííGo! obedient to my call,

ííííTurn to profit thy young days,

ííííWiser make betimes thy breast

ííííIn Fate's balance as it sways,

ííííSeldom is the cock at rest;Thou must either mount, or fall,

ííííThou must either rule and win,

ííííOr submissively give in,Triumph, or else yield to clamour:Be the anvil or the hammer.

íííí1789.-----VANITAS! VANITATUM VANITAS!

ííííMY trust in nothing now is placed,

ííííHurrah!So in the world true joy I taste,

ííííHurrah!Then he who would be a comrade of mineMust rattle his glass, and in chorus combine,Over these dregs of wine.

ííííI placed my trust in gold and wealth,

ííííHurrah!But then I lost all joy and health,

ííííLack-a-day!Both here and there the money roll'd,And when I had it here, behold,From there had fled the gold!

ííííI placed my trust in women next,

ííííHurrah!But there in truth was sorely vex'd,

ííííLack-a-day!The False another portion sought,The True with tediousness were fraught,The Best could not be bought.

ííííMy trust in travels then I placed,

ííííHurrah!And left my native land in haste.

ííííLack-a-day!But not a single thing seem'd good,The beds were bad, and strange the food,And I not understood.

ííííI placed my trust in rank and fame,

ííííHurrah!Another put me straight to shame,

ííííLack-a-day!And as I had been prominent,All scowl'd upon me as I went,I found not one content.

ííííI placed my trust in war and fight,

ííííHurrah!We gain'd full many a triumph bright,

ííííHurrah!Into the foeman's land we cross'd,We put our friends to equal cost,And there a leg I lost.

ííííMy trust is placed in nothing now,

ííííHurrah!At my command the world must bow,

ííííHurrah!And as we've ended feast and strain,The cup we'll to the bottom drain;No dregs must there remain!

íííí1806.-----FORTUNE OF WAR.

ííííNOUGHT more accursed in war I know

ííííThan getting off scot-free;Inured to danger, on we go

ííííIn constant victory;We first unpack, then pack again,

ííííWith only this reward,That when we're marching, we complain,

ííííAnd when in camp, are bor'd.

ííííThe time for billeting comes next,--

ííííThe peasant curses it;Each nobleman is sorely vex'd,

íííí'Tis hated by the cit.Be civil, bad though be thy food,

ííííThe clowns politely treat;If to our hosts we're ever rude,

ííííJail-bread we're forced to eat.

ííííAnd when the cannons growl around,

ííííAnd small arms rattle clear,And trumpet, trot, and drum resound,

ííííWe merry all appear;And as it in the fight may chance,

ííííWe yield, then charge amain,And now retire, and now advance,

ííííAnd yet a cross ne'er gain.

ííííAt length there comes a musket-ball,

ííííAnd hits the leg, please Heaven;And then our troubles vanish all,

ííííFor to the town we're driven,(Well cover'd by the victor's force,)

ííííWhere we in wrath first came,--The women, frightened then, of course,

ííííAre loving now and tame.

ííííCellar and heart are open'd wide,

ííííThe cook's allow'd no rest;While beds with softest down supplied

ííííAre by our members press'd.The nimble lads upon us wait,

ííííNo sleep the hostess takesHer shift is torn in pieces straight,--

ííííWhat wondrous lint it makes!

ííííIf one has tended carefully

ííííThe hero's wounded limb,Her neighbour cannot rest, for she

ííííHas also tended him.A third arrives in equal haste,

ííííAt length they all are there,And in the middle he is placed

ííííOf the whole band so fair!

ííííOn good authority the king

ííííHears how we love the fight,And bids them cross and ribbon bring,

ííííOur coat and breast to dight.Say if a better fate can e'er

ííííA son of Mars pursue!'Midst tears at length we go from there,

ííííBeloved and honour'd too.

íííí1814.-----OPEN TABLE.

ííííMANY a guest I'd see to-day,

ííííMet to taste my dishes!Food in plenty is prepar'd,

ííííBirds, and game, and fishes.Invitations all have had,

ííííAll proposed attending.Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííPretty girls I hope to see,

ííííDear and guileless misses,Ignorant how sweet it is

ííííGiving tender kisses.Invitations all have had,

ííííAll proposed attending.Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííWomen also I expect,

ííííLoving tow'rd their spouses,Whose rude grumbling in their breasts

ííííGreater love but rouses.Invitations they've had too,

ííííAll proposed attending!Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííI've too ask'd young gentlemen,

ííííWho are far from haughty,And whose purses are well-stock'd,

ííííWell-behaved, not haughty.These especially I ask'd,

ííííAll proposed attending.Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííMen I summon'd with respect,

ííííWho their own wives treasure;Who in ogling other Fair

ííííNever take a pleasure.To my greetings they replied,

ííííAll proposed attending.Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííThen to make our joy complete,

ííííPoets I invited,Who love other's songs far more

ííííThan what they've indited.All acceded to my wish,

ííííAll proposed attending.Johnny, go and look around!

ííííAre they hither wending?

ííííNot a single one appears,

ííííNone seem this way posting.All the soup boils fast away,

ííííJoints are over-roasting.Ah, I fear that we have been

ííííRather too unbending!Johnny, tell me what you think!

ííííNone are hither wending.

ííííJohnny, run and quickly bring

ííííOther guests to me now!Each arriving as he is--

ííííThat's the plan, I see now.In the town at once 'tis known,

ííííEvery one's commending.Johnny, open all the doors:

ííííAll are hither wending!

íííí1815.*-----THE RECKONING.

ííííLEADER.

ííííLET no cares now hover o'er us

ííííLet the wine unsparing run!Wilt thou swell our merry chorus?

ííííHast thou all thy duty done?

ííííSOLO.

ííííTwo young folks--the thing is curious--

ííííLoved each other; yesterdayBoth quite mild, to-day quite furious,

ííííNext day, quite the deuce to pay!If her neck she there was stooping,

ííííHe must here needs pull his hair.I revived their spirits drooping,

ííííAnd they're now a happy pair.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííSurely we for wine may languish!

ííííLet the bumper then go round!For all sighs and groans of anguish

ííííThou to-day in joy hast drown'd.

ííííSOLO.

ííííWhy, young orphan, all this wailing?

íííí"Would to heaven that I were dead!For my guardian's craft prevailing

ííííSoon will make me beg my bread."Knowing well the rascal genus,

ííííInto court I dragg'd the knave;Fair the judges were between us,

ííííAnd the maiden's wealth did save.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííSurely we for wine may languish!

ííííLet the bumper then go round!For all sighs and groans of anguish

ííííThou to-day in joy hast drown'd.

ííííSOLO.

ííííTo a little fellow, quiet,

ííííUnpretending and subdued,Has a big clown, running riot,

ííííBeen to-day extremely rude.I bethought me of my duty,

ííííAnd my courage swell'd apace,So I spoil'd the rascal's beauty,

ííííSlashing him across the face.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííSurely we for wine may languish!

ííííLet the bumper then go round!For all sighs and groans of anguish

ííííThou to-day in joy hast drown'd.

ííííSOLO.

ííííBrief must be my explanation,

ííííFor I really have done nought.Free from trouble and vexation,

ííííI a landlord's business bought.There I've done, with all due ardour,

ííííAll that duty order'd me;Each one ask'd me for the larder,

ííííAnd there was no scarcity.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííSurely we for wine may languish!

ííííLet the bumper then go round!For all sighs and groans of anguish

ííííThou to-day in joy hast drown'd.

ííííLEADER.

ííííEach should thus make proclamation

ííííOf what he did well to-day!That's the match whose conflagration

ííííShould inflame our tuneful lay.Let it be our precept ever

ííííTo admit no waverer here!For to act the good endeavour,

ííííNone but rascals meek appear.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííSurely we for wine may languish!

ííííLet the bumper then go round!For all sighs and groans of anguish

ííííWe have now in rapture drown'd.

ííííTRIO.

ííííLet each merry minstrel enter,

ííííHe's right welcome to our hall!'Tis but with the self─tormentor

ííííThat we are not liberal;

ííííFor we fear that his caprices,

ííííThat his eye-brows dark and sad,That his grief that never ceases

ííííHide an empty heart, or bad.

ííííCHORUS.

ííííNo one now for wine shall languish!

ííííHere no minstrel shall be found,Who all sighs and groans of anguish,

ííííHas not first in rapture drown'd!

íííí1810.-----ERGO BIBAMUS!

ííííFOR a praiseworthy object we're now gather'd here,

ííííSo, brethren, sing: ERGO BIBAMUS!Tho' talk may be hush'd, yet the glasses ring clear,

ííííRemember then: ERGO BIBAMUS!In truth 'tis an old, 'tis an excellent word,With its sound so befitting each bosom is stirr'd,And an echo the festal hall filling is heard,

ííííA glorious ERGO BIBAMUS!

ííííI saw mine own love in her beauty so rare,

ííííAnd bethought me of: ERGO BIBAMUS;So I gently approach'd, and she let me stand there,

ííííWhile I help'd myself, thinking: BIBAMUS!And when she's appeased, and will clasp you and kiss,Or when those embraces and kisses ye miss,Take refuge, till sound is some worthier bliss,

ííííIn the comforting ERGO BIBAMUS!

ííííI am call'd by my fate far away from each friend;

ííííYe loved ones, then: ERGO BIBAMUS!With wallet light-laden from hence I must wend.

ííííSo double our ERGO BIBAMUS!Whate'er to his treasures the niggard may add,Yet regard for the joyous will ever be had,For gladness lends over its charms to the glad,

ííííSo, brethren, sing; ERGO BIBAMUS!

ííííAnd what shall we say of to-day as it flies?

ííííI thought but of: ERGO BIBAMUS'Tis one of those truly that seldom arise,

ííííSo again and again sing: BIBAMUS!For joy through a wide-open portal it guides,Bright glitter the clouds, as the curtain divides,An a form, a divine one, to greet us in glides,

ííííWhile we thunder our: ERGO BIBAMUS!

íííí1810.-----EPIPHANIAS.

ííííTHE three holy kings with their star's bright ray,--They eat and they drink, but had rather not pay;They like to eat and drink away,They eat and drink, but had rather not pay.

ííííThe three holy kings have all come here,In number not four, but three they appear;And if a fourth join'd the other three,Increased by one their number would be.

ííííThe first am I,--the fair and the white,I ought to be seen when the sun shines bright!But, alas! with all my spices and myrrh,No girl now likes me,--I please not her.

ííííThe next am I,--the brown and the long,Known well to women, known well to song.Instead of spices, 'tis gold I bear,And so I'm welcome everywhere.

ííííThe last am I,--the black and small,And fain would be right merry withal.I like to eat and to drink full measure,I eat and drink, and give thanks with pleasure.

ííííThe three holy kings are friendly and mild,They seek the Mother, and seek the Child;The pious Joseph is sitting by,The ox and the ass on their litter lie.

ííííWe're bringing gold, we're bringing myrrh,The women incense always prefer;And if we have wine of a worthy growth,We three to drink like six are not loth.

ííííAs here we see fair lads and lasses,But not a sign of oxen or asses,We know that we have gone astrayAnd so go further on our way.-----

ííííBALLADS.

íííí-----Poet's art is ever ableTo endow with truth mere fable.----MIGNON.[This universally known poem is also to be found in WilhelmMeister.]

ííííKNOW'ST thou the land where the fair citron blows,Where the bright orange midst the foliage glows,Where soft winds greet us from the azure skies,Where silent myrtles, stately laurels rise,Know'st thou it well?

íííí'Tis there, 'tis there,That I with thee, beloved one, would repair.

ííííKnow'st thou the house? On columns rests its pile,Its halls are gleaming, and its chambers smile,And marble statues stand and gaze on me:"Poor child! what sorrow hath befallen thee?"Know'st thou it well?

íííí'Tis there, 'tis there,That I with thee, protector, would repair!

ííííKnow'st thou the mountain, and its cloudy bridge?The mule can scarcely find the misty ridge;In caverns dwells the dragon's olden brood,The frowning crag obstructs the raging flood.Know'st thou it well?

íííí'Tis there, 'tis there,Our path lies--Father--thither, oh repair!

íííí1795.*-----THE MINSTREL.

íííí[This fine poem is introduced in the second book of WilhelmMeister.]

íííí"WHAT tuneful strains salute mine ear

ííííWithout the castle walls?Oh, let the song re-echo here,

ííííWithin our festal halls!"Thus spake the king, the page out-hied;The boy return'd; the monarch cried:

íííí"Admit the old man yonder!"

íííí"All hail, ye noble lords to-night!

ííííAll hail, ye beauteous dames!Star placed by star! What heavenly sight!

ííííWhoe'er can tell their names?Within this glittering hall sublime,Be closed, mine eyes! 'tis not the time

ííííFor me to feast my wonder."

ííííThe minstrel straightway closed his eyes,

ííííAnd woke a thrilling tone;The knights look'd on in knightly guise,

ííííFair looks tow'rd earth were thrown.The monarch, ravish'd by the strain,Bade them bring forth a golden chain,

ííííTo be his numbers' guerdon.

íííí"The golden chain give not to me,

ííííBut give the chain to thoseIn whose bold face we shiver'd see

ííííThe lances of our foes.Or give it to thy chancellor there;With other burdens he may bear

ííííThis one more golden burden.

íííí"I sing, like birds of blithesome note,

ííííThat in the branches dwell;The song that rises from the throat

ííííRepays the minstrel well.One boon I'd crave, if not too bold--One bumper in a cup of gold

ííííBe as my guerdon given."

ííííThe bowl he raised, the bowl he quaff'd:

íííí"Oh drink, with solace fraught!Oh, house thrice-blest, where such a draught

ííííA trifling gift is thought!When Fortune smiles, remember me,And as I thank you heartily,

ííííAs warmly thank ye Heaven!"

íííí1795.*-----BALLAD

ííííOF THE BANISHED AND RETURNING COUNT.

íííí[Goethe began to write an opera called Lowenstuhl, founded uponthe old tradition which forms the subject of this Ballad, but henever carried out his design.]

ííííOH, enter old minstrel, thou time-honour'd one!We children are here in the hall all alone,

ííííThe portals we straightway will bar.Our mother is praying, our father is gone

ííííTo the forest, on wolves to make war.Oh sing us a ballad, the tale then repeat,

íííí'Till brother and I learn it right;We long have been hoping a minstrel to meet,

ííííFor children hear tales with delight.

íííí"At midnight, when darkness its fearful veil weaves,His lofty and stately old castle he leaves,

ííííBut first he has buried his wealth.What figure is that in his arms one perceives,

ííííAs the Count quits the gateway by stealth?O'er what is his mantle so hastily thrown?

ííííWhat bears he along in his flight?A daughter it is, and she gently sleeps on"--

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

íííí"The morning soon glimmers. the world is so wide,In valleys and forests a home is supplied,

ííííThe bard in each village is cheer'd.Thus lives he and wanders, while years onward glide,

ííííAnd longer still waxes his beard;But the maiden so fair in his arms grows amain,

íííí'Neath her star all-protecting and bright,Secured in the mantle from wind and from rain--"

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

íííí"And year upon year with swift footstep now steals,The mantle it fades, many rents it reveals,

ííííThe maiden no more it can hold.The father he sees her, what rapture he feels!

ííííHis joy cannot now be controll'd.How worthy she seems of the race whence she springs,

ííííHow noble and fair to the sight!What wealth to her dearly-loved father she brings!"--

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

íííí"Then comes there a princely knight galloping by,She stretches her hand out, as soon as he's nigh,

ííííBut alms he refuses to give.He seizes her hand, with a smile in his eye:

íííí'Thou art mine!' he exclaims, 'while I live!''When thou know'st,' cries the old man, 'the treasure that'sthere,

ííííA princess thou'lt make her of right;Betroth'd be she now, on this spot green and fair--'"

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

íííí"So she's bless'd by the priest on the hallowed place,And she goes with a smiling but sorrowful face,

ííííFrom her father she fain would not part.The old man still wanders with ne'er-changing pace,

ííííHe covers with joy his sad heart.So I think of my daughter, as years pass away,

ííííAnd my grandchildren far from my sight;I bless them by night, and I bless them by day"--

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

ííííHe blesses the children: a knocking they hear,The father it is! They spring forward in fear,

ííííThe old man they cannot conceal--"Thou beggar, wouldst lure, then, my children so dear?

ííííStraight seize him, ye vassals of steel!To the dungeon most deep, with the fool-hardy knave!"

ííííThe mother from far hears the fight;She hastens with flatt'ring entreaty to crave--

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

ííííThe vassals they suffer the Bard to stand there,And mother and children implore him to spare,

ííííThe proud prince would stifle his ire,'Till driven to fury at hearing their prayer,

ííííHis smouldering anger takes fire:"Thou pitiful race! Oh, thou beggarly crew!

ííííEclipsing my star, once so bright!Ye'll bring me destruction, ye sorely shall rue!"

ííííThe children they hear with affright.

ííííThe old man still stands there with dignified mien,The vassals of steel quake before him, I ween,

ííííThe Count's fury increases in power;"My wedded existence a curse long has been,

ííííAnd these are the fruits from that flower!'Tis ever denied, and the saying is true,

ííííThat to wed with the base-born is right;The beggar has borne me a beggarly crew,--"

ííííThe children they hear with affright.

íííí"If the husband, the father, thus treats you with scorn,If the holiest bonds by him rashly are torn,

ííííThen come to your father--to me!The beggar may gladden life's pathway forlorn,

ííííThough aged and weak he may be.This castle is mine! thou hast made it thy prey,

ííííThy people 'twas put me to flight;The tokens I bear will confirm what I say"--

ííííThe children they hear with delight.

íííí"The king who erst govern'd returneth again,And restores to the Faithful the goods that were ta'en,

ííííI'll unseal all my treasures the while;The laws shall be gentle, and peaceful the reign"--

ííííThe old man thus cries with a smile--"Take courage, my son! all hath turned out for good,

ííííAnd each hath a star that is bright,Those the princess hath borne thee are princely in blood,"--

ííííThe children thy hear with delight.

íííí1816.-----THE VIOLET.

ííííUPON the mead a violet stood,Retiring, and of modest mood,

ííííIn truth, a violet fair.Then came a youthful shepherdess,And roam'd with sprightly joyousness,And blithely woo'd

ííííWith carols sweet the air

íííí"Ah!" thought the violet, "had I beenFor but the smallest moment e'en

ííííNature's most beauteous flower,'Till gather'd by my love, and press'd,When weary, 'gainst her gentle breast,For e'en, for e'en

ííííOne quarter of an hour!"

ííííAlas! alas! the maid drew nigh,The violet failed to meet her eye,

ííííShe crush'd the violet sweet.It sank and died, yet murmur'd not:"And if I die, oh, happy lot,For her I die,

ííííAnd at her very feet!"

íííí1775.*-----THE FAITHLESS BOY.

ííííTHERE was a wooer blithe and gay,

ííííA son of France was he,--Who in his arms for many a day,

ííííAs though his bride were she,A poor young maiden had caress'd,And fondly kiss'd, and fondly press'd,

ííííAnd then at length deserted.

ííííWhen this was told the nut-brown maid,

ííííHer senses straightway fled;She laugh'd and wept, and vow'd and pray'd,

ííííAnd presently was dead.The hour her soul its farewell took,The boy was sad, with terror shook,

ííííThen sprang upon his charger.

ííííHe drove his spurs into his side,

ííííAnd scour'd the country round;But wheresoever he might ride,

ííííNo rest for him was found.For seven long days and nights he rode,It storm'd, the waters overflow'd,

ííííIt bluster'd, lighten'd, thunder'd.

ííííOn rode he through the tempest's din,

ííííTill he a building spied;In search of shelter crept he in,

ííííWhen he his steed had tied.And as he groped his doubtful way,The ground began to rock and sway,--

ííííHe fell a hundred fathoms.

ííííWhen he recover'd from the blow,

ííííHe saw three lights pass by;He sought in their pursuit to go,

ííííThe lights appear'd to fly.They led his footsteps all astray,Up, down, through many a narrow way

ííííThrough ruin'd desert cellars.

ííííWhen lo! he stood within a hall,

ííííWith hollow eyes. and grinning all;They bade him taste the fare.

ííííA hundred guests sat there.He saw his sweetheart 'midst the throng,Wrapp'd up in grave-clothes white and long;

ííííShe turn'd, and----*

íííí1774.(* This ballad is introduced in Act II. of Claudine of VillaBella, where it is suddenly broken off, as it is here.)-----THE ERL-KING.

ííííWHO rides there so late through the night dark and drear?The father it is, with his infant so dear;He holdeth the boy tightly clasp'd in his arm,He holdeth him safely, he keepeth him warm.

íííí"My son, wherefore seek'st thou thy face thus to hide?""Look, father, the Erl-King is close by our side!Dost see not the Erl-King, with crown and with train?""My son, 'tis the mist rising over the plain."

íííí"Oh, come, thou dear infant! oh come thou with me!Full many a game I will play there with thee;On my strand, lovely flowers their blossoms unfold,My mother shall grace thee with garments of gold."

íííí"My father, my father, and dost thou not hearThe words that the Erl-King now breathes in mine ear?""Be calm, dearest child, 'tis thy fancy deceives;'Tis the sad wind that sighs through the withering leaves."

íííí"Wilt go, then, dear infant, wilt go with me there?My daughters shall tend thee with sisterly careMy daughters by night their glad festival keep,They'll dance thee, and rock thee, and sing thee to sleep."

íííí"My father, my father, and dost thou not see,How the Erl-King his daughters has brought here for me?""My darling, my darling, I see it aright,'Tis the aged grey willows deceiving thy sight."

íííí"I love thee, I'm charm'd by thy beauty, dear boy!And if thou'rt unwilling, then force I'll employ.""My father, my father, he seizes me fast,Full sorely the Erl-King has hurt me at last."

ííííThe father now gallops, with terror half wild,He grasps in his arms the poor shuddering child;He reaches his courtyard with toil and with dread,--The child in his arms finds he motionless, dead.

íííí1782.*-----JOHANNA SEBUS.

íííí[To the memory of an excellent and beautiful girl of 17,belonging to the village of Brienen, who perished on the 13th ofJanuary, 1809, whilst giving help on the occasion of the breakingup of the ice on the Rhine, and the bursting of the dam ofCleverham.]

ííííTHE DAM BREAKS DOWN, THE ICE-PLAIN GROWLS,THE FLOODS ARISE, THE WATER HOWLS.

íííí"I'll bear thee, mother, across the swell,

íííí'Tis not yet high, I can wade right well."

íííí"Remember us too! in what danger are we!

ííííThy fellow-lodger, and children three!

ííííThe trembling woman!--Thou'rt going away!"

ííííShe bears the mother across the spray.

íííí"Quick! haste to the mound, and awhile there wait,

ííííI'll soon return, and all will be straight.

ííííThe mound's close by, and safe from the wet;

ííííBut take my goat too, my darling pet!"

ííííTHE DAM DISSOLVES, THE ICE-PLAIN GROWLS,THE FLOODS DASH ON, THE WATER HOWLS.

ííííShe places the mother safe on the shore;

ííííFair Susan then turns tow'rd the flood once more.

íííí"Oh whither? Oh whither? The breadth fast grows,

ííííBoth here and there the water o'erflows.

ííííWilt venture, thou rash one, the billows to brave?""THEY SHALL, AND THEY MUST BE PRESERVED FROM THE WAVE!"

ííííTHE DAM DISAPPEARS, THE WATER GROWLS,LIKE OCEAN BILLOWS IT HEAVES AND HOWLS.

ííííFair Susan returns by the way she had tried,

ííííThe waves roar around, but she turns not aside;

ííííShe reaches the mound, and the neighbour straight,

ííííBut for her and the children, alas, too late!

ííííTHE DAM DISAPPEAR'D,--LIKE A SEA IT GROWLS,ROUND THE HILLOCK IN CIRCLING EDDIES IT HOWLS.

ííííThe foaming abyss gapes wide, and whirls round,

ííííThe women and children are borne to the ground;

ííííThe horn of the goat by one is seized fast,

ííííBut, ah, they all must perish at last!

ííííFair Susan still stands-there, untouch'd by the wave;

ííííThe youngest, the noblest, oh, who now will save?

ííííFair Susan still stands there, as bright as a star,

ííííBut, alas! all hope, all assistance is far.

ííííThe foaming waters around her roar,

ííííTo save her, no bark pushes off from the shore.

ííííHer gaze once again she lifts up to Heaven,

ííííThen gently away by the flood she is driven.

ííííNO DAM, NO PLAIN! TO MARK THE PLACESOME STRAGGLING TREES ARE THE ONLY TRACE.

ííííThe rushing water the wilderness covers,

ííííYet Susan's image still o'er it hovers.--

ííííThe water sinks, the plains re-appear.

ííííFair Susan's lamented with many a tear,--

ííííMay he who refuses her story to tell,

ííííBe neglected in life and in death as well!

íííí1809.-----THE FISHERMAN.

ííííTHE waters rush'd, the waters rose,

ííííA fisherman sat by,While on his line in calm repose

ííííHe cast his patient eye.And as he sat, and hearken'd there,

ííííThe flood was cleft in twain,And, lo! a dripping mermaid fair

ííííSprang from the troubled main.

ííííShe sang to him, and spake the while:

íííí"Why lurest thou my brood,With human wit and human guile

ííííFrom out their native flood?Oh, couldst thou know how gladly dart

ííííThe fish across the sea,Thou wouldst descend, e'en as thou art,

ííííAnd truly happy be!

íííí"Do not the sun and moon with grace

ííííTheir forms in ocean lave?Shines not with twofold charms their face,

ííííWhen rising from the wave?The deep, deep heavens, then lure thee not,--

ííííThe moist yet radiant blue,--Not thine own form,--to tempt thy lot

íííí'Midst this eternal dew?"

ííííThe waters rush'd, the waters rose,

ííííWetting his naked feet;As if his true love's words were those,

ííííHis heart with longing beat.She sang to him, to him spake she,

ííííHis doom was fix'd, I ween;Half drew she him, and half sank he,

ííííAnd ne'er again was seen.

íííí1779.*-----THE KING OF THULE.*

íííí(* This ballad is also introduced in Faust, where it is sung byMargaret.)

ííííIN Thule lived a monarch,

ííííStill faithful to the grave,To whom his dying mistress

ííííA golden goblet gave.

ííííBeyond all price he deem'd it,

ííííHe quaff'd it at each feast;And, when he drain'd that goblet,

ííííHis tears to flow ne'er ceas'd.

ííííAnd when he felt death near him,

ííííHis cities o'er he told,And to his heir left all things,

ííííBut not that cup of gold.

ííííA regal banquet held he

ííííIn his ancestral ball,In yonder sea-wash'd castle,

íííí'Mongst his great nobles all.

ííííThere stood the aged reveller,

ííííAnd drank his last life's-glow,--Then hurl'd the holy goblet

ííííInto the flood below.

ííííHe saw it falling, filling,

ííííAnd sinking 'neath the main,His eyes then closed for ever,

ííííHe never drank again.

íííí1774.-----

ííííTHE BEAUTEOUS FLOWER.

ííííSONG OF THE IMPRISONED COUNT.

ííííCOUNT.

ííííI KNOW a flower of beauty rare,

ííííAh, how I hold it dear!To seek it I would fain repair,

ííííWere I not prison'd here.My sorrow sore oppresses me,For when I was at liberty,

ííííI had it close beside me.

ííííThough from this castle's walls so steep

ííííI cast mine eyes around,And gaze oft from the lofty keep,

ííííThe flower can not be found.Whoe'er would bring it to my sight,Whether a vassal he, or knight,

ííííMy dearest friend I'd deem him.

ííííTHE ROSE.

ííííI blossom fair,--thy tale of woes

ííííI hear from 'neath thy grate.Thou doubtless meanest me, the rose.

ííííPoor knight of high estate!Thou hast in truth a lofty mind;The queen of flowers is then enshrin'd,

ííííI doubt not, in thy bosom.

ííííCOUNT.

ííííThy red, in dress of green array'd,

ííííAs worth all praise I hold;And so thou'rt treasured by each maid

ííííLike precious stones or gold.Thy wreath adorns the fairest faceBut still thou'rt not the flower whose grace

ííííI honour here in silence.

ííííTHE LILY.

ííííThe rose is wont with pride to swell,

ííííAnd ever seeks to rise;But gentle sweethearts love full well

ííííThe lily's charms to prize,The heart that fills a bosom true,That is, like me, unsullied too,

ííííMy merit values duly.

ííííCOUNT.

ííííIn truth, I hope myself unstain'd,

ííííAnd free from grievous crime;Yet I am here a prisoner chain'd,

ííííAnd pass in grief my time,To me thou art an image sureOf many a maiden, mild and pure,

ííííAnd yet I know a dearer.

ííííTHE PINK.

ííííThat must be me, the pink, who scent

ííííThe warder's garden here;Or wherefore is he so intent

ííííMy charms with care to rear?My petals stand in beauteous ring,Sweet incense all around I fling,

ííííAnd boast a thousand colours.

ííííCOUNT.

ííííThe pink in truth we should not slight,

ííííIt is the gardener's prideIt now must stand exposed to light,

ííííNow in the shade abide.Yet what can make the Count's heart glowIs no mere pomp of outward show;

ííííIt is a silent flower.

ííííTHE VIOLET.

ííííHere stand I, modestly half hid,

ííííAnd fain would silence keep;Yet since to speak I now am bid,

ííííI'll break my silence deep.If, worthy Knight, I am that flower,It grieves me that I have not power

ííííTo breathe forth all my sweetness.

ííííCOUNT.

ííííThe violet's charms I prize indeed,

ííííSo modest 'tis, and fair,And smells so sweet; yet more I need

ííííTo ease my heavy care.The truth I'll whisper in thine ear:Upon these rocky heights so drear,

ííííI cannot find the loved one.

ííííThe truest maiden 'neath the sky

ííííRoams near the stream below,And breathes forth many a gentle sigh,

ííííTill I from hence can go.And when she plucks a flow'ret blue,And says "Forget-me-not!"--I, too,

ííííThough far away, can feel it.

ííííAy, distance only swells love's might,

ííííWhen fondly love a pair;Though prison'd in the dungeon's night,

ííííIn life I linger thereAnd when my heart is breaking nigh,"Forget-me-not!" is all I cry,

ííííAnd straightway life returneth.

íííí1798.-----SIR CURT'S WEDDING-JOURNEY.

ííííWITH a bridegroom's joyous bearing,

ííííMounts Sir Curt his noble beast,To his mistress' home repairing,

ííííThere to hold his wedding feast;When a threatening foe advances

ííííFrom a desert, rocky spot;For the fray they couch their lances,

ííííNot delaying, speaking not.

ííííLong the doubtful fight continues,

ííííVictory then for Curt declares;Conqueror, though with wearied sinews,

ííííForward on his road he fares.When he sees, though strange it may be,

ííííSomething 'midst the foliage move;'Tis a mother, with her baby,

ííííStealing softly through the grove!

ííííAnd upon the spot she beckons--

íííí"Wherefore, love, this speed so wild?Of the wealth thy storehouse reckons,

ííííHast thou nought to give thy child!"Flames of rapture now dart through him,

ííííAnd he longs for nothing more,While the mother seemeth to him

ííííLovely as the maid of yore.

ííííBut he hears his servants blowing,

ííííAnd bethinks him of his bride;And ere long, while onward going,

ííííChances past a fair to ride;In the booths he forthwith buys him

ííííFor his mistress many a pledge;But, alas! some Jews surprise him,

ííííAnd long-standing debts allege.

ííííAnd the courts of justice duly

ííííSend the knight to prison straight.Oh accursed story, truly!

ííííFor a hero, what a fate!Can my patience such things weather?

ííííGreat is my perplexity.Women, debts, and foes together,--

ííííAh, no knight escapes scot free!

íííí1803.*-----WEDDING SONG.

ííííTHE tale of the Count our glad song shall record

ííííWho had in this castle his dwelling,Where now ye are feasting the new-married lord,

ííííHis grandson of whom we are telling.The Count as Crusader had blazon'd his fame,Through many a triumph exalted his name,And when on his steed to his dwelling he came,

ííííHis castle still rear'd its proud head,But servants and wealth had all fled.

íííí'Tis true that thou, Count, hast return'd to thy home,

ííííBut matters are faring there ill.The winds through the chambers at liberty roam,

ííííAnd blow through the windows at willWhat's best to be done in a cold autumn night?Full many I've pass'd in more piteous plight;The morn ever settles the matter aright.

ííííThen quick, while the moon shines so clear,

ííííTo bed on the straw, without fear,

ííííAnd whilst in a soft pleasing slumber he lay,

ííííA motion he feels 'neath his bed.The rat, an he likes it, may rattle away!

ííííAy, had he but crumbs there outspread!But lo! there appears a diminutive wight,A dwarf 'tis, yet graceful, and bearing a light,With orator-gestures that notice invite,

ííííAt the feet of the Count on the floor

ííííWho sleeps not, though weary full sore.

íííí"We've long been accustom'd to hold here our feast,

ííííSince thou from thy castle first went;And as we believed thou wert far in the East,

ííííTo revel e'en now we were bent.And if thou'lt allow it, and seek not to chide,We dwarfs will all banquet with pleasure and pride,To honour the wealthy, the beautiful bride

ííííSays the Count with a smile, half-asleep;--

íííí"Ye're welcome your quarters to keep!"

ííííThree knights then advance, riding all in a group,

ííííWho under the bed were conceal'd;And then is a singing and noise-making troop

ííííOf strange little figures reveal'd;And waggon on waggon with all kinds of things--The clatter they cause through the ear loudly rings--The like ne'er was seen save in castles of kings;

ííííAt length, in a chariot of gold,

ííííThe bride and the guests too, behold!

ííííThen all at full gallop make haste to advance,

ííííEach chooses his place in the hall;With whirling and waltzing, and light joyous dance,

ííííThey begin with their sweethearts the ball.The fife and the fiddle all merrily sound,Thy twine, and they glide, and with nimbleness bound,Thy whisper, and chatter, and, chatter around;

ííííThe Count on the scene casts his eye,

ííííAnd seems in a fever to lie.

ííííThey hustle, and bustle, and rattle away

ííííOn table, on bench, and on stool;Then all who had joined in the festival gay

ííííWith their partners attempt to grow cool.The hams and the sausages nimbly they bear,And meat, fish, and poultry in plenty are there,Surrounded with wine of the vintage most rare:

ííííAnd when they have revell'd full long,

ííííThey vanish at last with a song.

íííí*      *      *      *      *      *

ííííAnd if we're to sing all that further occurr'd,

ííííPray cease ye to bluster and prate;For what he so gladly in small saw and heard

ííííHe enjoy'd and he practis'd in great.For trumpets, and singing, and shouts without endOn the bridal-train, chariots and horsemen attend,They come and appear, and they bow and they bend,

ííííIn merry and countless array.

ííííThus was it, thus is it to-day.

íííí1802.-----THE TREASURE-DIGGER

ííííALL my weary days I pass'd

ííííSick at heart and poor in purse.

ííííPoverty's the greatest curse,

ííííRiches are the highest good!And to end my woes at last,

ííííTreasure-seeking forth I sped.

íííí"Thou shalt have my soul instead!"

ííííThus I wrote, and with my blood.

ííííRing round ring I forthwith drew,

ííííWondrous flames collected there,

ííííHerbs and bones in order fair,

ííííTill the charm had work'd aright.Then, to learned precepts true,

ííííDug to find some treasure old,

ííííIn the place my art foretold

ííííBlack and stormy was the night.

ííííComing o'er the distant plain,

ííííWith the glimmer of a star,

ííííSoon I saw a light afar,

ííííAs the hour of midnight knell'd.Preparation was in vain.

ííííSudden all was lighted up

ííííWith the lustre of a cup

ííííThat a beauteous boy upheld.

ííííSweetly seem'd his eves to laugh

ííííNeath his flow'ry chaplet's load;

ííííWith the drink that brightly glow'd,

ííííHe the circle enter'd in.And he kindly bade me quaff:

ííííThen methought "This child can ne'er,

ííííWith his gift so bright and fair,

ííííTo the arch-fiend be akin."

íííí"Pure life's courage drink!" cried he:"This advice to prize then learn,--

ííííNever to this place return

ííííTrusting in thy spells absurd;Dig no longer fruitlessly.

ííííGuests by night, and toil by day!

ííííWeeks laborious, feast-days gay!

ííííBe thy future magic-word!

íííí1797.-----THE RAT-CATCHER.

ííííI AM the bard known far and wide,The travell'd rat-catcher beside;A man most needful to this town,So glorious through its old renown.However many rats I see,How many weasels there may be,I cleanse the place from ev'ry one,All needs must helter-skelter run.

ííííSometimes the bard so full of cheerAs a child-catcher will appear,Who e'en the wildest captive brings,Whene'er his golden tales he sings.However proud each boy in heart,However much the maidens start,I bid the chords sweet music make,And all must follow in my wake.

ííííSometimes the skilful bard ye viewIn the form of maiden-catcher too;For he no city enters e'er,Without effecting wonders there.However coy may be each maid,However the women seem afraid,Yet all will love-sick be ere longTo sound of magic lute and song.

íííí[Da Capo.]                  1803.*-----

ííííTHE SPINNER.

ííííAs I calmly sat and span,

ííííToiling with all zeal,Lo! a young and handsome man

ííííPass'd my spinning-wheel.

ííííAnd he praised,--what harm was there?--

ííííSweet the things he said--Praised my flax-resembling hair,

ííííAnd the even thread.

ííííHe with this was not content,

ííííBut must needs do more;And in twain the thread was rent,

ííííThough 'twas safe before.

ííííAnd the flax's stonelike weight

ííííNeeded to be told;But no longer was its state

ííííValued as of old.

ííííWhen I took it to the weaver,

ííííSomething felt I start,And more quickly, as with fever,

ííííThrobb'd my trembling heart.

ííííThen I bear the thread at length

ííííThrough the heat, to bleach;But, alas, I scarce have strength

ííííTo the pool to reach.

ííííWhat I in my little room

ííííSpan so fine and slight,--As was likely. I presume--

ííííCame at last to light.

íííí1800.*-----BEFORE A COURT OF JUSTICE.

ííííTHE father's name ye ne'er shall be told

ííííOf my darling unborn life;"Shame, shame," ye cry, "on the strumpet bold!"

ííííYet I'm an honest wife.

ííííTo whom I'm wedded, ye ne'er shall be told,

ííííYet he's both loving and fair;He wears on his neck a chain of gold,

ííííAnd a hat of straw doth he wear.

ííííIf scorn 'tis vain to seek to repel,

ííííOn me let the scorn be thrown.I know him well, and he knows me well,

ííííAnd to God, too, all is known.

ííííSir Parson and Sir Bailiff, again,

ííííI pray you, leave me in peace!My child it is, my child 'twill remain,

ííííSo let your questionings cease!

íííí1815.*-----THE PAGE AND THE MILLER'S DAUGHTER.

ííííPAGE.

ííííWHERE goest thou? Where?Miller's daughter so fair!

ííííThy name, pray?--

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.

íííí'Tis Lizzy.

ííííPAGE.Where goest thou? Where?With the rake in thy hand?

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.Father's meadows and land

ííííTo visit, I'm busy.

ííííPAGE.Dost go there alone?

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.By this rake, sir, 'tis shown

ííííThat we're making the hay;And the pears ripen fastIn the garden at last,

ííííSo I'll pick them to-day.

ííííPAGE.Is't a silent thicket I yonder view?

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.Oh, yes! there are two;There's one on each side.

ííííPAGE.I'll follow thee soon;When the sun burns at noonWe'll go there, o'urselves from his rays to hide,And then in some glade all-verdant and deep--

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.Why, people would say--

ííííPAGE.Within mine arms thou gently wilt sleep.

ííííMILLER'S DAUGHTER.

ííííYour pardon, I pray!Whoever is kiss'd by the miller-maid,Upon the spot must needs be betray'd.

íííí'Twould give me distress

ííííTo cover with whiteYour pretty dark dress.Equal with equal! then all is right!That's the motto in which I delight.I am in love with the miller-boy;He wears nothing that I could destroy.

íííí1797.-----THE YOUTH AND THE MILLSTREAM.

íííí[This sweet Ballad, and the one entitled The Maid of the Mill'sRepentance, were written on the occasion of a visit paid by Goetheto Switzerland. The Maid of the Mill's Treachery, to which thelatter forms the sequel, was not written till the following year.]

ííííYOUTH.

ííííSAY, sparkling streamlet, whither thou

ííííArt going!With joyous mien thy waters now

ííííAre flowing.Why seek the vale so hastily?Attend for once, and answer me!

ííííMILLSTREAM.

ííííOh youth, I was a brook indeed;

ííííBut latelyMy bed they've deepen'd, and my speed

ííííSwell'd greatly,That I may haste to yonder mill.And so I'm full and never still.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííThe mill thou seekest in a mood

ííííContented,And know'st not how my youthful blood

íííí'S tormented.But doth the miller's daughter fairGaze often on thee kindly there?

ííííMILLSTREAM.

ííííShe opes the shutters soon as light

ííííIs gleaming;And comes to bathe her features bright

ííííAnd beaming.So full and snow-white is her breast,--I feel as hot as steam suppress'd.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííIf she in water can inflame

ííííSuch ardour,Surely, then, flesh and blood to tame

ííííIs harder.When once is seen her beauteous face,One ever longs her steps to trace.

ííííMILLSTREAM.

ííííOver the wheel I, roaring, bound,

ííííAll-proudly,And ev'ry spoke whirls swiftly round,

ííííAnd loudly.Since I have seen the miller's daughter,With greater vigour flows the water.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííLike others, then, can grief, poor brook,

ííííOppress thee?"Flow on!"--thus she'll, with smiling look,

ííííAddress thee.With her sweet loving glance, oh say,Can she thy flowing current stay?

ííííMILLSTREAM.

íííí'Tis sad, 'tis sad to have to speed

ííííFrom yonder;I wind, and slowly through the mead

ííííWould wander;And if the choice remain'd with me,Would hasten back there presently.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííFarewell, thou who with me dost prove

ííííLove's sadness!Perchance some day thou'lt breathe of love

ííííAnd gladness.Go, tell her straight, and often too,The boy's mute hopes and wishes true.

íííí1797.-----

ííííTHE MAID OF THE MILL'S TREACHERY.

íííí[This Ballad is introduced in the Wanderjahre, in a tale calledThe Foolish Pilgrim.]

ííííWHENCE comes our friend so hastily,

ííííWhen scarce the Eastern sky is grey?Hath he just ceased, though cold it be,

ííííIn yonder holy spot to pray?The brook appears to hem his path,

ííííWould he barefooted o'er it go?Why curse his orisons in wrath,

ííííAcross those heights beclad with snow?

ííííAlas! his warm bed he bath left,

ííííWhere he had look'd for bliss, I ween;And if his cloak too, had been reft,

ííííHow fearful his disgrace had been!By yonder villain sorely press'd,

ííííHis wallet from him has been torn;Our hapless friend has been undress'd,

ííííLeft well nigh naked as when born.

ííííThe reason why he came this road,

ííííIs that he sought a pair of eyes,Which, at the mill, as brightly glow'd

ííííAs those that are in Paradise.He will not soon again be there;

ííííFrom out the house he quickly hied,And when he gain'd the open air,

ííííThus bitterly and loudly cried

íííí"Within her gaze, so dazzling bright,

ííííNo word of treachery I could read;She seem'd to see me with delight,

ííííYet plann'd e'en then this cruel deed!Could I, when basking in her smile,

ííííDream of the treason in her breast?She bade kind Cupid stay awhile,

ííííAnd he was there, to make us blest.

íííí"To taste of love's sweet ecstasy

ííííThroughout the night, that endless seem'd,And for her mother's help to cry

ííííOnly when morning sunlight beam'd!A dozen of her kith and kin,

ííííA very human flood, in-press'dHer cousins came, her aunts peer'd in,

ííííAnd uncles, brothers, and the rest.

íííí"Then what a tumult, fierce and loud!

ííííEach seem'd a beast of prey to be;The maiden's honour all the crowd,

ííííWith fearful shout, demand of me.Why should they, madmen-like, begin

ííííTo fall upon a guiltless youth?For he who such a prize would win,

ííííFar nimbler needs must be, in truth.

íííí"The way to follow up with skill

ííííHis freaks, by love betimes is known:He ne'er will leave, within a mill,

ííííSweet flowers for sixteen years alone.--They stole my clothes away,--yes, all!

ííííAnd tried my cloak besides to steal.How strange that any house so small

ííííSo many rascals could conceal!

íííí"Then I sprang up, and raved, and swore,

ííííTo force a passage through them there.I saw the treacherous maid once more,

ííííAnd she was still, alas, so fairThey all gave way before my wrath,

ííííWild outcries flew about pell-mell;At length I managed to rush forth,

ííííWith voice of thunder, from that hell.

íííí"As maidens of the town we fly,

ííííWe'll shun you maidens of the village;Leave it to those of quality

ííííTheir humble worshippers to pillage.Yet if ye are of practised skill,

ííííAnd of all tender ties afraid,Exchange your lovers, if ye will,

ííííBut never let them be betray'd."

ííííThus sings he in the winter-night,

ííííWhile not a blade of grass was green.I laugh'd to see his piteous plight,

ííííFor it was well-deserved, I ween.And may this be the fate of all,

ííííWho treat by day their true loves ill,And, with foolhardy daring, crawl

ííííBy night to Cupid's treacherous mill!

íííí1798.-----THE MAID OF THE MILL'S REPENTANCE.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííAWAY, thou swarthy witch! Go forth

ííííFrom out my house, I tell thee!Or else I needs must, in my wrath,

ííííExpel thee!What's this thou singest so falsely, forsooth,Of love and a maiden's silent truth?

ííííWho'll trust to such a story!

ííííGIPSY.

ííííI sing of a maid's repentant fears,

ííííAnd long and bitter yearning;Her levity's changed to truth and tears

ííííAll-burning.She dreads no more the threats of her mother,She dreads far less the blows of her brother,

ííííThan the dearly loved-one's hatred.

ííííYOUTH.

ííííOf selfishness sing and treacherous lies,

ííííOf murder and thievish plunder!Such actions false will cause no surprise,

ííííOr wonder.When  they share their booty, both clothes and purse,--As bad as you gipsies, and even worse,

ííííSuch tales find ready credence.

ííííGIPSY.

íííí"Alas, alas! oh what have I done?

ííííCan listening aught avail me?I hear him toward my room hasten on,

ííííTo hail me.My heart beat high, to myself I said:'O would that thou hadst never betray'd

ííííThat night of love to thy mother!'"

ííííYOUTH.

ííííAlas! I foolishly ventured there,

ííííFor the cheating silence misled me;Ah, sweetest! let me to thee repair,--

ííííNor dread me!When suddenly rose a fearful din,Her mad relations came pouring in.

ííííMy blood still boils in my body!

ííííGIPSY.

íííí"Oh when will return an hour like this?

íííí1813.-----THE DANCE OF DEATH.

ííííTHE warder looks down at the mid hour of night,

ííííOn the tombs that lie scatter'd below:The moon fills the place with her silvery light,

ííííBut the cerements stand in their way;And as modesty cannot avail them aught here,They shake themselves all, and the shrouds soon appear

ííííScatter'd over the tombs in confusion.

ííííNow waggles the leg, and now wriggles the thigh,

ííííAs the troop with strange gestures advance,And a rattle and clatter anon rises high,

ííííAs of one beating time to the dance.The sight to the warder seems wondrously queer,When the villainous Tempter speaks thus in his ear:

ííííBehind the church-door with all speed;The moon still continues her clear light to shed

ííííOn the dance that they fearfully lead.But the dancers at length disappear one by one,And their shrouds, ere they vanish, they carefully don,

ííííAnd under the turf all is quiet.

ííííBut one of them stumbles and shuffles there still,

ííííAnd gropes at the graves in despair;Yet 'tis by no comrade he's treated so ill

ííííThe shroud he soon scents in the air.So he rattles the door--for the warder 'tis wellThat 'tis bless'd, and so able the foe to repel,

ííííAll cover'd with crosses in metal.

ííííAdvances the dreaded pursuer.

ííííThe warder he quakes, and the warder turns pale,

ííííThe shroud to restore fain had sought;When the end,--now can nothing to save him avail,--
