ííííIn the drear void of a sad tortured breast;Now on the well-known threshold Hope hath smil'd,Herself appeareth in the sunlight mild.

ííííUnto the peace of God, which, as we read,

ííííBlesseth us more than reason e'er bath done,Love's happy peace would I compare indeed,

ííííWhen in the presence of the dearest one.There rests the heart, and there that sweetest thought,The thought of being hers, is check'd by nought.

ííííIn the pure bosom doth a yearning float,

ííííUnto a holier, purer, unknown BeingIts grateful aspiration to devote,

ííííThe Ever-Nameless then unriddled seeing;We call it: piety!--such blest delightI feel a share in, when before her sight.

ííííBefore her sight, as 'neath the sun's hot ray,

ííííBefore her breath, as 'neath the spring's soft wind,In its deep wintry cavern melts away

ííííSelf-love, so long in icy chains confin'd;No selfishness and no self-will are nigh,For at her advent they were forced to fly.

ííííIt seems as though she said: "As hours pass by

ííííThey spread before us life with kindly plan;Small knowledge did the yesterday supply,

ííííTo know the morrow is conceal'd from man;And if the thought of evening made me start,The sun at setting gladden'd straight my heart.

íííí"Act, then, as I, and look, with joyous mind,

ííííThe moment in the face; nor linger thou!Meet it with speed, so fraught with life, so kind

ííííIn action, and in love so radiant now;Let all things be where thou art, childlike ever,Thus thoult be all, thus, thou'lt be vanquish'd never."

ííííThou speakest well, methought, for as thy guide

ííííThe moment's favour did a god assign,And each one feels himself when by thy side,

ííííFate's fav'rite in a moment so divine;I tremble at thy look that bids me go,Why should I care such wisdom vast to know?

ííííNow am I far! And what would best befit

ííííThe present minute? I could scarcely tell;Full many a rich possession offers it,

ííííThese but offend, and I would fain repel.Yearnings unquenchable still drive me on,All counsel, save unbounded tears, is gone.

ííííFlow on, flow on in never-ceasing course,

ííííYet may ye never quench my inward fire!Within my bosom heaves a mighty force,

ííííWhere death and life contend in combat dire.Medicines may serve the body's pangs to still;Nought but the spirit fails in strength of will,--

ííííFails in conception; wherefore fails it so?

ííííA thousand times her image it portrays;Enchanting now, and now compell'd to go,

ííííNow indistinct, now clothed in purest rays!How could the smallest comfort here be flowing?The ebb and flood, the coming and the going!

íííí*      *      *      *      *      *

ííííLeave me here now, my life's companions true!

ííííLeave me alone on rock, in moor and heath;But courage! open lies the world to you,

ííííThe glorious heavens above, the earth beneath;Observe, investigate, with searching eyes,And nature will disclose her mysteries.

ííííTo me is all, I to myself am lost,

ííííWho the immortals' fav'rite erst was thought;They, tempting, sent Pandoras to my cost,

ííííSo rich in wealth, with danger far more fraught;They urged me to those lips, with rapture crown'd,Deserted me, and hurl'd me to the ground.

íííí1823.

ííííIII.  ATONEMENT.

íííí[Composed, when 74 years old, for a Polish lady, who excelled inplaying on the pianoforte.]

ííííPASSION brings reason--who can pacify

ííííAn anguish'd heart whose loss hath been so great?Where are the hours that fled so swiftly by?

ííííIn vain the fairest thou didst gain from fate;Sad is the soul, confused the enterprise;

ííííThe glorious world, how on the sense it dies!

ííííIn million tones entwined for evermore,

ííííMusic with angel-pinions hovers there,To pierce man's being to its inmost core,

ííííEternal beauty has its fruit to bear;The eye grows moist, in yearnings blest reveresThe godlike worth of music as of tears.

ííííAnd so the lighten'd heart soon learns to see

ííííThat it still lives, and beats, and ought to beat,Off'ring itself with joy and willingly,

ííííIn grateful payment for a gift so sweet.And then was felt,--oh may it constant prove!--The twofold bliss of music and of love.

íííí1823.-----

ííííTHE remembrance of the GoodKeep us ever glad in mood.

ííííThe remembrance of the FairMakes a mortal rapture share.

ííííThe remembrance of one's LoveBlest Is, if it constant prove.

ííííThe remembrance of the OneIs the greatest joy that's known.

íííí1828.-----[Written at the age of 77.]

ííííWHEN I was still a youthful wight,

ííííSo full of enjoyment and merry,The painters used to assert, in spite,

ííííThat my features were small--yes, very;Yet then full many a beauteous childWith true affection upon me smil'd.

ííííNow as a greybeard I sit here in state,

ííííBy street and by lane held in awe, sirs;And may be seen, like old Frederick the Great,

ííííOn pipebowls, on cups, and on saucers.Yet the beauteous maidens, they keep afar;Oh vision of youth! Oh golden star!

íííí1826.-----FOR EVER.

ííííTHE happiness that man, whilst prison'd here,

ííííIs wont with heavenly rapture to compare,--The harmony of Truth, from wavering clear,--

ííííOf Friendship that is free from doubting care,--The light which in stray thoughts alone can cheer

ííííThe wise,--the bard alone in visions fair,--In my best hours I found in her all this,And made mine own, to mine exceeding bliss.

íííí1820.*-----FROM AN ALBUM OF 1604.

ííííHOPE provides wings to thought, and love to hope.Rise up to Cynthia, love, when night is clearest,And say, that as on high her figure changeth,So, upon earth, my joy decays and grows.And whisper in her ear with modest softness,How doubt oft hung its head, and truth oft wept.And oh ye thoughts, distrustfully inclined,If ye are therefore by the loved one chided,Answer: 'tis true ye change, but alter not,As she remains the same, yet changeth ever.Doubt may invade the heart, but poisons not,For love is sweeter, by suspicion flavour'd.If it with anger overcasts the eye,And heaven's bright purity perversely blackens,Then zephyr-sighs straight scare the clouds away,And, changed to tears, dissolve them into rain.Thought, hope, and love remain there as before,Till Cynthia gleams upon me as of old.

íííí1820.*-----LINES ON SEEING SCHILLER'S SKULL.

íííí[This curious imitation of the ternary metre of Dante was writtenat the age of 77.]

ííííWITHIN a gloomy charnel-house one day

ííííI view'd the countless skulls, so strangely mated,And of old times I thought, that now were grey.

ííííClose pack'd they stand, that once so fiercely hated,And hardy bones, that to the death contended,

ííííAre lying cross'd,--to lie for ever, fated.What held those crooked shoulder-blades suspended?

ííííNo one now asks; and limbs with vigour fired,The hand, the foot--their use in life is ended.

ííííVainly ye sought the tomb for rest when tired;Peace in the grave may not be yours; ye're driven

ííííBack into daylight by a force inspired;But none can love the wither'd husk, though even

ííííA glorious noble kernel it contained.To me, an adept, was the writing given

ííííWhich not to all its holy sense explained,When 'mid the crowd, their icy shadows flinging,

ííííI saw a form, that glorious still remained.And even there, where mould and damp were clinging,

ííííGave me a blest, a rapture-fraught emotion,As though from death a living fount were springing.

ííííWhat mystic joy I felt! What rapt devotion!That form, how pregnant with a godlike trace!

ííííA look, how did it whirl me tow'rd that oceanWhose rolling billows mightier shapes embrace!

ííííMysterious vessel! Oracle how dear!Even to grasp thee is my hand too base,

ííííExcept to steal thee from thy prison hereWith pious purpose, and devoutly go

ííííBack to the air, free thoughts, and sunlight clear.What greater gain in life can man e'er know

ííííThan when God-Nature will to him explainHow into Spirit steadfastness may flow,

ííííHow steadfast, too, the Spirit-Born remain.

íííí1826.-----ROYAL PRAYER.

ííííHA, I am the lord of earth! The noble,

ííííWho're in my service, love me.Ha, I am the lord of earth! The noble,

ííííO'er whom my sway extendeth, love I.Oh, grant me, God in Heaven, that I may ne'er

ííííDispense with loftiness and love!

íííí1815.*-----HUMAN FEELINGS.

ííííAH, ye gods! ye great immortalsIn the spacious heavens above us!Would ye on this earth but give usSteadfast minds and dauntless courageWe, oh kindly ones, would leave youAll your spacious heavens above us!

íííí1815.*-----ON THE DIVAN.

ííííHE who knows himself and others

ííííHere will also see,That the East and West, like brothers,

ííííParted ne'er shall be.

ííííThoughtfully to float for ever

íííí'Tween two worlds, be man's endeavour!So between the East and West

ííííTo revolve, be my behest!

íííí1833.*-----EXPLANATION  OF AN ANCIENT WOODCUT, REPRESENTINGHANS SACHS' POETICAL MISSION.

íííí[I feel considerable hesitation in venturing to offer thisversion of a poem which Carlyle describes to be 'a beautifulpiece (a very Hans Sacks beatified, both in character and style),which we wish there was any possibility of translating.' Thereader will be aware that Hans Sachs was the celebrated Minstrel-Cobbler of Nuremberg, who Wrote 208 plays, 1700 comic tales, andbetween 4000 and 5000 lyric poems. He flourished throughoutalmost the whole of the 16th century.]

ííííEARLY within his workshop here,On Sundays stands our master dear;His dirty apron he puts away,And wears a cleanly doublet to-day;Lets wax'd thread, hammer, and pincers rest,And lays his awl within his chest;The seventh day he takes reposeFrom many pulls and many blows.

ííííSoon as the spring-sun meets his view,Repose begets him labour anew;He feels that he holds within his brainA little world, that broods there amain,And that begins to act and to live,Which he to others would gladly give.

ííííHe had a skilful eye and true,And was full kind and loving too.For contemplation, clear and pure,--For making all his own again, sure;He had a tongue that charm'd when 'twas heard,And graceful and light flow'd ev'ry word;Which made the Muses in him rejoice,The Master-singer of their choice.

ííííAnd now a maiden enter'd there,With swelling breast, and body fair;With footing firm she took her place,And moved with stately, noble grace;She did not walk in wanton mood,Nor look around with glances lewd.

ííííShe held a measure in her hand,Her girdle was a golden band,A wreath of corn was on her head,Her eye the day's bright lustre shed;Her name is honest Industry,Else, Justice, Magnanimity.

ííííShe enter'd with a kindly greeting;He felt no wonder at the meeting,For, kind and fair as she might be,He long had known her, fancied he.

íííí"I have selected thee," she said,"From all who earth's wild mazes tread,That thou shouldst have clear-sighted sense,And nought that's wrong shouldst e'er commence.When others run in strange confusion,Thy gaze shall see through each illusionWhen others dolefully complain,Thy cause with jesting thou shalt gain,Honour and right shalt value duly,In everything act simply, truly,--Virtue and godliness proclaim,And call all evil by its name,Nought soften down, attempt no quibble,Nought polish up, nought vainly scribble.The world shall stand before thee, then,As seen by Albert Durer's ken,In manliness and changeless life,In inward strength, with firmness rife.Fair Nature's Genius by the handShall lead thee on through every land,Teach thee each different life to scan,Show thee the wondrous ways of man,His shifts, confusions, thrustings, and drubbings,Pushings, tearings, pressings, and rubbings;The varying madness of the crew,The anthill's ravings bring to view;But thou shalt see all this express'd,As though 'twere in a magic chest.Write these things down for folks on earth,In hopes they may to wit give birth."--Then she a window open'd wide,And show'd a motley crowd outside,All kinds of beings 'neath the sky,As in his writings one may spy.

ííííOur master dear was, after this,On Nature thinking, full of bliss,When tow'rd him, from the other sideHe saw an aged woman glide;The name she bears, Historia,Mythologia, Fabula;With footstep tottering and unstableShe dragg'd a large and wooden carved-table,Where, with wide sleeves and human mien,The Lord was catechizing seen;Adam, Eve, Eden, the Serpent's seduction,Gomorrah and Sodom's awful destruction,The twelve illustrious women, too,That mirror of honour brought to view;All kinds of bloodthirstiness, murder, and sin,The twelve wicked tyrants also were in,And all kinds of goodly doctrine and law;Saint Peter with his scourge you saw,With the world's ways dissatisfied,And by our Lord with power supplied.Her train and dress, behind and before,And e'en the seams, were painted o'erWith tales of worldly virtue and crime.--Our master view'd all this for a time;The sight right gladly he survey'd,So useful for him in his trade,Whence he was able to procureExample good and precept sure,Recounting all with truthful care,As though he had been present there.His spirit seem'd from earth to fly,He ne'er had turned away his eye,Did he not just behind him hearA rattle of bells approaching near.And now a fool doth catch his eye,With goat and ape's leap drawing nighA merry interlude preparingWith fooleries and jests unsparing.Behind him, in a line drawn out,He dragg'd all fools, the lean and stout,The great and little, the empty and full,All too witty, and all too dull,A lash he flourish'd overhead,As though a dance of apes he led,Abusing them with bitterness,As though his wrath would ne'er grow less.

ííííWhile on this sight our master gazed,His head was growing well-nigh crazed:What words for all could he e'er find,Could such a medley be combined?Could he continue with delightFor evermore to sing and write?When lo, from out a cloud's dark bedIn at the upper window spedThe Muse, in all her majesty,As fair as our loved maids we see.With clearness she around him threwHer truth, that ever stronger grew.

íííí"I, to ordain thee come," she spake:"So prosper, and my blessing take!The holy fire that slumb'ring liesWithin thee, in bright flames shall rise;Yet that thine ever-restless lifeMay still with kindly strength be rife,I, for thine inward spirit's calm.Have granted nourishment and balm,That rapture may thy soul imbue,Like some fair blossom bathed in dew."--Behind his house then secretlyOutside the doorway pointed she,Where, in a shady garden-nook,A beauteous maid with downcast lookWas sitting where a stream was flowing,With elder bushes near it growing,She sat beneath an apple tree,And nought around her seem'd to see.Her lap was full of roses fair,Which in a wreath she twined with care.And, with them, leaves and blossoms blended:For whom was that sweet wreath intended?Thus sat she, modest and retired,Her bosom throbb'd, with hope inspired;Such deep forebodings fill'd her mind,No room for wishing could she find,And with the thoughts that o'er it flew,Perchance a sigh was mingled too.

íííí"But why should sorrow cloud thy brow?That, dearest love, which fills thee nowIs fraught with joy and ecstasy.Prepared in one alone for thee,That he within thine eye may findSolace when fortune proves unkind,And be newborn through many a kiss,That he receives with inward bliss;When'er he clasps thee to his breast.May he from all his toils find restWhen he in thy dear arms shall sink,May he new life and vigour drink:Fresh joys of youth shalt thou obtain,In merry jest rejoice again.With raillery and roguish spite,Thou now shalt tease him, now delight.Thus Love will nevermore grow old,Thus will the minstrel ne'er be cold!"

ííííWhile he thus lives, in secret bless'd,Above him in the clouds doth restAn oak-wreath, verdant and sublime,Placed on his brow in after-time;While they are banish'd to the slough,Who their great master disavow.

íííí1776.-----

ííííSONNETS.

íííí-----Lovingly I'll sing of love;Ever comes she from above.-----THE FRIENDLY MEETING.

ííííIN spreading mantle to my chin conceald,

ííííI trod the rocky path, so steep and grey,

ííííThen to the wintry plain I bent my wayUneasily, to flight my bosom steel'd.

ííííBut sudden was the newborn day reveal'd:

ííííA maiden came, in heavenly bright array,

ííííLike the fair creatures of the poet's layIn realms of song. My yearning heart was heal'd.

ííííYet turn'd I thence, till she had onward pass'd,

ííííWhile closer still the folds to draw I tried,

ííííAs though with heat self-kindled to grow warm;

ííííBut follow'd her. She stood. The die was cast!

ííííNo more within my mantle could I hide;

ííííI threw it off,--she lay within mine arm.

íííí1807-8.-----IN A WORD.

ííííTHUS to be chain'd for ever, can I bear?

ííííA very torment that, in truth, would be.

ííííThis very day my new resolve shall see.--I'll not go near the lately-worshipp'd Fair.

ííííYet what excuse, my heart, can I prepare

ííííIn such a case, for not consulting thee?

ííííBut courage! while our sorrows utter weIn tones where love, grief, gladness have a share.

ííííBut see! the minstrel's bidding to obey,

ííííIts melody pours forth the sounding lyre,

ííííYearning a sacrifice of love to bring.

ííííScarce wouldst thou think it--ready is the lay;

ííííWell, but what then? Methought in the first fire

ííííWe to her presence flew, that lay to sing.

íííí1807?.-----THE MAIDEN SPEAKS.

ííííHow grave thou loookest, loved one! wherefore so?

ííííThy marble image seems a type of thee;

ííííLike it, no sign of life thou giv'st to me;Compared with thee, the stone appears to glow.

ííííBehind his shield in ambush lurks the foe,

ííííThe friend's brow all-unruffled we should see.

ííííI seek thee, but thou seek'st away to flee;Fix'd as this sculptured figure, learn to grow!

ííííTell me, to which should I the preference pay?

ííííMust I from both with coldness meet alone?

ííííThe one is lifeless, thou with life art blest.

ííííIn short, no longer to throw words away,

ííííI'll fondy kiss and kiss and kiss this stone,

ííííTill thou dost tear me hence with envious breast.

íííí1807.-----GROWTH.

ííííO'ER field and plain, in childhood's artless days,

ííííThou sprang'st with me, on many a spring-morn fair.

íííí"For such a daughter, with what pleasing care,Would I, as father, happy dwellings raise!"

ííííAnd when thou on the world didst cast thy gaze,

ííííThy joy was then in household toils to share.

íííí"Why did I trust her, why she trust me e'er?For such a sister, how I Heaven should praise!"

ííííNothing can now the beauteous growth retard;

ííííLove's glowing flame within my breast is fann'd.

ííííShall I embrace her form, my grief to end?

ííííThee as a queen must I, alas, regard:

ííííSo high above me placed thou seem'st to stand;

ííííBefore a passing look I meekly bend.

íííí1807?.-----FOOD IN TRAVEL.

ííííIF to her eyes' bright lustre I were blind,

ííííNo longer would they serve my life to gild.

ííííThe will of destiny must be fulfilid,--This knowing, I withdrew with sadden'd mind.

ííííNo further happiness I now could find:

ííííThe former longings of my heart were still'd;

ííííI sought her looks alone, whereon to buildMy joy in life,--all else was left behind.

ííííWine's genial glow, the festal banquet gay,

ííííEase, sleep, and friends, all wonted pleasures glad

ííííI spurn'd, till little there remain'd to prove.

ííííNow calmly through the world I wend my way:

ííííThat which I crave may everywhere be had,

ííííWith me I bring the one thing needful--love.

íííí1807?.-----DEPARTURE.

ííííWITH many a thousand kiss not yet content,

ííííAt length with One kiss I was forced to go;

ííííAfter that bitter parting's depth of woe,I deem'd the shore from which my steps I bent,

ííííIts hills, streams, dwellings, mountains, as I went,

ííííA pledge of joy, till daylight ceased to glow;

ííííThen on my sight did blissful visions growIn the dim-lighted, distant firmament,

ííííAnd when at length the sea confined my gaze,

ííííMy ardent longing fill'd my heart once more;

ííííWhat I had lost, unwillingly I sought.

ííííThen Heaven appear'd to shed its kindly rays:

ííííMethought that all I had possess'd of yore

ííííRemain'd still mine--that I was reft of nought.

íííí1807?.-----THE LOVING ONE WRITES.

ííííTHE look that thy sweet eyes on mine impress

ííííThe pledge thy lips to mine convey,--the kiss,--

ííííHe who, like me, hath knowledge sure of this,Can he in aught beside find happiness?

ííííRemoved from thee, friend-sever'd, in distress,

ííííThese thoughts I vainly struggle to dismiss:

ííííThey still return to that one hour of bliss,The only one; then tears my grief confess.

ííííBut unawares the tear makes haste to dry:

ííííHe loves, methinks, e'en to these glades so still,--

ííííAnd shalt not thou to distant lands extend?

ííííReceive the murmurs of his loving sigh;

ííííMy only joy on earth is in thy will,

ííííThy kindly will tow'rd me; a token send!

íííí1807?.-----THE LOVING ONE ONCE MORE.

ííííWHY do I o'er my paper once more bend?

ííííAsk not too closely, dearest one, I pray

ííííFor, to speak truth, I've nothing now to say;Yet to thy hands at length 'twill come, dear friend.

ííííSince I can come not with it, what I send

ííííMy undivided heart shall now convey,

ííííWith all its joys, hopes, pleasures, pains, to-day:All this hath no beginning, hath no end.

ííííHenceforward I may ne'er to thee confide

ííííHow, far as thought, wish, fancy, will, can reach,

ííííMy faithful heart with thine is surely blended.

ííííThus stood I once enraptured by thy side,

ííííGazed on thee, and said nought. What need of speech?

ííííMy very being in itself was ended.

íííí1807?.-----SHE CANNOT END.

ííííWHEN unto thee I sent the page all white,

ííííInstead of first thereon inscribing aught,

ííííThe space thou doubtless filledst up in sport.And sent it me, to make my joy grow bright.

ííííAs soon as the blue cover met my sight,

ííííAs well becomes a woman, quick as thought

ííííI tore it open, leaving hidden nought,And read the well-known words of pure delight:

ííííMY ONLY BEING! DEAREST HEART! SWEET CHILD!

ííííHow kindly thou my yearning then didst still

ííííWith gentle words, enthralling me to thee.

ííííIn truth methought I read thy whispers mild

ííííWherewith thou lovingly my soul didst fill,

ííííE'en to myself for aye ennobling me.

íííí1807?.-----NEMESIS.

ííííWHEN through the nations stalks contagion wild,

ííííWe from them cautiously should steal away.

ííííE'en I have oft with ling'ring and delayShunn'd many an influence, not to be defil'd.

ííííAnd e'en though Amor oft my hours beguil'd,

ííííAt length with him preferr'd I not to play,

ííííAnd so, too, with the wretched sons of clay,When four and three-lined verses they compil'd.

ííííBut punishment pursues the scoffer straight,

ííííAs if by serpent-torch of furies led

ííííFrom bill to vale, from land to sea to fly.

ííííI hear the genie's laughter at my fate;

ííííYet do I find all power of thinking fled

ííííIn sonnet-rage and love's fierce ecstasy.

íííí1807-8.-----THE CHRISTMAS-BOX.

ííííTHIS box, mine own sweet darling, thou wilt find

ííííWith many a varied sweetmeat's form supplied;

ííííThe fruits are they of holy Christmas tide,But baked indeed, for children's use design'd.

ííííI'd fain, in speeches sweet with skill combin'd,

ííííPoetic sweetmeats for the feast provide;

ííííIn flaming letters written, was impress d

ííííGOOD FRIDAY. And on mine, be it confess'd,Is this year's ADVENT, as it passeth o'er.

íííí1807.-----THE DOUBTERS AND THE LOVERS.

ííííTHE DOUBTERS.

ííííYE love, and sonnets write! Fate's strange behest!

ííííThe heart, its hidden meaning to declare,

ííííMust seek for rhymes, uniting pair with pair:Learn, children, that the will is weak, at best.

ííííScarcely with freedom the o'erflowing breast

ííííAs yet can speak, and well may it beware;

ííííTempestuous passions sweep each chord that's there,Then once more sink to night and gentle rest.

ííííUp the steep path but step by step to roll?

ííííIt falls again, and ye ne'er cease to strive.

ííííTHE LOVERS.

ííííBut we are on the proper road alone!

ííííIf gladly is to thaw the frozen soul,

ííííThe fire of love must aye be kept alive.

íííí1807?.-----CHARADE.

ííííTwo words there 'are, both short, of beauty rare,

ííííWhose sounds our lips so often love to frame,

ííííBut which with clearness never can proclaimThe things whose own peculiar stamp they bear.

íííí'Tis well in days of age and youth so fair,

ííííOne on the other boldly to inflame;

ííííAnd if those words together link'd we name,A blissful rapture we discover there.

ííííBut now to give them pleasure do I seek,

ííííAnd in myself my happiness would find;

ííííI hope in silence, but I hope for this:

ííííGently, as loved one's names, those words to speak

ííííTo see them both within one image shrin'd,

ííííBoth in one being to embrace with bliss.

ííííThat as yet ye are unborn:For each sorrow and each tear

ííííUnproduced, and known to none;If your father cannot do it,

íííí1784.-----THE FOOL'S EPILOGUE.

ííííMANY good works I've done and ended,Ye take the praise--I'm not offended;For in the world, I've always thoughtEach thing its true position hath sought.When praised for foolish deeds am I,I set off laughing heartily;When blamed for doing something good,I take it in an easy mood.If some one stronger gives me hard blows,That it's a jest, I feign to suppose:But if 'tis one that's but my own like,I know the way such folks to strike.When Fortune smiles, I merry grow,And sing in dulci jubilo;When sinks her wheel, and tumbles me o'er,I think 'tis sure to rise once more.

ííííIn the sunshine of summer I ne'er lament,Because the winter it cannot prevent;And when the white snow-flakes fall around,I don my skates, and am off with a bound.Though I dissemble as I will,The sun for me will ne'er stand still;The old and wonted course is run,Until the whole of life is done;Each day the servant like the lord,In turns comes home, and goes abroad;If proud or humble the line they take,They all must eat, drink, sleep, and wake.So nothing ever vexes me;Act like the fool, and wise ye'll be!

íííí1767-9.-----EXPLANATION OF AN ANTIQUE GEM,

ííííWhose skill was past disputing,Who in his head a fancy took

ííííTHERE lived in the desert a holy man

ííííTo whom a goat-footed Faun one dayPaid a visit, and thus began

ííííTo his surprise: "I entreat thee to prayThat grace to me and my friends may be given,That we may be able to mount to Heaven,For great is our thirst for heav'nly bliss."The holy man made answer to this:"Much danger is lurking in thy petition,Nor will it be easy to gain admission;Thou dost not come with an angel's salute;For I see thou wearest a cloven foot."The wild man paused, and then answer'd he:"What doth my goat's foot matter to thee?Full many I've known into heaven to passStraight and with ease, with the head of an ass!"

íííí1776.*-----THE DILETTANTE AND THE CRITIC.

ííííA BOY a pigeon once possess'd,In gay and brilliant plumage dress'd;He loved it well, and in boyish sportIts food to take from his mouth he taught,And in his pigeon he took such pride,That his joy to others he needs must confide.

ííííAn aged fox near the place chanc'd to dwell,Talkative, clever, and learned as well;The boy his society used to prize,Hearing with pleasure his wonders and lies.

íííí"My friend the fox my pigeon must seeHe ran, and stretch'd 'mongst the bushes lay he"Look, fox, at my pigeon, my pigeon so fair!His equal I'm sure thou hast look'd upon ne'er!"

íííí"Let's see!"--The boy gave it.--"'Tis really not bad;And yet, it is far from complete, I must add.The feathers, for, instance, how short! 'Tis absurd!"So he set to work straightway to pluck the poor bird.

ííííThe boy screamed.--"Thou must now stronger pinions supply,Or else 'twill be ugly, unable to fly."--Soon 'twas stripp'd--oh, the villain!--and torn all to pieces.The boy was heart-broken,--and so my tale ceases.

ííííHe who sees in the boy shadow'd forth his own case,Should be on his guard 'gainst the fox's whole race.

íííí1776.*-----THE WRANGLER.

ííííONE day a shameless and impudent wightWent into a shop full of steel wares bright,Arranged with art upon ev'ry shelf.He fancied they were all meant for himself;And so, while the patient owner stood by,The shining goods needs must handle and try,And valued,--for how should a fool better know?--The bad things high, and the good ones low,And all with an easy self-satisfied face;Then, having bought nothing, he left the place.

ííííThe tradesman now felt sorely vex'd,So when the fellow went there next,A lock of steel made quite red hot.The other cried upon the spot:"Such wares as these, who'd ever buy?the steel is tarnish'd shamefully,"--Then pull'd it, like a fool about,But soon set up a piteous shout."Pray what's the matter?" the shopman spoke;The other scream'd: "Faith, a very cool joke!"

íííí1815.*-----THE YELPERS.

ííííOUR rides in all directions bend,

ííííFor business or for pleasure,Yet yelpings on our steps attend,

ííííAnd barkings without measure.The dog that in our stable dwells,

ííííAfter our heels is striding,And all the while his noisy yells

ííííBut show that we are riding.

íííí1815.*-----THE STORK'S VOCATION.

ííííTHE stork who worms and frogs devours

ííííThat in our ponds reside,Why should he dwell on high church-towers,

ííííWith which he's not allied?

ííííIncessantly he chatters there,

ííííAnd gives our ears no rest;But neither old nor young can dare

ííííTo drive him from his nest.

ííííI humbly ask it,--how can he

ííííGive of his title proof,Save by his happy tendency

ííííTo soil the church's roof?-----CELEBRITY.

íííí[A satire on his own Sorrows of Werther.]

ííííON bridges small and bridges greatStands Nepomucks in ev'ry state,Of bronze, wood, painted, or of stone,Some small as dolls, some giants grown;Each passer must worship before Nepomuck,Who to die on a bridge chanced to have the ill luck,When once a man with head and earsA saint in people's eyes appears,Or has been sentenced piteouslyBeneath the hangman's hand to die,He's as a noted person prized,In portrait is immortalized.Engravings, woodcuts, are supplied,And through the world spread far and wide.Upon them all is seen his name,And ev'ry one admits his claim;Even the image of the LordIs not with greater zeal ador'd.Strange fancy of the human race!Half sinner frail, half child of graceWe see HERR WERTHER of the storyIn all the pomp of woodcut glory.His worth is first made duly known,By having his sad features shownAt ev'ry fair the country round;In ev'ry alehouse too they're found.His stick is pointed by each dunce"The ball would reach his brain at once!"And each says, o'er his beer and bread:"Thank Heav'n that 'tis not we are dead!"

íííí1815.*-----PLAYING AT PRIESTS.

ííííWITHIN a town where parityAccording to old form we see,--That is to say, where CatholicAnd Protestant no quarrels pick,And where, as in his father's day,Each worships God in his own way,We Luth'ran children used to dwell,By songs and sermons taught as well.The Catholic clingclang in truthSounded more pleasing to our youth,For all that we encounter'd there,To us seem'd varied, joyous, fair.As children, monkeys, and mankindTo ape each other are inclin'd,We soon, the time to while away,A game at priests resolved to play.Their aprons all our sisters lentFor copes, which gave us great content;And handkerchiefs, embroider'd o'er,Instead of stoles we also wore;Gold paper, whereon beasts were traced,The bishop's brow as mitre graced.

ííííThrough house and garden thus in stateWe strutted early, strutted late,Repeating with all proper unction,Incessantly each holy function.The best was wanting to the game;

ííííWe knew that a sonorous ring

ííííWas here a most important thing;But Fortune to our rescue came,For on the ground a halter lay;

ííííWe were delighted, and at once

ííííMade it a bellrope for the nonce,And kept it moving all the day;

ííííIn turns each sister and each brother

ííííActed as sexton to another;All help'd to swell the joyous throng;

ííííThe whole proceeded swimmingly,

ííííAnd since no actual bell had we,We all in chorus sang, Ding dong!

íííí*      *      *      *      *

ííííOur guileless child's-sport long was hush'd

ííííIn memory's tomb, like some old lay;And yet across my mind it rush'd

ííííWith pristine force the other day.The New-Poetic CatholicsIn ev'ry point its aptness fix!

íííí1815.*-----SONGS.

ííííSONGS are like painted window-panes!In darkness wrapp'd the church remains,If from the market-place we view it;Thus sees the ignoramus through it.No wonder that he deems it tame,--And all his life 'twill be the same.

íííí1827.*-----THE DEATH OF THE FLY.

ííííWITH eagerness he drinks the treach'rous potion,

ííííNor stops to rest, by the first taste misled;Sweet is the draught, but soon all power of motion

ííííHe finds has from his tender members fled;No longer has he strength to plume his wing,No longer strength to raise his head, poor thing!E'en in enjoyment's hour his life he loses,His little foot to bear his weight refuses;So on he sips, and ere his draught is o'er,Death veils his thousand eyes for evermore.

ííííOft shallow is its sluggish flood;Then, when thy fields thou tendest well,

ííííThe prudent fisher upward goes;Round reef and rock ice casts its chains,

ííííAt his flat plate, all demurely,Ye with envy must have granted:

ííííOn one foot, as usual, cradled,From the flasks his fish-refection

ííííWith his bill and long neck ladled.

ííííAs they went, extoll'd the fishes,Each one scoffing at his brother

ííííNo longer dared to croak or spring;But promised, being half asleep,If suffer'd to the air to creep,

ííííTo the grave one day from a house they bore

ííííA maiden;To the window the citizens went to explore;In splendour they lived, and with wealth as of yore

ííííTheir banquets were laden.Then thought they: "The maid to the tomb is now borne;We too from our dwellings ere long must be torn,And he that is left our departure to mourn,

ííííTo our riches will be the successor,

ííííFor some one must be their possessor.

íííí1827.*-----THREATENING SIGNS.

ííííIF Venus in the evening skyIs seen in radiant majesty,If rod-like comets, red as blood,Are 'mongst the constellations view'd,Out springs the Ignoramus, yelling:"The star's exactly o'er my dwelling!What woeful prospect, ah, for me!Then calls his neighbour mournfully:"Behold that awful sign of evil,Portending woe to me, poor devil!My mother's asthma ne'er will leave her,My child is sick with wind and fever;I dread the illness of my wife,A week has pass'd, devoid of strife,--And other things have reach'd my ear;The Judgment Day has come, I fear!"

ííííHis neighbour answered: "Friend, you're right!Matters look very had to-night.Let's go a street or two, though, hence,And gaze upon the stars from thence."--No change appears in either case.Let each remain then in his place,And wisely do the best he can,Patient as any other man.

ííííThe man who gratis will his goods supplyWill never find a lack of folks to buy!

íííí1820.-----THE MOUNTAIN VILLAGE.

íííí"THE mountain village was destroy'd;But see how soon is fill'd the void!Shingles and boards, as by magic arise,The babe in his cradle and swaddling-clothes lies;How blest to trust to God's protection!"

ííííBehold a wooden new erection,So that, if sparks and wind but choose,God's self at such a game must lose!

íííí1821.*-----SYMBOLS.

ííííPALM Sunday at the Vatican

ííííThey celebrate with palms;With reverence bows each holy man,

ííííAnd chaunts the ancient psalms.Those very psalms are also sung

ííííWith olive boughs in hand,While holly, mountain wilds among,

ííííIn place of palms must stand:In fine, one seeks some twig that's green,

ííííAnd takes a willow rod,So that the pious man may e'en

ííííIn small things praise his God.

ííííAnd if ye have observed it well,

ííííTo gain what's fit ye're able,If ye in faith can but excel;

ííííI.

íííí"Incense is hut a tribute for the gods,--To mortals 'tis but poison."

ííííTHE smoke that from thine altar blows,

ííííCan it the gods offend?For I observe thou hold'st thy nose--

ííííPray what does this portend?Mankind deem incense to excel

ííííEach other earthly thing,So he that cannot bear its smell,

ííííNo incense e'er should bring.

ííííWith unmoved face by thee at least

ííííTo dolls is homage given;If not obstructed by the priest,

ííííThe scent mounts up to heaven.

íííí1827.*

ííííII

ííííCONFLICT OF WIT AND BEAUTY.

ííííSIR Wit, who is so much esteem'd,

ííííAnd who is worthy of all honour,Saw Beauty his superior deem'd

ííííBy folks who loved to gaze upon her;At this he was most sorely vex'd.

ííííThen came Sir Breath (long known as fit

ííííTo represent the cause of wit),

ííííBeginning, rudely, I admit,To treat the lady with a text.To this she hearken'd not at all,But hasten'd to his principal:"None are so wise, they say, as you,--Is not the world enough for two?

ííííIf you are obstinate, good-bye!If wise, to love me you will try,For be assured the world can ne'erGive birth to a more handsome pair."

íííí1827.*

íííí=====

ííííFAIR daughters were by Beauty rear'd,

ííííWit had but dull sons for his lot;So for a season it appear'd

ííííBeauty was constant, Wit was not.But Wit's a native of the soil,

ííííSo he return'd, work'd, strove amain,And found--sweet guerdon for his toil!--

ííííBeauty to quicken him again.

íííí1827.*

ííííIII.

ííííRAIN AND RAINBOW.

ííííDURING a heavy storm it chancedThat from his room a cockney glancedAt the fierce tempest as it broke,While to his neighbour thus he spoke:"The thunder has our awe inspired,Our barns by lightning have been fired,--Our sins to punish, I suppose;But in return, to soothe our woes,See how the rain in torrents fell,Making the harvest promise well!But is't a rainbow that I spyExtending o'er the dark-grey sky?With it I'm sure we may dispense,The colour'd cheat! The vain pretence!"Dame Iris straightway thus replied:"Dost dare my beauty to deride?In realms of space God station'd meA type of better worlds to beTo eyes that from life's sorrows roveIn cheerful hope to Heav'n above,And, through the mists that hover hereGod and his precepts blest revere.Do thou, then, grovel like the swine,And to the ground thy snout confine,But suffer the enlighten'd eyeTo feast upon my majesty."

íííí1827.*

ííííVALEDICTION.

ííííI ONCE was fond of fools,

ííííAnd bid them come each day;Then each one brought his tools

ííííThe carpenter to play;The roof to strip first choosing,

ííííAnother to supply,The wood as trestles using,

ííííTo move it by-and-by,While here and there they ran,

ííííAnd knock'd against each other;To fret I soon began,

ííííMy anger could not smother,So cried, "Get out, ye fools!"

ííííAt this they were offendedThen each one took his tools,

ííííAnd so our friendship ended.

ííííSince that, I've wiser been,

ííííAnd sit beside my door;When one of them is seen,

ííííI cry, "Appear no more!""Hence, stupid knave!" I bellow:

ííííAt this he's angry too:"You impudent old fellow!

ííííAnd pray, sir, who are you?Along the streets we riot,

ííííAnd revel at the fair;But yet we're pretty quiet,

ííííAnd folks revile us ne'er.Don't call us names, then, please!"--At length I meet with ease,

ííííFor now they leave my door--'Tis better than before!

íííí1827.*-----THE COUNTRY SCHOOLMASTER.

ííííI.

ííííA MASTER of a country schoolJump'd up one day from off his stool,Inspired with firm resolve to tryTo gain the best society;So to the nearest baths he walk'd,And into the saloon he stalk'd.He felt quite. startled at the door,Ne'er having seen the like before.To the first stranger made he nowA very low and graceful bow,But quite forgot to bear in mindThat people also stood behind;His left-hand neighbor's paunch he struckA grievous blow, by great ill luck;Pardon for this he first entreated,And then in haste his bow repeated.His right hand neighbor next he hit,And begg'd him, too, to pardon it;But on his granting his petition,Another was in like condition;These compliments he paid to all,Behind, before, across the hall;At length one who could stand no more,Show'd him impatiently the door.

íííí*      *      *      *

ííííMay many, pond'ring on their crimes,A moral draw from this betimes!

ííííII.

ííííAs he proceeded on his wayHe thought, "I was too weak to-day;To bow I'll ne'er again be seen;For goats will swallow what is green."Across the fields he now must speed,Not over stumps and stones, indeed,But over meads and cornfields sweet,Trampling down all with clumsy feet.A farmer met him by-and-by,And didn't ask him: how? or why?But with his fist saluted him.

íííí"I feel new life in every limb!"Our traveller cried in ecstasy."Who art thou who thus gladden'st me?May Heaven such blessings ever send!Ne'er may I want a jovial friend!"

íííí1808.*-----THE LEGEND OF THE HORSESHOE.

ííííWHAT time our Lord still walk'd the earth,Unknown, despised, of humble birth,And on Him many a youth attended(His words they seldom comprehended),It ever seem'd to Him most meetTo hold His court in open street,As under heaven's broad canopyOne speaks with greater liberty.The teachings of His blessed wordFrom out His holy mouth were heard;Each market to a fane turn'd HeWith parable and simile.

ííííOne day, as tow'rd a town He roved,In peace of mind with those He loved,Upon the path a something gleam'd;A broken horseshoe 'twas, it seem'd.So to St. Peter thus He spake:"That piece of iron prythee take!"St. Peter's thoughts had gone astray,--He had been musing on his wayRespecting the world's government,A dream that always gives content,For in the head 'tis check'd by nought;This ever was his dearest thought,For him this prize was far too meanHad it a crown and sceptre been!But, surely, 'twasn't worth the troubleFor half a horseshoe to bend double!And so he turn'd away his head,As if he heard not what was said,

ííííThe Lord, forbearing tow'rd all men,Himself pick'd up the horseshoe then(He ne'er again like this stoop'd down).And when at length they reach'd the town,Before a smithy He remain'd,And there a penny for 't obtain'd.As they the market-place went by,Some beauteous cherries caught His eye:Accordingly He bought as manyAs could be purchased for a penny,And then, as oft His wont had been,Placed them within His sleeve unseen.

ííííThey went out by another gate,O'er plains and fields proceeding straight,No house or tree was near the spot,The sun was bright, the day was hot;In short, the weather being such,A draught of water was worth much.The Lord walk'd on before them all,And let, unseen, a cherry fall.St. Peter rush'd to seize it hold,As though an apple 'twere of gold;His palate much approv'd the berry;The Lord ere long another cherryOnce more let fall upon the plain;St. Peter forthwith stoop'd again.The Lord kept making him thus bendTo pick up cherries without end.For a long time the thing went on;The Lord then said, in cheerful tone:"Had'st thou but moved when thou wert bid,Thou of this trouble had'st been rid;The man who small things scorns, will next,By things still smaller be perplex'd."

íííí1797.-----A SYMBOL.

íííí(This fine poem is given by Goethe amongst a small collection ofwhat he calls Loge (Lodge), meaning thereby Masonic pieces.)

ííííTHE mason's trade                Observe them well,

ííííResembles life,                  And watch them revealing

ííííWith all its strife,--           How solemn feelingIs like the stir made            And wonderment swell

ííííBy man on earth's face.         The hearts of the brave.

ííííThough weal and woe               The voice of the blest,

ííííThe future may hide,              And of spirits on high

ííííUnterrified                       Seems loudly to cry:We onward go                      "To do what is best,

ííííIn ne'er changing race.           Unceasing endeavour!

ííííA veil of dread                   "In silence eterne

ííííHangs heavier still.              Here chaplets are twin'd,

ííííDeep slumbers fill                That each noble mindThe stars over-head,              Its guerdon may earn.--

ííííAnd the foot-trodden grave.       Then hope ye for ever!"

ííííART.

íííí-----Artist, fashion! talk not long!Be a breath thine only song!-----THE DROPS OF NECTAR.

ííííWHEN Minerva, to give pleasureTo Prometheus, her well-loved one,Brought a brimming bowl of nectarFrom the glorious realms of heavenAs a blessing for his creatures,And to pour into their bosomsImpulses for arts ennobling,She with rapid footstep hasten'd,Fearing Jupiter might see her,And the golden goblet trembled,And there fell a few drops from itOn the verdant plain beneath her.Then the busy bees flew thitherStraightway, eagerly to drink them,And the butterfly came quicklyThat he, too, might find a drop there;Even the misshapen spiderThither crawl'd and suck'd with vigour.

ííííTo a happy end they tasted,They, and other gentle insects!For with mortals now divide theyArt─that noblest gift of all.

íííí1789.*-----THE WANDERER.

íííí[Published in the Gottingen Musen Almanach, having been written"to express his feelings and caprices" after his separation fromFrederica.]

ííííWANDERER.

ííííYOUNG woman, may God bless thee,Thee, and the sucking infantUpon thy breast!Let me, 'gainst this rocky wall,Neath the elm-tree's shadow,Lay aside my burden,Near thee take my rest.

ííííWOMAN.

ííííWhat vocation leads thee,While the day is burning,Up this dusty path?Bring'st thou goods from out the townRound the country?Smil'st thou, stranger,At my question?

ííííWANDERER.

ííííFrom the town no goods I bring.Cool is now the evening;Show to me the fountain'Whence thou drinkest,Woman young and kind!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííUp the rocky pathway mount;Go thou first! Across the thicketLeads the pathway tow'rd the cottageThat I live in,To the fountainWhence I drink.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííSigns of man's arranging handSee I 'mid the trees!Not by thee these stones were join'd,Nature, who so freely scatterest!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííUp, still up!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííLo, a mossy architrave is here!I discern thee, fashioning spirit!On the stone thou hast impress'd thy seal.

ííííWOMAN.

ííííOnward, stranger!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííOver an inscription am I treading!'Tis effaced!Ye are seen no longer,Words so deeply graven,Who your master's true devotionShould have shown to thousand grandsons!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííAt these stones, whyStart'st thou, stranger?Many stones are lying yonderRound my cottage.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííYonder?

ííííWOMAN.

ííííThrough the thicket,Turning to the left,Here!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííYe Muses and ye Graces!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííThis, then, is my cottage.

ííííWANDERER.

íííí'Tis a ruin'd temple! *

ííííWOMAN.

ííííJust below it, see,Springs the fountainWhence I drink.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííThou dost hoverO'er thy grave, all glowing,Genius! while upon theeHath thy master-pieceFallen crumbling,Thou Immortal One!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííStay, a cup I'll fetch theeWhence to drink.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííIvy circles thy slenderForm so graceful and godlike.How ye rise on highFrom the ruins,Column-pairAnd thou, their lonely sister yonder,--How thou,Dusky moss upon thy sacred head,--Lookest down in mournful majestyOn thy brethren's figuresLying scatter'dAt thy feet!In the shadow of the brambleEarth and rubbish veil them,Lofty grass is waving o'er themIs it thus thou, Nature, prizestThy great masterpiece's masterpiece?Carelessly destroyest thouThine own sanctuary,Sowing thistles there?

ííííWOMAN.

ííííHow the infant sleeps!Wilt thou rest thee in the cottage,Stranger? Wouldst thou ratherIn the open air still linger?Now 'tis cool! take thou the childWhile I go and draw some water.Sleep on, darling! sleep!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííSweet is thy repose!How, with heaven-born health imbued,Peacefully he slumbers!Oh thou, born among the ruinsSpread by great antiquity,On thee rest her spirit!He whom it encirclesWill, in godlike consciousness,Ev'ry day enjoy.Full, of germ, unfold,As the smiling springtime'sFairest charm,Outshining all thy fellows!And when the blossom's husk is faded,May the full fruit shoot forthFrom out thy breast,And ripen in the sunshine!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííGod bless him!--Is he sleeping still?To the fresh draught I nought can add,Saving a crust of bread for thee to eat.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííI thank thee well.How fair the verdure all around!How green!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííMy husband soonWill home returnFrom labour. Tarry, tarry, man,And with us eat our evening meal.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííIs't here ye dwell?

ííííWOMAN.

ííííYonder, within those walls we live.My father 'twas who built the cottageOf tiles and stones from out the ruins.'Tis here we dwell.He gave me to a husbandman,And in our arms expired.--Hast thou been sleeping, dearest heartHow lively, and how full of play!Sweet rogue!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííNature, thou ever budding one,Thou formest each for life's enjoyments,And, like a mother, all thy children dear,Blessest with that sweet heritage,--a homeThe swallow builds the cornice round,Unconscious of the beautiesShe plasters up.The caterpillar spins around the bough,To make her brood a winter house;And thou dost patch, between antiquity'sMost glorious relics,For thy mean use,Oh man, a humble cot,--Enjoyest e'en mid tombs!--Farewell, thou happy woman!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííThou wilt not stay, then?

ííííWANDERER.

ííííMay God preserve thee,And bless thy boy!

ííííWOMAN.

ííííA happy journey!

ííííWANDERER.

ííííWhither conducts the pathAcross yon hill?

ííííWOMAN.

ííííTo Cuma.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííHow far from hence?

ííííWOMAN.

íííí'Tis full three miles.

ííííWANDERER.

ííííFarewell!Oh Nature, guide me on my way!The wandering stranger guide,Who o'er the tombsOf holy bygone timesIs passing,To a kind sheltering place,From North winds safe,And where a poplar groveShuts out the noontide ray!And when I comeHome to my cotAt evening,Illumined by the setting sun,Let me embrace a wife like this,Her infant in her arms!

íííí1772.* Compare with the beautiful description contained in thesubsequent lines, an account of a ruined temple of Ceres, givenby Chamberlayne in his Pharonnida (published in 1659)

íííí".... With mournful majesiyA heap of solitary ruins lie,Half sepulchred in dust, the bankrupt heirTo prodigal antiquity...."-----LOVE AS A LANDSCAPE PAINTER.

ííííON a rocky peak once sat I early,Gazing on the mist with eyes unmoving;Stretch'd out like a pall of greyish texture,All things round, and all above it cover'd.

ííííSuddenly a boy appear'd beside me,Saying "Friend, what meanest thou by gazingOn the vacant pall with such composure?Hast thou lost for evermore all pleasureBoth in painting cunningly, and forming?"On the child I gazed, and thought in secret:"Would the boy pretend to be a master?"

íííí"Wouldst thou be for ever dull and idle,"Said the boy, "no wisdom thou'lt attain to;See, I'll straightway paint for thee a figure,--How to paint a beauteous figure, show thee."

ííííAnd he then extended his fore-finger,--(Ruddy was it as a youthful rosebud)Tow'rd the broad and far outstretching carpet,And began to draw there with his finger.

ííííFirst on high a radiant sun he painted,Which upon mine eyes with splendour glisten'd,And he made the clouds with golden border,Through the clouds he let the sunbeams enter;Painted then the soft and feathery summitsOf the fresh and quicken'd trees, behind themOne by one with freedom drew the mountains;Underneath he left no lack of water,But the river painted so like Nature,That it seem'd to glitter in the sunbeams,That it seem'd against its banks to murmur.

ííííAh, there blossom'd flowers beside the river,And bright colours gleam'd upon the meadow,Gold, and green, and purple, and enamell'd,All like carbuncles and emeralds seeming!

ííííBright and clear he added then the heavens,And the blue-tinged mountains far and farther,So that I, as though newborn, enrapturedGazed on, now the painter, now the picture.

ííííThen spake he: "Although I have convinced theeThat this art I understand full surely,Yet the hardest still is left to show thee."

ííííThereupon he traced, with pointed finger,And with anxious care, upon the forest,At the utmost verge, where the strong sunbeamsFrom the shining ground appear'd reflected,

ííííTraced the figure of a lovely maiden,Fair in form, and clad in graceful fashion,Fresh the cheeks beneath her brown locks' ambush,And the cheeks possess'd the selfsame colourAs the finger that had served to paint them.

íííí"Oh thou boy!" exclaim'd I then, "what masterIn his school received thee as his pupil,Teaching thee so truthfully and quicklyWisely to begin, and well to finish?"

ííííWhilst I still was speaking, lo, a zephyrSoftly rose, and set the tree-tops moving,Curling all the wavelets on the river,And the perfect maiden's veil, too, fill'd it,And to make my wonderment still greater,Soon the maiden set her foot in motion.On she came, approaching tow'rd the stationWhere still sat I with my arch instructor.

ííííAs now all, yes, all thus moved together,--Flowers, river, trees, the veil,--all moving,--And the gentle foot of that most fair one,Can ye think that on my rock I linger'd,Like a rock, as though fast-chain'd and silent?

íííí1788.-----

ííííGOD, SOUL, AND WORLD.

íííí-----RHYMED DISTICHS.

íííí[The Distichs, of which these are given as a specimen, are aboutforty in number.]

ííííWHO trusts in God,Fears not His rod.-----THIS truth may be by all believed:Whom God deceives, is well deceived.-----HOW? when? and where?--No answer comes from high;Thou wait'st for the Because, and yet thou ask'st not Why?-----IF the whole is ever to gladden thee,That whole in the smallest thing thou must see.-----WATER its living strength first shows,When obstacles its course oppose.-----TRANSPARENT appears the radiant air,Though steel and stone in its breast it may bear;At length they'll meet with fiery power,And metal and stones on the earth will shower.------WHATE'ER a living flame may surround,No longer is shapeless, or earthly bound.'Tis now invisible, flies from earth,And hastens on high to the place of its birth.

íííí1815.*------PROCEMION.

ííííIN His blest name, who was His own creation,Who from all time makes making his vocation;The name of Him who makes our faith so bright,Love, confidence, activity, and might;In that One's name, who, named though oft He be,Unknown is ever in Reality:As far as ear can reach, or eyesight dim,Thou findest but the known resembling Him;How high so'er thy fiery spirit hovers,Its simile and type it straight discoversOnward thou'rt drawn, with feelings light and gay,Where'er thou goest, smiling is the way;No more thou numbrest, reckonest no time,Each step is infinite, each step sublime.

íííí1816.-----WHAT God would outwardly alone control,And on his finger whirl the mighty Whole?He loves the inner world to move, to viewNature in Him, Himself in Nature too,So that what in Him works, and is, and lives,The measure of His strength, His spirit gives.

íííí1816.-----WITHIN us all a universe doth dwell;And hence each people's usage laudable,That ev'ry one the Best that meets his eyesAs God, yea e'en his God, doth recognise;To Him both earth and heaven surrenders he,Fears Him, and loves Him too, if that may be.

íííí1816.-----THE METAMORPHOSIS OF PLANTS.

ííííTHOU art confused, my beloved, at, seeing the thousandfold union

ííííShown in this flowery troop, over the garden dispers'd;any a name dost thou hear assign'd; one after another

ííííFalls on thy list'ning ear, with a barbarian sound.None resembleth another, yet all their forms have a likeness;

ííííTherefore, a mystical law is by the chorus proclaim'd;Yes, a sacred enigma! Oh, dearest friend, could I only

ííííHappily teach thee the word, which may the mystery solve!Closely observe how the plant, by little and little progressing,

ííííStep by step guided on, changeth to blossom and fruit!First from the seed it unravels itself, as soon as the silent

ííííFruit-bearing womb of the earth kindly allows Its escape,And to the charms of the light, the holy, the ever-in-motion,

ííííTrusteth the delicate leaves, feebly beginning to shoot.Simply slumber'd the force in the seed; a germ of the future,

ííííPeacefully lock'd in itself, 'neath the integument lay,Leaf and root, and bud, still void of colour, and shapeless;

ííííThus doth the kernel, while dry, cover that motionless life.Upward then strives it to swell, in gentle moisture confiding,

ííííAnd, from the night where it dwelt, straightway ascendeth to light.Yet still simple remaineth its figure, when first it appeareth;

ííííAnd 'tis a token like this, points out the child 'mid the plants.Soon a shoot, succeeding it, riseth on high, and reneweth,

ííííPiling-up node upon node, ever the primitive form;Yet not ever alike: for the following leaf, as thou seest,

ííííEver produceth itself, fashioned in manifold ways.Longer, more indented, in points and in parts more divided,

ííííWhich. all-deform'd until now, slept in the organ below,So at length it attaineth the noble and destined perfection,

ííííWhich, in full many a tribe, fills thee with wondering awe.Many ribb'd and tooth'd, on a surface juicy and swelling,

ííííFree and unending the shoot seemeth in fullness to be;Yet here Nature restraineth, with powerful hands, the formation,

ííííAnd to a perfecter end, guideth with softness its growth,Less abundantly yielding the sap, contracting the vessels,

ííííSo that the figure ere long gentler effects doth disclose.Soon and in silence is check'd the growth of the vigorous branches,

ííííAnd the rib of the stalk fuller becometh in form.Leafless, however, and quick the tenderer stem then up-springeth,

ííííAnd a miraculous sight doth the observer enchant.Ranged in a circle, in numbers that now are small, and now countless,

ííííGather the smaller-sized leaves, close by the side of their like.Round the axis compress'd the sheltering calyx unfoldeth,

ííííAnd, as the perfectest type, brilliant-hued coronals forms.Thus doth Nature bloom, in glory still nobler and fuller,

ííííShowing, in order arranged, member on member uprear'd.Wonderment fresh dost thou feel, as soon as the stem rears the flower

ííííOver the scaffolding frail of the alternating leaves.But this glory is only the new creation's foreteller,

ííííYes, the leaf with its hues feeleth the hand all divine,And on a sudden contracteth itself; the tenderest figures

ííííTwofold as yet, hasten on, destined to blend into one.Lovingly now the beauteous pairs are standing together,

ííííGather'd in countless array, there where the altar is raised.Hymen hovereth o'er them, and scents delicious and mighty

ííííStream forth their fragrance so sweet, all things enliv'ning around.Presently, parcell'd out, unnumber'd germs are seen swelling,

ííííSweetly conceald in the womb, where is made perfect the fruit.Here doth Nature close the ring of her forces eternal;

ííííYet doth a new one, at once, cling to the one gone before,So that the chain be prolonged for ever through all generations,

ííííAnd that the whole may have life, e'en as enjoy'd by each part.Now, my beloved one, turn thy gaze on the many-hued thousands

ííííWhich, confusing no more, gladden the mind as they wave.Every plant unto thee proclaimeth the laws everlasting,

ííííEvery flowered speaks louder and louder to thee;But if thou here canst decipher the mystic words of the goddess,

ííííEverywhere will they be seen, e'en though the features are changed.Creeping insects may linger, the eager butterfly hasten,--

ííííPlastic and forming, may man change e'en the figure decreed!Oh, then, bethink thee, as well, how out of the germ of acquaintance,

ííííKindly intercourse sprang, slowly unfolding its leaves;Soon how friendship with might unveil'd itself in our bosoms,

ííííAnd how Amor, at length, brought forth blossom and fruitThink of the manifold ways wherein Nature hath lent to our feelings,

ííííSilently giving them birth, either the first or the last!Yes, and rejoice in the present day! For love that is holy

ííííSeeketh the noblest of fruits,--that where the thoughts are the same,Where the opinions agree,--that the pair may, in rapt contemplation,

ííííLovingly blend into one,--find the more excellent world.

íííí1797.-----

ííííPROVERBS.

íííí-----'TIS easier far a wreath to bind,Than a good owner fort to find.-----I KILL'D a thousand flies overnight,Yet was waken'd by one, as soon as twas light.-----To the mother I give;For the daughter I live.-----A BREACH is every day,

ííííBy many a mortal storm'd;Let them fall in the gaps as they may,

ííííYet a heap of dead is ne'er form'd.-----WHAT harm has thy poor mirror done, alas?Look not so ugly, prythee, in the glass!

íííí1815.*-----TAME XENIA.

ííííTHE Epigrams bearing the title of XENIA were written by Goetheand Schiller together, having been first occasioned by someviolent attacks made on them by some insignificant writers. Theyare extremely numerous, but scarcely any of them could betranslated into English. Those here given are merely presented asa specimen.

ííííGOD gave to mortals birth,

ííííIn his own image too;Then came Himself to earth,

ííííA mortal kind and true.

íííí1821.*-----BARBARIANS oft endeavour

ííííGods for themselves to makeBut they're more hideous ever

ííííThan dragon or than snake.

íííí1821.*-----WHAT shall I teach thee, the very first thing?--Fain would I learn o'er my shadow to spring!

íííí1827.*-----"WHAT is science, rightly known?'Tis the strength of life alone.Life canst thou engender never,Life must be life's parent ever.

íííí1827.*-----It matters not, I ween,

ííííWhere worms our friends consume,Beneath the turf so green,

ííííOr 'neath a marble tomb.Remember, ye who live,

ííííThough frowns the fleeting day,That to your friends ye give

ííííWhat never will decay.

íííí1827.*-----

ííííRELIGION AND CHURCH.

íííí-----THOUGHTS ON JESUS CHRIST'S DESCENT INTO HELL.

íííí[THE remarkable Poem of which this is a literal but faintrepresentation, was written when Goethe was only sixteen yearsold. It derives additional interest from the fact of its beingthe very earliest piece of his that is preserved. The few otherpieces included by Goethe under the title of Religion and Churchare polemical, and devoid of interest to the English reader.]

ííííWHAT wondrous noise is heard around!Through heaven exulting voices sound,

ííííA mighty army marches onBy thousand millions follow'd, lo,To yon dark place makes haste to go

ííííGod's Son, descending from His throne!He goes--the tempests round Him break,

ííííAs Judge and Hero cometh He;He goes--the constellations quake,

ííííThe sun, the world quake fearfully.

ííííI see Him in His victor-car,On fiery axles borne afar,

ííííWho on the cross for us expired.The triumph to yon realms He shows,--Remote from earth, where star ne'er glows,

ííííThe triumph He for us acquired.He cometh, Hell to extirpate,

ííííWhom He, by dying, wellnigh kill'd;He shall pronounce her fearful fate

ííííHark! now the curse is straight fulfill'd.

ííííHell sees the victor come at last,She feels that now her reign is past,

ííííShe quakes and fears to meet His sight;She knows His thunders' terrors dread,In vain she seeks to hide her head,

ííííAttempts to fly, but vain is flight;Vainly she hastes to 'scape pursuit

ííííAnd to avoid her Judge's eye;The Lord's fierce wrath restrains her foot

ííííLike brazen chains,--she cannot fly.

ííííHere lies the Dragon, trampled down,He lies, and feels God's angry frown,

ííííHe feels, and grinneth hideously;He feels Hell's speechless agonies,A thousand times he howls and sighs:

íííí"Oh, burning flames! quick, swallow me!"There lies he in the fiery waves,

ííííBy torments rack'd and pangs infernal,Instant annihilation craves,

ííííAnd hears, those pangs will be eternal.

ííííThose mighty squadrons, too, are here,The partners of his cursed career,

ííííYet far less bad than he were they.Here lies the countless throng combined,In black and fearful crowds entwined,

ííííWhile round him fiery tempests play;He sees how they the Judge avoid,

ííííHe sees the storm upon them feed,Yet is not at the sight o'erjoy'd,

ííííBecause his pangs e'en theirs exceed.

ííííThe Son of Man in triumph passesDown to Hell's wild and black morasses,

ííííAnd there unfolds His majesty.Hell cannot bear the bright array,For, since her first created day.

ííííDarkness alone e'er govern'd she.She lay remote from ev'ry light

ííííWith torments fill'd in Chaos here;God turn'd for ever from her sight

ííííHis radiant features' glory clear.

ííííWithin the realms she calls her own,She sees the splendour of the Son,

ííííHis dreaded glories shining forth;She sees Him clad in rolling thunder,She sees the rocks all quake with wonder,

ííííWhen God before her stands in wrath.She sees He comes her Judge to be,

ííííShe feels the awful pangs inside her,Herself to slay endeavours she,

ííííBut e'en this comfort is denied her.

ííííNow looks she back, with pains untold,Upon those happy times of old,

ííííWhen those glories gave her joy;When yet her heart revered the truth,When her glad soul, in endless youth

ííííAnd rapture dwelt, without alloy.She calls to mind with madden'd thought

ííííHow over man her wiles prevail'd;To take revenge on God she sought,

ííííAnd feels the vengeance it entail'd.

ííííGod was made man, and came to earth.Then Satan cried with fearful mirth:

íííí"E'en He my victim now shall be!"He sought to slay the Lord Most High,The world's Creator now must die;

ííííBut, Satan, endless woe to thee!Thou thought'st to overcome Him then,

ííííRejoicing in His suffering;But he in triumph comes again

ííííTo bind thee: Death! where is thy sting?

ííííSpeak, Hell! where is thy victory?Thy power destroy'd and scatter'd see!

ííííKnow'st thou not now the Highest's might?See, Satan, see thy rule o'erthrown!

ííííBy thousand-varying pangs weigh'd down,Thou dwell'st in dark and endless night.

ííííAs though by lightning struck thou liest,No gleam of rapture far or wide;

ííííIn vain! no hope thou there decriest,--For me alone Messiah died!

ííííA howling rises through the air,A trembling fills each dark vault there,

ííííWhen Christ to Hell is seen to come.She snarls with rage, but needs must cowerBefore our mighty hero's power;

ííííHe signs--and Hell is straightway dumb.Before his voice the thunders break,

ííííOn high His victor-banner blows;E'en angels at His fury quake,

ííííWhen Christ to the dread judgment goes.

ííííNow speaks He, and His voice is thunder,He speaks, the rocks are rent in sunder,

ííííHis breath is like devouring flames.Thus speaks He: "Tremble, ye accurs'd!He who from Eden hurl'd you erst,

ííííYour kingdom's overthrow proclaims.Look up! My children once were ye,

ííííYour arms against Me then ye turn'd,Ye fell, that ye might sinners be,

ííííYe've now the wages that ye earn'd.

íííí"My greatest foeman from that day,Ye led my dearest friends astray,--

ííííAs ye had fallen, man must fall.To kill him evermore ye sought,'They all shall die the death,' ye thought;

ííííBut howl! for Me I won them all.For them alone did I descend,

ííííFor them pray'd, suffer'd, perish'd I.Ye ne'er shall gain your wicked end;

ííííWho trusts in Me shall never die.

íííí"In endless chains here lie ye now,Nothing can save you from the slough.

ííííNot boldness, not regret for crime.Lie, then, and writhe in brimstone fire!'Twas ye yourselves drew down Mine ire,

ííííLie and lament throughout all time!And also ye, whom I selected,

ííííE'en ye forever I disown,For ye My saving grace rejected

ííííYe murmur? blame yourselves alone!

íííí"Ye might have lived with Me in bliss,For I of yore had promis'd this;

ííííYe sinn'd, and all My precepts slightedWrapp'd in the sleep of sin ye dwelt,Now is My fearful judgment felt,

ííííBy a just doom your guilt requited."--Thus spake He, and a fearful storm

ííííFrom Him proceeds, the lightnings glow,The thunders seize each wicked form,

ííííAnd hurl them in the gulf below.

ííííThe God-man closeth Hell's sad doors,In all His majesty He soars

ííííFrom those dark regions back to light.He sitteth at the Father's side;Oh, friends, what joy doth this betide!

ííííFor us, for us He still will fight!The angels sacred quire around

ííííRejoice before the mighty Lord,So that all creatures hear the sound:

íííí"Zebaoth's God be aye ador'd!"

ííííANTIQUES.

íííí-----LEOPOLD, DUKE OF BRUNSWICK.

íííí[Written on the occasion of the death, by drowning, of thePrince.]

ííííTHOU wert forcibly seized by the hoary lord of the river,--

ííííHolding thee, ever he shares with thee his streaming domain,Calmly sleepest thou near his urn as it silently trickles,

ííííTill thou to action art roused, waked by the swift-rolling flood.Kindly be to the people, as when thou still wert a mortal,

ííííPerfecting that as a god, which thou didst fail in, as man.

íííí1785.-----TO THE HUSBANDMAN.

ííííSMOOTHLY and lightly the golden seed by the furrow is cover'd;

ííííYet will a deeper one, friend, cover thy bones at the last.Joyously plough'd and sow'd! Here food all living is budding,

ííííE'en from the side of the tomb Hope will not vanish away.

íííí1789.*-----ANACREON'S GRAVE.

ííííHERE where the roses blossom, where vines round the laurels are twining,

ííííWhere the turtle-dove calls, where the blithe cricket is heard,Say, whose grave can this be, with life by all the Immortals

ííííBeauteously planted and deck'd?--Here doth Anacreon sleepSpring and summer and autumn rejoiced the thrice-happy minstrel,

ííííAnd from the winter this mound kindly hath screen'd him at last.

íííí1789.*-----THE BRETHREN.

ííííSLUMBER and Sleep, two brethren ordain'd by the gods to their service,

ííííWere by Prometheus implored, comfort to give to his race;But though so light to the gods, too heavy for man was their burden,

ííííWe in their slumber find sleep, we in their sleep meet with death.

íííí1789.*-----MEASURE OF TIME.

ííííEROS, what mean'st thou by this? In each of thine hands is an hourglass!

ííííWhat, oh thou frivolous god! twofold thy measure of time?"Slowly run from the one, the hours of lovers when parted;

ííííWhile through the other they rush swiftly, as soon as they meet."

íííí1789.*-----WARNING.

ííííWAKEN not Amor from sleep! The beauteous urchin still slumbers;

ííííGo, and complete thou the task, that to the day is assign'd!Thus doth the prudent mother with care turn time to her profit,

ííííWhile her babe is asleep, for 'twill awake but too soon.

íííí1785.*-----SOLITUDE.

ííííOH ye kindly nymphs, who dwell 'mongst the rocks and the thickets,

ííííGrant unto each whatsoe'er he may in silence desire!Comfort impart to the mourner, and give to the doubter instruction,

ííííAnd let the lover rejoice, finding the bliss that he craves.For from the gods ye received what they ever denied unto mortals,

ííííPower to comfort and aid all who in you may confide.

íííí1782.-----THE CHOSEN CLIFF.

ííííHERE in silence the lover fondly mused on his loved one;

ííííGladly he spake to me thus: "Be thou my witness, thou stone!Yet thou must not be vainglorious, thou hast many companions;

ííííUnto each rock on the plain, where I, the happy one, dwell,Unto each tree of the wood that I cling to, as onward I ramble,

íííí'Be thou a sign of my bliss!' shout I, and then 'tis ordain'd.Yet to thee only I lend a voice, as a Muse from the people

ííííChooseth one for herself, kissing his lips as a friend."

íííí1782.-----THE CONSECRATED SPOT.

ííííWHEN in the dance of the Nymphs, in the moonlight so holy assembled,

ííííMingle the Graces, down from Olympus in secret descending,Here doth the minstrel hide, and list to their numbers enthralling,

ííííHere doth he watch their silent dances' mysterious measure.All that is glorious in Heaven, and all that the earth in her beauty

ííííEver hath brought into life, the dreamer awake sees before him;All he repeats to the Muses, and lest the gods should be anger'd,

ííííHow to tell of secrets discreetly, the Muses instruct him.

íííí1789.*-----THE INSTRUCTORS.

ííííWHEN Diogenes quietly sunn'd himself in his barrel,

ííííWhen Calanus with joy leapt in the flame-breathing grave,Oh, what noble lessons were those for the rash son of Philip,

ííííWere not the lord of the world e'en for instruction too great!

íííí1789.*-----THE UNEQUAL MARRIAGE,

ííííEVEN this heavenly pair were unequally match'd when united:

ííííPsyche grew older and wise, Amor remain'd still a child,

íííí1789.*-----EXCUSE.

ííííTHOU dost complain of woman for changing from one to another?

ííííCensure her not: for she seeks one who will constant remain.

íííí1789.*-----SAKONTALA.

ííííWOULDST thou the blossoms of spring, as well as the fruits of the autumn,

ííííWouldst thou what charms and delights, wouldst thou what

ííííplenteously, feeds,Would thou include both Heaven and earth in one designation,

ííííAll that is needed is done, when I Sakontala name.

íííí1792.-----THE MUSE'S MIRROR.

ííííEARLY one day, the Muse, when eagerly bent on adornment,Follow'd a swift-running streamlet, the quietest nook by it seeking.Quickly and noisily flowing, the changeful surface distortedEver her moving form; the goddess departed in anger.Yet the stream call'd mockingly after her, saying: "What, truly!Wilt thou not view, then, the truth, in my mirror so clearly depicted?"But she already was far away, on the brink of the ocean,In her figure rejoicing, and duly arranging her garland.

íííí1799.*-----PHOEBUS AND HERMES.

ííííDELOS' stately ruler, and Maia's son, the adroit one,

ííííWarmly were striving, for both sought the great prize to obtain.Hermes the lyre demanded, the lyre was claim'd by Apollo,

ííííYet were the hearts of the foes fruitlessly nourish'd by hope.For on a sudden Ares burst in, with fury decisive,

ííííDashing in twain the gold toy, brandishing wildly his sword.Hermes, malicious one, laughed beyond measure; yet deep-seated sorrow

ííííSeized upon Phoebus's heart, seized on the heart of each Muse.

íííí1799.*-----THE NEW AMOR.

ííííAMOR, not the child, the youthful lover of Psyche,Look'd round Olympus one day, boldly, to triumph inured;There  he espied a goddess, the fairest amongst the immortals,--Venus Urania she,--straight was his passion inflamed.Even the holy one powerless proved, alas! 'gainst his wooing,--Tightly embraced in his arm, held her the daring one fast.Then from their union arose a new, a more beauteous Amor,Who from his father his wit, grace from his mother derives.Ever thou'lt find him join'd in the kindly Muses' communion,And his charm-laden bolt foundeth the love of the arts.

íííí1792.-----THE GARLANDS.

ííííKLOPSTOCK would lead us away from Pindus; no longer for laurelMay we be eager--the homely acorn alone must content us;Yet he himself his more-than-epic crusade is conductingHigh on Golgotha's summit, that foreign gods he may honour!Yet, on what hill he prefers, let him gather the angels together,Suffer deserted disciples to weep o'er the grave of the just one:There where a hero and saint hath died, where a bard breath'd his numbers,Both for our life and our death an ensample of courage resplendentAnd of the loftiest human worth to bequeath,--ev'ry nationThere will joyously kneel in devotion ecstatic, reveringThorn and laurel garland, and all its charms and its tortures.

íííí1815.*-----THE SWISS ALPS.

ííííYESTERDAY brown was still thy head, as the locks of my loved one,

ííííWhose sweet image so dear silently beckons afar.Silver-grey is the early snow to-day on thy summit,

ííííThrough the tempestuous night streaming fast over thy brow.Youth, alas, throughout life as closely to age is united

ííííAs, in some changeable dream, yesterday blends with to-day.

ííííUri, October 7th, 1797.-----DISTICHS.

ííííCHORDS are touch'd by Apollo,--the death-laden bow, too, he bendeth;

ííííWhile he the shepherdess charms, Python he lays in the dust.-----WHAT is merciful censure? To make thy faults appear smaller?

ííííMay be to veil them? No, no! O'er them to raise thee on high!-----DEMOCRATIC food soon cloys on the multitude's stomach;But I'll wager, ere long, other thou'lt give them instead.-----WHAT in France has pass'd by, the Germans continue to practise,

ííííFor the proudest of men flatters the people and fawns.-----WHO is the happiest of men? He who values the merits of others,And in their pleasure takes joy, even as though 'twere his own.-----NOT in the morning alone, not only at mid-day he charmeth;

ííííEven at setting, the sun is still the same glorious planet.-----

ííííVENETIAN EPIGRAMS.(Written in 1790.)-----URN and sarcophagus erst were with life adorn'd by the heathen

ííííFauns are dancing around, while with the Bacchanal troopChequerd circles they trace; and the goat-footed, puffy-cheekd player

ííííWildly produceth hoarse tones out of the clamorous horn.Cymbals and drums resound; we see and we hear, too, the marble.

ííííFluttering bird! oh how sweet tastes the ripe fruit to thy bill!Noise there is none to disturb thee, still less to scare away Amor,

ííííWho, in the midst of the throng, learns to delight in his torch.Thus doth fullness overcome death; and the ashes there cover'd

ííííSeem, in that silent domain, still to be gladdend with life.Thus may the minstrel's sarcophagus be hereafter surrounded

ííííWith such a scroll, which himself richly with life has adorn'd.-----CLASP'D in my arms for ever eagerly hold I my mistress,

ííííEver my panting heart throbs wildly against her dear breast,And on her knees forever is leaning my head, while I'm gazing

ííííNow  on her sweet-smiling mouth, now on her bright sparkling eyes."Oh thou effeminate!" spake one, "and thus, then, thy days thou

ííííart spending?"

ííííAh, they in sorrow are spent. List while I tell thee my tale:Yes! I have left my only joy in life far behind me,

ííííTwenty long days hath my car borne me away from her sight.Vettrini defy me, while crafty chamberlains flatter,

ííííAnd the sly Valet de place thinks but of lies and deceit.If I attempt to escape, the Postmaster fastens upon me,

ííííPostboys the upper hand get, custom-house duties enrage."Truly, I can't understand thee! thou talkest enigmas! thou seemest

ííííWrapp'd in a blissful repose, glad as Rinaldo of yore:Ah, I  myself understand full well; 'tis my body that travels,

ííííAnd 'tis my spirit that rests still in my mistress's arms.-----I WOULD liken this gondola unto the soft-rocking cradle,

ííííAnd the chest on its deck seems a vast coffin to be.Yes! 'tween the cradle and coffin, we totter and waver for ever

ííííOn the mighty canal, careless our lifetime is spent.-----WHY are the people thus busily moving? For food they are seeking,

ííííChildren they fain would beget, feeding them well as they can.Traveller, mark this well, and when thou art home, do thou likewise!

ííííMore can no mortal effect, work with what ardour he will.-----I WOULD compare to the land this anvil, its lord to the hammer,

ííííAnd to the people the plate, which in the middle is bent.Sad is the poor tin-plate's lot, when the blows are but given at random:

ííííNe'er will the kettle be made, while they uncertainly fall.-----WHAT is the life of a man? Yet thousands are ever accustom'dFreely to talk about man,--what he has done, too, and how.Even less is a poem; yet thousands read and enjoy it,Thousands abuse it.--My friend, live and continue to rhyme!-----MERRY'S the trade of a poet; but somewhat a dear one, I fear me

ííííFor, as my book grows apace, all of my sequins I lose.-----Is' thou'rt in earnest, no longer delay, but render me happy;Art thou in jest? Ah, sweet love! time for all jesting is past.-----ART thou, then, vex'd at my silence? What shall I speak of? Thou markest

ííííNeither my sorrowful sigh, nor my soft eloquent look.Only one goddess is able the seal of my lips to unloosen,--

ííííWhen by Aurora I'm found, slumbering calm on thy breast.Ah, then my hymn in the ears of the earliest gods shall be chaunted,
